 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Luzon broad-toothed rat (Abditomys latidens) is a species of rodent in the family Muridae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

It is endemic to central and northern Luzon in the Philippines
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is the only member of the genus Abditomys
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The abdomen (less formally called the belly, stomach, tummy or midriff) constitutes the part of the body between the thorax (chest) and pelvis, in humans and in other vertebrates
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The region occupied by the abdomen is termed the abdominal cavity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In arthropods it is the posterior tagma of the body; it follows the thorax or cephalothorax
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The abdomen stretches from the thorax at the thoracic diaphragm to the pelvis at the pelvic brim
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The pelvic brim stretches from the lumbosacral joint (the intervertebral disc between L5 and S1) to the pubic symphysis and is the edge of the pelvic inlet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The space above this inlet and under the thoracic diaphragm is termed the abdominal cavity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The boundary of the abdominal cavity is the abdominal wall in the front and the peritoneal surface at the rear
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The abdomen (less formally called the belly, stomach, tummy or midriff) constitutes the part of the body between the thorax (chest) and pelvis, in humans and in other vertebrates
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The region occupied by the abdomen is termed the abdominal cavity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In arthropods it is the posterior tagma of the body; it follows the thorax or cephalothorax
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The abdomen stretches from the thorax at the thoracic diaphragm to the pelvis at the pelvic brim
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The pelvic brim stretches from the lumbosacral joint (the intervertebral disc between L5 and S1) to the pubic symphysis and is the edge of the pelvic inlet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The space above this inlet and under the thoracic diaphragm is termed the abdominal cavity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The boundary of the abdominal cavity is the abdominal wall in the front and the peritoneal surface at the rear
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Paracentesis (from Greek κεντάω, "to pierce") is a form of body fluid sampling procedure, generally referring to peritoneocentesis (also called laparocentesis or abdominal paracentesis) in which the peritoneal cavity is punctured by a needle to sample peritoneal fluid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The procedure is used to remove fluid from the peritoneal cavity, particularly if this cannot be achieved with medication
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The most common indication is ascites that has developed in people with cirrhosis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
This is a list of Latin words with derivatives in English (and other modern languages)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Ancient orthography did not distinguish between i and j or between u and v
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many modern works distinguish u from v but not i from j
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In this article, both distinctions are shown as they are helpful when tracing the origin of English words
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 See also Latin spelling and pronunciation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abductive reasoning (also called abduction, abductive inference, or retroduction) is a form of logical inference which starts with an observation then seeks to find the simplest and most likely explanation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In abductive reasoning, unlike in deductive reasoning, the premises do not guarantee the conclusion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 One can understand abductive reasoning as inference to the best explanation, although not all uses of the terms abduction and inference to the best explanation are exactly equivalent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the 1990s, as computing power grew, the fields of law, computer science, and artificial intelligence research spurred renewed interest in the subject of abduction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Diagnostic expert systems frequently employ abduction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abecedarians is a name given to a 16th-century German sect of Anabaptists who rejected all human learning
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Questions have been raised as to the historical accuracy of the name and sect
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An abecedarius is an acrostic in which the first letter of every word, strophe or verse follows the order of the alphabet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abecedarius is also a generic term for an alphabet book, which dates back to Biblical writings such as the Psalms, which used successive letters of the Hebrew alphabet as the first letter of each stanza
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Another example is Old Polish poem Skarga umierającego (A Dying Man Complaint)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Such poems are important historical sources for development of orthography
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They can be proofs that some letters were used long ago and later were totally forgotten
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Bishop Constantine of Preslav's abecedarius (shown on the right) from 9th century documents the early Slavic alphabet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Nowadays abecedariuses are written chiefly for children
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The most famous example of abecedarius in English literature is Geoffrey Chaucer's ABC
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An abecedarium (or abecedary) is an inscription consisting of the letters of an alphabet, almost always listed in order
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Typically, abecedaria (or abecedaries) are practice exercises
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Cain and Abel (; Hebrew: הֶבֶל ,קַיִן‎ Qayin, Heḇel; Arabic: قابيل، هابيل‎‎ Qābīl, Hābīl) were sons of Adam and Eve in the biblical Book of Genesis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Cain, the firstborn, tilled the soil, and his brother Abel was a shepherd
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The brothers made sacrifices to God, each of his own produce, but God favored Abel's sacrifice instead of Cain's
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Cain murdered Abel
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 God punished Cain to a life of wandering, but set a mark on him so that no man would kill him
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Cain then dwelt in the land of Nod (נוֹד‎, "wandering"), where he built a city and fathered the line of descendants beginning with Enoch
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The narrative never explicitly states Cain's motive (though it does describe him as being wrathful, and his motive is traditionally assumed to be envy), nor God's reason for rejecting Cain's sacrifice, nor details on the identity of Cain's wife
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some traditional interpretations consider Cain to be the originator of evil, violence, or greed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 According to Genesis, Cain was the first human born and Abel was the first to die
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Cain and Abel (; Hebrew: הֶבֶל ,קַיִן‎ Qayin, Heḇel; Arabic: قابيل، هابيل‎‎ Qābīl, Hābīl) were sons of Adam and Eve in the biblical Book of Genesis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Cain, the firstborn, tilled the soil, and his brother Abel was a shepherd
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The brothers made sacrifices to God, each of his own produce, but God favored Abel's sacrifice instead of Cain's
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Cain murdered Abel
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 God punished Cain to a life of wandering, but set a mark on him so that no man would kill him
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Cain then dwelt in the land of Nod (נוֹד‎, "wandering"), where he built a city and fathered the line of descendants beginning with Enoch
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The narrative never explicitly states Cain's motive (though it does describe him as being wrathful, and his motive is traditionally assumed to be envy), nor God's reason for rejecting Cain's sacrifice, nor details on the identity of Cain's wife
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some traditional interpretations consider Cain to be the originator of evil, violence, or greed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 According to Genesis, Cain was the first human born and Abel was the first to die
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abelia  is a genus of about 30 species and many hybrids in the honeysuckle family Caprifoliaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some authors, including the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group, consider Abelia and related genera to belong instead in the segregate family Linnaeaceae, also including such genera as Linnaea, Abelia, Dipelta, Kolkwitzia, and Zabelia, but not such others as Lonicera or Symphoricarpos, included by them instead in a more narrowly viewed Caprifoliaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Abelias are shrubs from 1–6 m tall, native to eastern Asia (Japan west to the Himalaya) and southern North America (Mexico); the species from warm climates are evergreen, and colder climate species deciduous
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The leaves are opposite or in whorls of three, ovate, glossy, dark green, 1
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5–8 cm long, turning purplish-bronze to red in autumn in the deciduous species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The flowers appear in the upper leaf axils and stem ends, 1-8 together in a short cyme; they are pendulous, white to pink, bell-shaped with a five-lobed corolla, 1–5 cm long, and usually scented
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Flowering continues over a long and continuous period from late spring to fall
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Type species of this genus is Abelia chinensis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The generic name commemorates Clarke Abel, a keen naturalist who accompanied Lord Amherst's unsuccessful embassy to China in 1816 as surgeon, under the sponsorship of Sir Joseph Banks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 All of Abel's seeds and plants were lost in a shipwreck on the homeward voyage, however; living plants of Abelia chinensis were first imported to England in 1844 by Robert Fortune, who introduced A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 uniflora the following year
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The showy semi-hardy Mexican A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 floribunda of the Cordillera of Oaxaca was introduced to English horticulture in 1841
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Selected species
Hybrids
Abelia x grandiflora Hort
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ex
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Bailey
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abelmoschus is a genus of about fifteen species of flowering plants in the mallow family, Malvaceae, native to tropical Africa, Asia and northern Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was formerly included within Hibiscus, but is now classified as a distinct genus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The genus comprises annual and perennial herbaceous plants, growing to 2 m tall
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The leaves are 10–40 cm long and broad, palmately lobed with 3-7 lobes, the lobes are very variable in depth, from barely lobed, to cut almost to the base of the leaf
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The flowers are 4–8 cm diameter, with five white to yellow petals, often with a red or purple spot at the base of each petal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The fruit is a capsule, 5–20 cm long, containing numerous seeds
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Abelmoschus species are used as food plants by the larvae of some Lepidoptera species including Chionodes hibiscella which has been recorded on A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 moschatus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Selected Species
Abelmoschus caillei - (syn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hibsicus manihot var
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 caillei)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 West African okra
Abelmoschus esculentus - (syn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hibiscus esculentus)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Okra
Abelmoschus manihot - (syn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hibiscus manihot)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aibika
Abelmoschus moschatus - (syn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hibiscus abelmoschus)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Musk Mallow
Abelmoschus ficulneus - (syn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hibiscus ficulneus)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 White Wild Musk Mallow
Abelmoschus crinitus - (syb
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hibiscus crinitus)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abelmoschus moschatus (Abelmosk, ambrette seeds, annual hibiscus, Bamia Moschata, Galu Gasturi, muskdana, musk mallow, musk okra, musk seeds, ornamental okra, rose mallow seeds, tropical jewel hibiscus, Yorka okra) is an aromatic and medicinal plant native to India in the Malvaceae family
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abend is a German-language surname, meaning "evening"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Notable people with the surname include:
Edward Abend, (1822–1904), German American politician
Guy Abend (born 1990), Israeli footballer
Harry Abend (born 1937), Venezuelan artist
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aberdeen (; Scots: Aiberdeen,  listen ; Scottish Gaelic: Obar Dheathain [ˈopər ˈʝɛ
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
ɛɲ]; Latin: Aberdonia) is Scotland's third most populous city, one of Scotland's 32 local government council areas and the United Kingdom's 37th most populous built-up area, with an official population estimate of 196,670 for the city of Aberdeen  and 229,800 for the local authority area
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Nicknames include the Granite City, the Grey City and the Silver City with the Golden Sands
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During the mid-18th to mid-20th centuries, Aberdeen's buildings incorporated locally quarried grey granite, which can sparkle like silver because of its high mica content
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Since the discovery of North Sea oil in the 1970s, other nicknames have been the Oil Capital of the World or the Energy Capital of the World
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The area around Aberdeen has been settled since at least 8,000 years ago, when prehistoric villages lay around the mouths of the rivers Dee and Don
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The city has a long, sandy coastline and a marine climate, the latter resulting in chilly summers and mild winters
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Aberdeen received Royal Burgh status from David I of Scotland (1124–53), transforming the city economically
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The city's two universities, the University of Aberdeen, founded in 1495, and Robert Gordon University, which was awarded university status in 1992, make Aberdeen the educational centre of the north-east of Scotland
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The traditional industries of fishing, paper-making, shipbuilding, and textiles have been overtaken by the oil industry and Aberdeen's seaport
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aberdeen Heliport is one of the busiest commercial heliports in the world and the seaport is the largest in the north-east of Scotland
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Aberdeen has won the Britain in Bloom competition a record-breaking ten times, and hosts the Aberdeen International Youth Festival, a major international event which attracts up to 1000 of the most talented young performing arts companies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2015, Mercer named Aberdeen the 57th most liveable city in the world, as well as the fourth most liveable city in Britain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2012, HSBC named Aberdeen as a leading business hub and one of eight 'super cities' spearheading the UK's economy, marking it as the only city in Scotland to receive this accolade
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Eurasian siskin (Spinus spinus) is a small passerine bird in the finch family Fringillidae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is also called the European siskin, common siskin or just siskin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other (archaic) names include black-headed goldfinch, barley bird and aberdevine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is very common throughout Europe and Asia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is found in forested areas, both coniferous and mixed woodland where it feeds on seeds of all kinds, especially of alder and conifers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

It can be distinguished from other similar finches by the color of the plumage
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The upper parts are greyish green and the under parts grey-streaked white
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its wings are black with a conspicuous yellow wing bar, and the tail is black with yellow sides
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The male has a mainly yellow face and breast, with a neat black cap
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Female and young birds have a greyish green head and no cap
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a trusting, sociable and active bird
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The song of this bird is a pleasant mix of twitters and trills
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For these reasons it is often raised in captivity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

These birds have an unusual migration pattern as every few years in winter they migrate southwards in large numbers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The reasons for this behaviour are not known but may be related to climatic factors and above all the availability of food
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In this way overwintering populations can thrive where food is abundant
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This small finch is an acrobatic feeder, often hanging upside-down like a tit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It will visit garden bird feeding stations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aberrant is a role-playing game created by White Wolf Game Studio in 1999, set in 2008 in a world where super-powered humans started appearing one day in 1998
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is the middle setting in the greater Trinity Universe timeline, chronologically situated about 90 years after Adventure!, White Wolf's Pulp era game, and over a century before the psionic escapades of Trinity/Aeon
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The game deals with how the players' meta-human characters (called "novas") fit into a mundane world when they most definitely are not mundane, as well as how the mundane populace react to the sudden emergence of novas
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The original Aberrant product line was discontinued in 2002, though a d20 System version was released in 2004
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Onyx Path Publishing has recently acquired the rights to the Trinity Universe and has announced its intention to release a new edition of Aberrant
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abbot, meaning father, is an ecclesiastical title given to the male head of a monastery in various traditions, including Christianity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The office may also be given as an honorary title to a clergyman who is not the head of a monastery
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The female equivalent is abbess
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
ABET, incorporated as the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology, Inc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, is a non-governmental organization that accredits post-secondary education programs in "applied science, computing, engineering, and engineering technology"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The accreditation of these programs occurs mainly in the United States but also internationally
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As of October 2016, 3,709 programs are accredited, distributed over 752 universities and colleges in 30 countries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

ABET is the recognized U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 accreditor of college and university programs in applied science, computing, engineering, and technology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ABET also provides leadership internationally through workshops, consultancies, memoranda of understanding, and mutual recognition agreements, such as the Washington Accord
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ABET has been recognized by the Council for Higher Education Accreditation (CHEA) since 1997
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Also, ABET evaluates programs offered in a 100-percent online format
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abetalipoproteinemia, or Bassen-Kornzweig syndrome, is a rare autosomal recessive disorder that interferes with the normal absorption of fat and fat-soluble vitamins from food
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is caused by a mutation in microsomal triglyceride transfer protein resulting in deficiencies in the apolipoproteins B-48 and B-100, which are used in the synthesis and exportation of chylomicrons and VLDL respectively
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is not to be confused with familial dysbetalipoproteinemia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
ABET, incorporated as the Accreditation Board for Engineering and Technology, Inc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, is a non-governmental organization that accredits post-secondary education programs in "applied science, computing, engineering, and engineering technology"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The accreditation of these programs occurs mainly in the United States but also internationally
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As of October 2016, 3,709 programs are accredited, distributed over 752 universities and colleges in 30 countries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

ABET is the recognized U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 accreditor of college and university programs in applied science, computing, engineering, and technology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ABET also provides leadership internationally through workshops, consultancies, memoranda of understanding, and mutual recognition agreements, such as the Washington Accord
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ABET has been recognized by the Council for Higher Education Accreditation (CHEA) since 1997
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Also, ABET evaluates programs offered in a 100-percent online format
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abettor (from to abet, Old French abeter, à and beter, to bait, urge dogs upon any one; this word is probably of Scandinavian origin, meaning to cause to bite), is a legal term implying one who instigates, encourages or assists another to commit an offence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An abettor differs from an accessory in that he must be present at the commission of the crime; in addition they are equally guilty as they knowingly and voluntarily assist in the commission of that crime
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 All abettors (with certain exceptions) are principals, and, in the absence of specific statutory provision to the contrary, are punishable to the same extent as the actual perpetrator of the offence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A person may in certain cases be convicted as an abettor in the commission of an offence in which he or she could not be a principal, e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 a woman or boy under fourteen years of age in aiding rape, or a solvent person in aiding and abetting a bankrupt to commit offences against the bankruptcy laws
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

More recently, an abettor is generally known as an accomplice
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Order of Prince Danilo I of Montenegro (Montenegrin: Орден Књаза Данила I, Orden Knjaza Danila I) was an order of the Principality, and later Kingdom, of Montenegro
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is currently granted as a dynastic honor by the undisputed head of the House of Petrović-Njegoš, Nicholas Petrović Njegoš II
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although no longer a state order, recognition is indicated by the acceptance of the former President of Montenegro, Filip Vujanović
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 More formal recognition by the Republic of Montenegro is implicit in the 2011 "Law on the Status of the Descendants of the Petrović Njegoš Dynasty", which recognizes the current crown prince as head of the Royal Family and specifically sanctions the use of the royal family's heraldic symbols
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The act also provides the Crown Prince housing and a pension and has been noted as conferring a sort of "quasi restoration" of the throne
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In a May 15th Pobjeda newspaper interview, Prince Nikola cited Article 3 of this law as the basis for his May 5th re-institution of the Order, which he emphasized was "historically an extremely valuable Montenegrin decoration
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
" He went on to explain that the order can be awarded to Montenegrin nationals and worthy foreigners on two general grounds: (1), for support and affirmation of Montenegrin independence and the royal tradition of the Petrovic Njegos dynasty, and (2) to those whose "scientific or social work contributed to the development of culture, art and science
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
" The Order has since been bestowed on a number of high dignitaries internationally
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In an April 17, 2016 visit to Rome, HRH Prince Nikola II Petrovic Njegoš met with Pope Francis and other high Vatican officials bestowing the dynastic honor on the Cambodian ambassador, His Highness Prince Sisowath Ravivaddhana Monipong, the Montenegrin ambassador to the Holy See Veselin Šuković, as well as the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Ambassador to the Holy See Kenneth Francis Hackett, and the ambassador of Hungary HIRH Eduard von Habsburg-Lothringen, among several other Vatican officials and Italian nobles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The official Representative of the Royal House and the order is H
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
E
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Giuseppe Tedischi GCDO, who also has the Vatican charge "Addetto di Anticamera di Sua Santità," or Officer of Antechamber of His Holiness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Order was the first Montenegrin dynastic and state Order established by Prince Danilo Petrović Njegoš in 1853, as the Order of Danilo I for the Independence of Montenegro in 1852-53
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This decoration is still awarded to prominent champions of the preservation of Montenegrin independence and, as indicated above, for other humanitarian, scientific, artistic and pro-social achievements pursuant to the conditions by which the Order is awarded were defined by statute
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Alterations were made to the appearance of the original decoration created by Prince Danilo, and during the rule of His Majesty King Nikola I Petrović Njegoš the Order underwent two restructures
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During the first restructure in 1861, three classes were introduced, while in the second restructure, from 1873, an additional class was added, so that not only is there a star in the 1st class but also a 2nd class with star was introduced
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 By 1922, the order consisted of five classes: Grand Cross, Grand Officer, Commander, Officer, and knight or Chevalier
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 More changes occurred and today's five classes are:
Grand Cross I, (Sash and Large Chest Star)--Cavaliere di Grande Croce (1st Class)
Grand Officer II (Neck Cross, Sash, Chest Star)--Grande Uffiale (2nd Class)
Knight Commander III Neck Cross, Chest Star--Commendatore (3rd Class)
Knight IV Chest Cross--Cavaliere (4th Class)
Member V Chest Cross (Black and Silver)--Member (5th Class)
On Saturday June 4, 2005, Cetinje, the old Royal Capital of Montenegro, hosted the first gala ceremony of the Order in the country in 90 years
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abeyance (from the Old French abeance meaning "gaping") is a state of expectancy in respect of property, titles or office, when the right to them is not vested in any one person, but awaits the appearance or determination of the true owner
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In law, the term abeyance can only be applied to such future estates as have not yet vested or possibly may not vest
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, an estate is granted to A for life, with remainder to the heir of B
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During B's lifetime, the remainder is in abeyance, for until the death of B it is uncertain who is B's heir
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Similarly the freehold of a benefice, on the death of the incumbent, is said to be in abeyance until the next incumbent takes possession
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The term hold in abeyance is used in lawsuits and court cases when a case is temporarily put on hold
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
This list of ship directions explains dozens of related terms such as fore, aft, astern, aboard, or topside
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For background, see below: Origins
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

abaft (preposition)
at or toward the stern of a ship, or further back from a location, e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 the mizzenmast is abaft the mainmast
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aboard
onto or within a ship, or in a group
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

above
a higher deck of the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aft (adjective)
toward the stern of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

adrift
floating in the water without propulsion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aground
resting on the shore or wedged against the sea floor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

ahull
with sails furled and helm lashed alee
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

alee
on or toward the lee (the downwind side)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aloft
the stacks, masts, rigging, or other area above the highest solid structure
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

amidships
near the middle part of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aport
toward the port side of a ship (opposite of "astarboard")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

ashore
on or towards the shore or land
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

astarboard
toward the starboard side of a ship (opposite of "aport")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

astern (adjective)
toward the rear of a ship (opposite of "forward")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

athwartships
toward the sides of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aweather
toward the weather or windward side of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aweigh
just clear of the sea floor, as with an anchor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

below
a lower deck of the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

belowdecks
inside or into a ship, or down to a lower deck
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

bilge
the underwater part of a ship between the flat of the bottom and the vertical topsides
bottom
the lowest part of the ship's hull
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

bow or stem
front of a ship (opposite of "stern")
centerline
an imaginary, central line drawn from the bow to the stern
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

fore or forward
at or toward the front of a ship or further ahead of a location (opposite of "aft")
inboard
attached inside the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

keel
the bottom structure of a ship's hull
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

leeward
side or direction away from the wind (opposite of "windward")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

on deck
to an outside or muster deck (as "all hands on deck")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

on board
somewhere on or in the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

outboard
attached outside the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

port
the left side of the ship, facing forward (opposite of "starboard")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

starboard
the right side of the ship, when facing forward (opposite of "port")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

stern
the rear of a ship (opposite of "bow")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

topside
on the ship's main weather deck
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

underdeck
a lower deck of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

yardarm
an end of a yard spar below a sail
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

waterline
where the water surface meets the ship's hull
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

weather
side or direction from which wind blows (same as "windward")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

windward
side or direction from which wind blows (opposite of "leeward")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abhenry is the CGS (centimeter-gram-second) electromagnetic unit of inductance, equal to one billionth of a henry
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abhor (or Amba Hor) and Mehraela were a brother and sister who were martyrs for the Christian faith
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The book of their "acts" has been lost
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their feast day is celebrated on January 9 in the Coptic Church
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abhorrence is a Finnish death metal band originally formed in 1989
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abhorrers, the name given in 1679 to the persons who expressed their abhorrence at the action of those who had signed petitions urging King Charles II of England to assemble Parliament
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Feeling against Catholics, and especially against James, Duke of York, was running strongly; the Exclusion Bill had been passed by the House of Commons, and the popularity of James Scott, 1st Duke of Monmouth, was very great
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

To prevent this bill from passing into law, Charles had dissolved parliament in July 1679, and in the following October had prorogued its successor, which became known as the Exclusion Bill Parliament, without allowing it to meet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He was then deluged with petitions urging him to call it together, and this agitation was opposed by Sir George Jeffreys and Francis Wythens, who presented addresses expressing abhorrence of the Petitioners, and thus initiated the movement of the abhorrers, who supported the action of the king
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "The frolic went all over England," says Roger North; and the addresses of the Abhorrers which reached the king from all parts of the country formed a counterblast to those of the Petitioners
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is said that the terms Whig and Tory were first applied to English political parties in consequence of this dispute
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abidin or Abdin is both an Arabic given name and surname, meaning "worshippers"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Notable people with the name include:
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"Abide with Me" is a Christian hymn by Scottish Anglican Henry Francis Lyte most often sung to English composer William Henry Monk's tune entitled "Eventide"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Lyte wrote the poem in 1847 and set it to music while he lay dying from tuberculosis; he survived only a further three weeks after its completion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abidin or Abdin is both an Arabic given name and surname, meaning "worshippers"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Notable people with the name include:
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abidjan (French pronunciation: ​[abidʒɑ̃]) is the economic capital of Côte d'Ivoire and is one of the most populous French-speaking cities in Africa
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 According to the 2014 Côte d'Ivoire census, Abidjan's population was 4
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
7 million, which is 20 percent of the overall population of the country, and this also makes it the 4th most populous city proper in Africa, after Lagos, Cairo and Kinshasa
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Considered the cultural crossroads of Africa, Abidjan is characterised by a high level of industrialisation and urbanisation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The city expanded quickly after the construction of a new wharf in 1931, followed by its designation as the capital city of the then-French colony in 1933
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abidjan remained the capital of Côte d'Ivoire after its independence from France in 1960
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The completion of the Vridi Canal in 1951 enabled Abidjan to become an important sea port
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 1983, the city of Yamoussoukro was designated as the official political capital of Cote d'Ivoire
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, almost all political institutions and foreign embassies continue to be located in Abidjan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Because Abidjan is also the largest city in the country and the centre of its economic activity, it has officially been designated as the "economic capital" of the country
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Abidjan Autonomous District, which encompasses the city and some of its suburbs, is one of the 14 districts of Côte d'Ivoire
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Firs (Abies) are a genus of 48–56 species of evergreen coniferous trees in the family Pinaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are found through much of North and Central America, Europe, Asia, and North Africa, occurring in mountains over most of the range
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Firs are most closely related to the genus Cedrus (cedar)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Douglas firs are not true firs, being of the genus Pseudotsuga
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

They are large trees, reaching heights of 10–80 m (33–262 ft) tall and trunk diameters of 0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5–4 m (1 ft 8 in–13 ft 1 in) when mature
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Firs can be distinguished from other members of the pine family by the unique attachment of their needle-like leaves and by their different cones
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Identification of the different species is based on the size and arrangement of the leaves, the size and shape of the cones, and whether the bract scales of the cones are long and exserted, or short and hidden inside the cone
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abigail (Hebrew: אֲבִיגַיִל‎ / אֲבִיגָיִל‎, Modern Avigáyil Tiberian ʾĂḇîḡáyil / ʾĂḇîḡāyil)) spelled Abigal in 2 Samuel 17:25 in the American Standard Version and Ab'igal in the Revised Standard Version, but Abigail in the King James Version}} was the wife of Nabal; she became a wife of the future King David after Nabal's death (1 Samuel 25)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abigail was David's third wife, after Saul's daughter, Michal, whom Saul later married to Palti, son of Laish when David went into hiding, and Ahinoam
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

She became the mother of one of David's sons, who is listed in the Book of Chronicles under the name Daniel, in the Masoretic Text of the Books of Samuel as Chileab, and in the Septuagint text of 2 Samuel 3:3 as Δαλουια, Dalouia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abbot, meaning father, is an ecclesiastical title given to the male head of a monastery in various traditions, including Christianity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The office may also be given as an honorary title to a clergyman who is not the head of a monastery
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The female equivalent is abbess
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abiogenesis (British English: , ), biopoiesis, or informally the origin of life, is the natural process by which life arises from non-living matter, such as simple organic compounds
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abiogenesis is studied through a combination of paleontology, laboratory experiments and extrapolation from the characteristics of modern organisms, and aims to determine how pre-life chemical reactions gave rise to life on Earth
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The study of abiogenesis can be geophysical, chemical, or biological, with more recent approaches attempting a synthesis of all three
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Life itself is dependent upon the specialized chemistry of carbon and water and is largely based upon five different families of chemicals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Lipids are fatty molecules comprising large chemical chains of hydrocarbons and play an important role in the structure of living cell membranes, actively and passively determining the transport of other molecules into and out of cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Carbohydrates are sugars, and as monomer units can be assembled into polymers called polysaccharides, such as cellulose, the rigid chemical of most plant cell walls
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Nitrogenous bases are organic molecules in which the amine group of nitrogen, combined with two hydrogen atoms, plays an important part
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Chlorophyll is based upon a porphyrin ring derived from amine monomer units, and is important in the capture of the energy needed for life
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Nucleic acid monomers are made from a carbohydrate monosaccharide, a nitrogenous base and one or more high energy phosphate groups
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When joined together they form the unit of inheritance, the gene, made from DNA or RNA, which translates the genetic information into protein structures
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The monomer unit of a protein is usually one of 20 amino acids, comprising an amine group, a hydrocarbon, and a carboxylic acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Through a condensation reaction, in which the carboxylic acid of one amino acid is linked to the amine of another with removal of a water molecule, a peptide bond is formed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Polymers of amino acids are termed proteins and these molecules provide many catalytic metabolic functions for living processes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Any successful theory of abiogenesis must explain the origins and interactions of these five classes of molecules
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Many approaches to abiogenesis investigate how self-replicating molecules, or their components, came into existence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is generally thought that current life on Earth is descended from an RNA world, although RNA-based life may not have been the first life to have existed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The classic Miller–Urey experiment and similar research demonstrated that most amino acids, the basic chemical constituents of the proteins used in all living organisms, can be synthesized from inorganic compounds under conditions intended to replicate those of the early Earth
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Various external sources of energy that may have triggered these reactions have been proposed, including lightning and radiation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other approaches ("metabolism-first" hypotheses) focus on understanding how catalysis in chemical systems on the early Earth might have provided the precursor molecules necessary for self-replication
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Complex organic molecules have been found in the Solar System and in interstellar space, and these molecules may have provided starting material for the development of life on Earth
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The panspermia hypothesis alternatively suggests that microscopic life was distributed to the early Earth by meteoroids, asteroids and other small Solar System bodies and that life may exist throughout the Universe
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is speculated that the biochemistry of life may have begun shortly after the Big Bang, 13
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
8 billion years ago, during a habitable epoch when the age of the universe was only 10 to 17 million years old
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The panspermia hypothesis proposes that life originated outside the Earth, not how life came to be
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Nonetheless, Earth remains the only place in the Universe known to harbour life, and fossil evidence from the Earth informs most studies of abiogenesis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 More than 99% of all species of life forms, amounting to over five billion species, that ever lived on Earth are estimated to be extinct
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The age of the Earth is about 4
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
54 billion years old; the earliest undisputed evidence of life on Earth dates from at least 3
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5 billion years ago, and possibly as early as the Eoarchean Era (between 3
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
6 to 4
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
0 billion years ago), after geological crust started to solidify following the molten Hadean Eon
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In May 2017, evidence of the earliest known life on land may have been found in 3
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
48-billion-year-old geyserite and other related mineral deposits (often found around hot springs and geysers) uncovered in the Pilbara Craton of Western Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, there have been a number of discoveries that suggested the earliest appearance of life on Earth was even earlier
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Currently, microfossils within hydrothermal vent precipitates dated from 3
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
77 to 4
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
28 billion years old found in Quebec, Canada may be the oldest record of life on Earth, suggesting "an almost instantaneous emergence of life" after ocean formation 4
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
4 billion years ago
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 According to biologist Stephen Blair Hedges, "If life arose relatively quickly on Earth … then it could be common in the universe
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abiogenesis (British English: , ), biopoiesis, or informally the origin of life, is the natural process by which life arises from non-living matter, such as simple organic compounds
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Cerebellar abiotrophy (CA), also referred to as the cerebellar cortical abiotrophy (CCA), is a genetic neurological disease in animals best known to affect certain breeds of horses, dogs and cats
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can also develop in humans
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It develops when the neurons known as Purkinje cells, located in the cerebellum of the brain, begin to die off
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These cells affect balance and coordination
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They have a critical role to play in the brain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Purkinje layer allows communication between the granular and molecular cortical layers in the cerebellum
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Put simply, without Purkinje cells, an animal loses its sense of space and distance, making balance and coordination difficult
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 People with damage to the cerebellum can experience symptoms like unsteady gait, poor muscle control, and trouble speaking or swallowing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Abiotrophy means the loss of a vital nutritive factor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The exact cause of cerebellar abiotrophy is not known, but it is thought to be due to an intrinsic metabolic defect
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In most cases, the Purkinje neurons begin to die off shortly after the animal is born and the condition is noticeable when the animal is less than six months old, though sometimes the onset of symptoms is gradual and the animal is much older before the owner or caretaker notices a problem
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

CA cannot be prevented, other than by selective breeding to avoid the gene, and it cannot be cured
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Genetic testing can detect carriers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In addition to dogs and horses, there also have been cases of cerebellar abiotrophy in Siamese and Domestic shorthair cats; in Angus, Polled Hereford, Charolais and Holstein Friesian cattle; Merino and Wiltshire sheep; and Yorkshire pigs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abbot, meaning father, is an ecclesiastical title given to the male head of a monastery in various traditions, including Christianity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The office may also be given as an honorary title to a clergyman who is not the head of a monastery
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The female equivalent is abbess
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The term abjection literally means "the state of being cast off
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
" While in common usage it has connotations of degradation, baseness and meanness of spirit, the term has been explored in post-structuralism as that which inherently disturbs conventional identity and cultural concepts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Among the most popular interpretations of abjection is Julia Kristeva's (pursued particularly in her work Powers of Horror)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Kristeva describes subjective horror (abjection) as the feeling when an individual experiences, or is confronted by (both mentally and as a body), what Kristeva terms one's "corporeal reality", or a breakdown in the distinction between what is self and what is other
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The concept of abjection is best described as the process by which one separates one's sense of self – be it physical and biological, social or cultural – from that which one considers intolerable and infringes upon one's 'self', otherwise known as the abject
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The abject is, as such, the "me that is not me
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"
Kristeva's concept of abjection is utilized commonly and effectively to explain popular cultural narratives of horror and misogyny, and builds on the traditional psychoanalytic theories of Sigmund Freud and Jacques Lacan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The term abjection literally means "the state of being cast off
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
" While in common usage it has connotations of degradation, baseness and meanness of spirit, the term has been explored in post-structuralism as that which inherently disturbs conventional identity and cultural concepts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Abjuration is the solemn repudiation, abandonment, or renunciation by or upon oath, often the renunciation of citizenship or some other right or privilege
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term comes from the Latin abjurare, "to forswear"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
