Abkari is a 1988 Malayalam movie starring Mammootty and Ratheesh in the title roles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was written by T
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Damodaran and was directed by I
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 V
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Sasi
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The movie, based on the life of liquor barons and contractors, known as Abkaris, in Kerala, was a super hit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Weaning is the process of gradually introducing a mammal infant to what will be its adult diet and withdrawing the supply of its mother's milk
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The process takes place only in mammals, as only mammals produce milk
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The infant is considered to be fully weaned once it is no longer fed any breast milk (or bottled substitute)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ablation is removal of material from the surface of an object by vaporization, chipping, or other erosive processes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Examples of ablative materials are described below, and include spacecraft material for ascent and atmospheric reentry, ice and snow in glaciology, biological tissues in medicine and passive fire protection materials
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The ablative case (sometimes abbreviated abl) is a grammatical case for nouns, pronouns and adjectives in the grammar of various languages; it is sometimes used to express motion away from something, among other uses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The word "ablative" derives from the Latin ablatus, the (irregular) perfect passive participle of auferre "to carry away"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There is no ablative case in modern Germanic languages such as German, nor in ancient Greek
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In linguistics, apophony (also known as ablaut, (vowel) gradation, (vowel) mutation, alternation, internal modification, stem modification, stem alternation, replacive morphology, stem mutation, internal inflection etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
) is any sound change within a word that indicates grammatical information (often inflectional)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ablaze! is a British indie music fanzine, produced in Manchester and Leeds, that ran for ten issues between 1987 and 1993, and returned for an eleventh issue in 2015
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The fanzine has been made the subject of a book, entitled The City Is Ablaze!, published by Mittens On in 2012
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ablaze! is a British indie music fanzine, produced in Manchester and Leeds, that ran for ten issues between 1987 and 1993, and returned for an eleventh issue in 2015
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The fanzine has been made the subject of a book, entitled The City Is Ablaze!, published by Mittens On in 2012
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Pains of Being Pure at Heart are an American indie pop band from New York City, formed in 2007
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The band currently centers around founding member and principal songwriter Kip Berman (vocals, guitar)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Live he is joined by Christoph Hochheim (guitar), Jen Goma (keyboards, vocals), Jacob Sloan (bass), and Anton Hochheim (drums)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Former members and contributors include Peggy Wang (keyboards, vocals), Connor Hanwick, Kurt Feldman and Alex Naidus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Their first album was a self-released EP, released in 2007
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The release was distributed by Painbow – a record label created by the band
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their debut self-titled full-length album was released on February 3, 2009 via Slumberland Records, a personal favorite label of the band's
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their name comes from an unpublished children's story of the same title
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A friend of Kip Berman wrote the story, which revolves around "realising what matters most in life – things like friendship and having a good time"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The group's self-titled album peaked at number nine on the Billboard Heatseekers chart
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2009, they released Higher Than the Stars, their second EP
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The band's second record, entitled Belong, was released in 2011
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The third Pains of Being Pure at Heart album, Days of Abandon, was released in May 2014
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The fourth Pains of Being Pure at Heart album, The Echo of Pleasure, is set to be released on September 1, 2017
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
A papal legate or Apostolic legate (from the Ancient Roman title legatus) is a personal representative of the pope to foreign nations, or to some part of the Catholic Church
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He is empowered on matters of Catholic Faith and for the settlement of ecclesiastical matters
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The legate is appointed directly by the pope (the bishop of Rome, head of the Catholic Church and (historically) head of state of the papal states)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hence a legate is usually sent to a government, a sovereign or to a large body of believers (such as a national church) or to take charge of a major religious effort, such as an (ecumenical) council, a crusade to the Holy Land, or even against a heresy such as the Cathars
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The term legation is applied both to a legate's mandate and to the territory concerned (such as a state, or an ecclesiastical province)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The relevant adjective is legatine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ableism  (also known as ablism, disablism, anapirophobia, anapirism, disability discrimination, and handicapism) is discrimination and social prejudice against people with disabilities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Ableism characterizes persons as defined by their disabilities and as inferior to the non-disabled
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 On this basis, people are assigned or denied certain perceived abilities, skills, or character traits
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Discrimination faced by those who have or are perceived to have a mental disorder is sometimes called mentalism rather than ableism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There are stereotypes associated with various disabilities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These stereotypes in turn serve as a justification for ableist practices and reinforce discriminatory attitudes and behaviors toward people who are disabled
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Labeling affects people when it limits their options for action or changes their identity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In ableist societies, people with disabilities are viewed as less valuable to society, or even less than human
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The eugenics movement of the early 20th century could be considered an example of widespread ableism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The mass murder of disabled in the German Nazi Government's Aktion T4 could be an extreme example of ableism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Other definitions of ableism include those of Chouinard, who defines it as "ideas, practices, institutions, and social relations that presume able-bodiedness, and by so doing, construct persons with disabilities as marginalized […] and largely invisible 'others,'" and of Amundson and Taira, who define ableism as "a doctrine that falsely treats impairments as inherently and naturally horrible and blames the impairments themselves for the problems experienced by the people who have them
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ablation is removal of material from the surface of an object by vaporization, chipping, or other erosive processes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Examples of ablative materials are described below, and include spacecraft material for ascent and atmospheric reentry, ice and snow in glaciology, biological tissues in medicine and passive fire protection materials
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ablepharus is a genus of skinks that contains the common snake-eyed skinks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their name refers to the fact that their eyelids have fused to a translucent capsule; as in snakes, they thus are physically incapable of blinking
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They resemble small lizards and prefer to live in the leaf litter of dry fields and hills
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their scales give them a very shiny, bronze appearance with a characteristically dark stripe down the sides of their bodies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They prey on small insects and other small mollusks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Visual impairment, also known as vision impairment or vision loss, is a decreased ability to see to a degree that causes problems not fixable by usual means, such as glasses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some also include those who have a decreased ability to see because they do not have access to glasses or contact lenses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Visual impairment is often defined as a best corrected visual acuity of worse than either 20/40 or 20/60
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term blindness is used for complete or nearly complete vision loss
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Visual impairment may cause people difficulties with normal daily activities such as driving, reading, socializing, and walking
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The most common causes of visual impairment globally are uncorrected refractive errors (43%), cataracts (33%), and glaucoma (2%)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Refractive errors include near sighted, far sighted, presbyopia, and astigmatism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Cataracts are the most common cause of blindness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other disorders that may cause visual problems include age related macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, corneal clouding, childhood blindness, and a number of infections
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Visual impairment can also be caused by problems in the brain due to stroke, premature birth, or trauma among others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These cases are known as cortical visual impairment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Screening for vision problems in children may improve future vision and educational achievement
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Screening adults without symptoms is of uncertain benefit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Diagnosis is by an eye exam
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that 80% of visual impairment is either preventable or curable with treatment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This includes cataracts, the infections river blindness and trachoma, glaucoma, diabetic retinopathy, uncorrected refractive errors, and some cases of childhood blindness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many people with significant visual impairment benefit from vision rehabilitation, changes in their environment, and assistive devices
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

As of 2015 there were 940 million people with some degree of vision loss
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 246 million had low vision and 39 million were blind
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The majority of people with poor vision are in the developing world and are over the age of 50 years
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Rates of visual impairment have decreased since the 1990s
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Visual impairments have considerable economic costs both directly due to the cost of treatment and indirectly due to decreased ability to work
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Visual impairment, also known as vision impairment or vision loss, is a decreased ability to see to a degree that causes problems not fixable by usual means, such as glasses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some also include those who have a decreased ability to see because they do not have access to glasses or contact lenses

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Onesidezero (also depicted as OneSideZero) is a five-piece music group
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their style is often described as heavy melodic rock
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their songs are often very dark, with deep lyrics and slow bass lines
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abuse is the improper usage or treatment of an entity, often to unfairly or improperly gain benefit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abuse can come in many forms, such as: physical or verbal maltreatment, injury, assault, violation, rape, unjust practices, crimes, or other types of aggression
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Abenaki (Abnaki, Abinaki, Alnôbak) are a Native American tribe and First Nation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are one of the Algonquian-speaking peoples of northeastern North America
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Abenaki live in Quebec and the Maritimes of Canada and in the New England region of the United States, a region called Wabanahkik ("Dawn Land") in the Eastern Algonquian languages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Abenaki are one of the five members of the Wabanaki Confederacy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

"Abenaki" is a linguistic and geographic grouping; historically there was not a strong central authority
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As listed below, there were numerous smaller bands and tribes who shared many cultural traits
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They came together as a post-contact community after their original tribes were decimated by colonization, disease, and warfare
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Denial, in ordinary English usage, is asserting that a statement or allegation is not true
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The same word, and also abnegation (German: Verneinung), is used for a psychological defense mechanism postulated by psychoanalyst Sigmund Freud, in which a person is faced with a fact that is too uncomfortable to accept and rejects it instead, insisting that it is not true despite what may be overwhelming evidence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An individual that exhibits such behavior is described as a denialist or true believer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Denial also could mean denying the happening of an event or the reliability of information, which can lead to a feeling of aloofness and to the ignoring of possibly beneficial information
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The subject may use:
simple denial: deny the reality of the unpleasant fact altogether
minimisation: admit the fact but deny its seriousness (a combination of denial and rationalization)
projection: admit both the fact and seriousness but deny responsibility by blaming somebody or something else
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Self-denial (also called self-abnegation and self-sacrifice) refers to altruistic abstinence – the willingness to forgo personal pleasures or undergo personal trials in the pursuit of the increased good of another
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Various religions and cultures take differing views of self-denial, some considering it a positive trait and others considering it a negative one
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 According to some Protestants, self-denial is considered a superhuman virtue only obtainable through Jesus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some critics of self-denial suggest that self-denial can lead to self-hatred and claim that the self-denial practiced in Judaism has created self-hating Jews
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abnormality (or dysfunctional behavior), in the vivid sense of something deviating from the normal (c
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
f
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Norm (social)) or differing from the typical (such as an aberration), is a subjectively defined behavioral characteristic, assigned to those with rare or dysfunctional conditions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Behavior is considered abnormal when it is atypical, out of the ordinary, causes some kind of impairment, or consists of undesirable behavior
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Often what is abnormal, or what is not abnormal, is determined by an individual's culture
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The definition of what abnormal behavior is a contentious issue in abnormal psychology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is an assumption that abnormal behavior is a disorder that has a physical cause, specifically that it is related to the physical structure of the brain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A diagnosis of a mental disorder describes a patient who has a medical condition and the doctor makes a judgment that the patient is exhibiting abnormal behavior
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The distinction being that mental disorders describe processes, not people
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Human sexuality is the quality of being sexual, or the way people experience and express themselves as sexual beings
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This involves biological, erotic, physical, emotional, social, or spiritual feelings and behaviors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Because it is a broad term, which has varied over time, it lacks a precise definition
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The biological and physical aspects of sexuality largely concern the human reproductive functions, including the human sexual response cycle
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Someone's sexual orientation can influence that person's sexual interest and attraction for another person
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Physical and emotional aspects of sexuality include bonds between individuals that is expressed through profound feelings or physical manifestations of love, trust, and care
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Social aspects deal with the effects of human society on one's sexuality, while spirituality concerns an individual's spiritual connection with others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Sexuality also affects and is affected by cultural, political, legal, philosophical, moral, ethical, and religious aspects of life
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Interest in sexual activity typically increases when an individual reaches puberty
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Opinions differ on the origins of an individual's sexual orientation and sexual behavior
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some argue that sexuality is determined by genetics, while others believe it is molded by the environment, or that both of these factors interact to form the individual's sexual orientation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This pertains to the nature versus nurture debate
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the former, one assumes that the features of a person innately correspond to their natural inheritance, exemplified by drives and instincts; the latter refers to the assumption that the features of a person continue to change throughout their development and nurturing, exemplified by ego ideals and formative identifications
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Evolutionary perspectives on human coupling, reproduction and reproduction strategies, and social learning theory provide further views of sexuality
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Socio-cultural aspects of sexuality include historical developments and religious beliefs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Examples of these include Jewish views on sexual pleasure within marriage and some views of other religions on avoidance of sexual pleasures
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some cultures have been described as sexually repressive
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The study of sexuality also includes human identity within social groups, sexually transmitted infections (STIs/STDs), and birth control methods
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
f

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Scolopendra abnormis (Serpent Island centipede) is a species of centipede in the family Scolopendridae that is endemic to Mauritius
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It only occurs on two outlying islands, Round Island and Serpent Island
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 On Serpent Island it is very common, reaching densities of 12 adults per square metre in suitable habitat
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
This list of ship directions explains dozens of related terms such as fore, aft, astern, aboard, or topside
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For background, see below: Origins
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

abaft (preposition)
at or toward the stern of a ship, or further back from a location, e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 the mizzenmast is abaft the mainmast
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aboard
onto or within a ship, or in a group
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

above
a higher deck of the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aft (adjective)
toward the stern of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

adrift
floating in the water without propulsion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aground
resting on the shore or wedged against the sea floor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

ahull
with sails furled and helm lashed alee
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

alee
on or toward the lee (the downwind side)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aloft
the stacks, masts, rigging, or other area above the highest solid structure
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

amidships
near the middle part of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aport
toward the port side of a ship (opposite of "astarboard")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

ashore
on or towards the shore or land
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

astarboard
toward the starboard side of a ship (opposite of "aport")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

astern (adjective)
toward the rear of a ship (opposite of "forward")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

athwartships
toward the sides of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aweather
toward the weather or windward side of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

aweigh
just clear of the sea floor, as with an anchor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

below
a lower deck of the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

belowdecks
inside or into a ship, or down to a lower deck
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

bilge
the underwater part of a ship between the flat of the bottom and the vertical topsides
bottom
the lowest part of the ship's hull
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

bow or stem
front of a ship (opposite of "stern")
centerline
an imaginary, central line drawn from the bow to the stern
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

fore or forward
at or toward the front of a ship or further ahead of a location (opposite of "aft")
inboard
attached inside the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

keel
the bottom structure of a ship's hull
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

leeward
side or direction away from the wind (opposite of "windward")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

on deck
to an outside or muster deck (as "all hands on deck")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

on board
somewhere on or in the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

outboard
attached outside the ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

port
the left side of the ship, facing forward (opposite of "starboard")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

starboard
the right side of the ship, when facing forward (opposite of "port")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

stern
the rear of a ship (opposite of "bow")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

topside
on the ship's main weather deck
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

underdeck
a lower deck of a ship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

yardarm
an end of a yard spar below a sail
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

waterline
where the water surface meets the ship's hull
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

weather
side or direction from which wind blows (same as "windward")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

windward
side or direction from which wind blows (opposite of "leeward")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
A malocclusion is a misalignment or incorrect relation between the teeth of the two dental arches when they approach each other as the jaws close
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term was coined by Edward Angle, the "father of modern orthodontics", as a derivative of occlusion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This refers to the manner in which opposing teeth meet (mal- + occlusion = "incorrect occlusion")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abidin or Abdin is both an Arabic given name and surname, meaning "worshippers"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Notable people with the name include:
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The abohm is the basic unit of electrical resistance in the emu-cgs (centimeter-gram-second) system of units (emu stands for "electromagnetic units")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 One abohm is equal to 10−9 ohms in the SI system of units; one abohm is a nanoohm
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The emu-cgs (or "electromagnetic cgs") units are one of several systems of electromagnetic units within the centimetre gram second system of units; others include esu-cgs, Gaussian units, and Lorentz–Heaviside units
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In these other systems, the abohm is not one of the units
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

When a current of one abampere (1 abA) flows through a resistance of 1 abohm, the resulting potential difference across the component is one abvolt (1 abV)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aboiteau farming on reclaimed marshland is a labor-intensive method in which earthen dykes are constructed to stop high tides from inundating marshland
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A wooden sluice or aboiteau (plural aboiteaux) is then built into the dyke, with a hinged door (clapper valve) that swings open at low tide to allow fresh water to drain from the farmland but swings shut at high tide to prevent salt water from inundating the fields
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aboiteau farming is intimately linked with the story of French Acadian colonization of the shores of Canada's Bay of Fundy in the 17th and 18th centuries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the Kamouraska region of the St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Lawrence Valley of Quebec, aboiteau diking of salt marshes was closely tied to the modernization of agriculture in the 19th and early 20th centuries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Acadians constructed earthen dykes to isolate areas of salt marsh from repeated inundation by the tides
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A rare original "aboiteau" is the jewel of the West Pubnico Acadian Museums' artifacts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 1990, local residents found a couple of boards sticking out of an eroding beach on Double Island, West Pubnico
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They returned to the site in 1996 to remove the aboiteau, to preserve and display it at the museum
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Rosa María Alfonseca Arredondo (born April 29, 1953) is a Mexican graphic artist whose work has been recognized with membership in Mexico’s Salón de la Plástica Mexicana
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The abolition of monarchy has occurred throughout history, either through revolutions, coups d'état, wars, or legislative reforms (such as abdications)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The founding of the Roman Republic is a noteworthy example and became part of the nation's traditions including as justification for the assassination of Julius Caesar
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The twentieth century saw a major acceleration of this process, with many monarchies violently overthrown by revolution or war, or else abolished as part of the process of decolonisation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 By contrast, the restoration of monarchies is rare in modern times, with only two major examples, Spain and Cambodia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Mary Ann McCracken (8 July 1770 – 26 July 1866) was a Belfast republican and social reformer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abolitionism is a movement to end slavery, whether formal or informal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Western Europe and the Americas, abolitionism is a historical movement to end the African and Indian slave trade and set slaves free
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 King Charles I of Spain, usually known as Emperor Charles V, following the example of Louis X of France who abolished slavery within the Kingdom of France in 1315, passed a law which would have abolished colonial slavery in 1542, although this law was not passed in the largest colonial states, and so was not enforced
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the late 17th century, the Roman Catholic Church, taking up a plea by Lourenco da Silva de Mendouca, officially condemned the slave trade, which was affirmed vehemently by Pope Gregory XVI in 1839
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An abolitionist movement only started in the late 18th century, however, when English and American Quakers began to question the morality of slavery
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 James Oglethorpe was among the first to articulate the Enlightenment case against slavery, banning it in the Province of Georgia on humanitarian grounds, arguing against it in Parliament, and eventually encouraging his friends Granville Sharp and Hannah More to vigorously pursue the cause
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Soon after his death in 1785, they joined with William Wilberforce and others in forming the Clapham Sect
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Somersett Case in 1772, in which a fugitive slave was freed in England with the judgement that slavery did not exist under English common law and was thus prohibited in England, helped launch the British movement to abolish slavery
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Though anti-slavery sentiments were widespread by the late 18th century, the colonies and emerging nations that used slave labour continued to do so: Dutch, French, English, Spanish and Portuguese territories in the West Indies; South America; and the Southern United States
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 After the American Revolution established the United States, northern states, beginning with Pennsylvania in 1780, passed legislation during the next two decades abolishing slavery, sometimes by gradual emancipation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Massachusetts ratified a constitution that declared all men equal; freedom suits challenging slavery based on this principle brought an end to slavery in the state
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Vermont, which existed as an unrecognized state from 1777 to 1791, abolished adult slavery in 1777
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In other states, such as Virginia, similar declarations of rights were interpreted by the courts as not applicable to Africans
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During the following decades, the abolitionist movement grew in northern states, and Congress regulated the expansion of slavery in new states admitted to the union
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

France abolished slavery within the French Kingdom (continental France) in 1315
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Revolutionary France abolished slavery in France's colonies in 1794, although it was restored by Napoleon with the Law of 20 May 1802 as part of a program to ensure French sovereignty over its colonies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Haiti formally declared independence from France in 1804 and brought an end to slavery in its territory
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The northern states in the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 all abolished slavery by 1804
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The United Kingdom and the United States outlawed the international slave trade in 1807, after which Britain led efforts to block slave ships
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Britain abolished slavery throughout the British Empire with the Slavery Abolition Act 1833, the French colonies re-abolished it in 1848 and the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 abolished slavery in 1865 with the 13th Amendment to the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Constitution
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In Eastern Europe, groups organized to abolish the enslavement of the Roma in Wallachia and Moldavia; and to emancipate the serfs in Russia (Emancipation reform of 1861)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was declared illegal in 1948 under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The last country to abolish legal slavery was Mauritania, where it was officially abolished by presidential decree in 1981
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Today, child and adult slavery and forced labour are illegal in most countries, as well as being against international law, but a high rate of human trafficking for labour and for sexual bondage continues to affect tens of millions of adults and children
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

France abolished slavery within the French Kingdom (continental France) in 1315
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Revolutionary France abolished slavery in France's colonies in 1794, although it was restored by Napoleon with the Law of 20 May 1802 as part of a program to ensure French sovereignty over its colonies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Haiti formally declared independence from France in 1804 and brought an end to slavery in its territory
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The northern states in the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 all abolished slavery by 1804
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The United Kingdom and the United States outlawed the international slave trade in 1807, after which Britain led efforts to block slave ships
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Britain abolished slavery throughout the British Empire with the Slavery Abolition Act 1833, the French colonies re-abolished it in 1848 and the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 abolished slavery in 1865 with the 13th Amendment to the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Constitution
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In Eastern Europe, groups organized to abolish the enslavement of the Roma in Wallachia and Moldavia; and to emancipate the serfs in Russia (Emancipation reform of 1861)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was declared illegal in 1948 under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The last country to abolish legal slavery was Mauritania, where it was officially abolished by presidential decree in 1981
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Today, child and adult slavery and forced labour are illegal in most countries, as well as being against international law, but a high rate of human trafficking for labour and for sexual bondage continues to affect tens of millions of adults and children
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Elfazepam is a drug which is a benzodiazepine derivative
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Presumably it has sedative and anxiolytic actions like those of other benzodiazepines
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Orexigenic properties in animals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The mechanism for increasing feed intake is not clear and has been subject of investigation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It has been found that elfazepam suppresses gastric acid secretion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The abomasum, also known as the maw, rennet-bag, or reed tripe, is the fourth and final stomach compartment in ruminants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It secretes rennet, which is used in cheese creation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The word abomasum is from New Latin and it was first used in English in 1706
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It comes from Latin ab- + omasum "intestine of an ox," and it is possibly from the Gaulish language
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The abomasum's normal anatomical location is along ventral midline
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a secretory stomach similar in anatomy and function as the monogastric stomach
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It serves primarily in the acid hydrolysis of microbial and dietary protein, preparing these protein sources for further digestion and absorption in the small intestine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Dairy cattle on high production diets are susceptible to a number of pathologies, most commonly after calving
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A gas-filled abomasum can move into an abnormal location, resulting in left-displaced abomasum (LDA) or right-displaced abomasum (RDA)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 If the abomasum displaces to the right, it is at risk of torsion and becoming a right torsioned abomasum (RTA)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A displaced abomasum will cause cows to present all or some of the following signs: loss of appetite, decrease rumen contractions, decrease cud chewing, and drop in milk production
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 While an LDA and RDA are not immediately life-threatening, veterinary care is required for surgical correction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Milder cases can be corrected by rolling the cow over or forcing her to run up a steep hill
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abomasitis is a relatively rare, but serious, disease of the abomasum whose causes are currently unknown
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The abomasum is used to make the lampredotto, a typical dish of Florence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is also fried and eaten with onions as part of the Korean dish Makchang gui
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Another dish made with the abomasum is Turkish Şırdan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abominable is a 2006 horror film, directed and written by Ryan Schifrin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film stars Matt McCoy, Jeffrey Combs, Lance Henriksen, Rex Linn, Dee Wallace, Phil Morris, Paul Gleason and Haley Joel
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Despite the title, the antagonist of the film is the cryptid Bigfoot
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film premiered on April 10, 2006 in New York City
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The music is scored by Lalo Schifrin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abominable is a 2006 horror film, directed and written by Ryan Schifrin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film stars Matt McCoy, Jeffrey Combs, Lance Henriksen, Rex Linn, Dee Wallace, Phil Morris, Paul Gleason and Haley Joel
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Despite the title, the antagonist of the film is the cryptid Bigfoot
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film premiered on April 10, 2006 in New York City
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The music is scored by Lalo Schifrin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abortion is the ending of pregnancy by removing a fetus or embryo before it can survive outside the uterus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An abortion that occurs spontaneously is also known as a miscarriage
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An abortion may be caused purposely and is then called an induced abortion, or less frequently, "induced miscarriage"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The word abortion is often used to mean only induced abortions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A similar procedure after the fetus could potentially survive outside the womb is known as a "late termination of pregnancy"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

When allowed by law, abortion in the developed world is one of the safest procedures in medicine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Modern methods use medication or surgery for abortions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The drug mifepristone in combination with prostaglandin appears to be as safe and effective as surgery during the first and second trimester of pregnancy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Birth control, such as the pill or intrauterine devices, can be used immediately following abortion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When performed legally and safely, induced abortions do not increase the risk of long-term mental or physical problems
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In contrast, unsafe abortions (those performed by unskilled individuals, with hazardous equipment, or in unsanitary facilities) cause 47,000 deaths and 5 million hospital admissions each year
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The World Health Organization recommends safe and legal abortions be available to all women
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Around 56 million abortions are performed each year in the world, with a little under half done unsafely
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abortion rates changed little between 2003 and 2008, before which they decreased for at least two decades as access to family planning and birth control increased
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As of 2008, 40% of the world's women had access to legal abortions without limits as to reason
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Countries that permit abortions have different limits on how late in pregnancy abortion is allowed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Since ancient times, abortions have been done using herbal medicines, sharp tools, with force, or through other traditional methods
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abortion laws and cultural or religious views of abortions are different around the world
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In some areas abortion is legal only in specific cases such as rape, problems with the fetus, poverty, risk to a woman's health, or incest
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In many places there is much debate over the moral, ethical, and legal issues of abortion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Those who oppose abortion often maintain that an embryo or fetus is a human with a right to life and may compare abortion to murder
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Those who favor the legality of abortion often hold that a woman has a right to make decisions about her own body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An abortifacient ("that which will cause a miscarriage" from Latin: abortus "miscarriage" and faciens "making") is a substance that induces abortion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abortifacients for animals that have mated undesirably are known as mismating shots
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Common abortifacients used in performing medical abortions include mifepristone, which is typically used in conjunction with misoprostol in a two-step approach
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Oxytocin is commonly used to induce abortion in the second or third trimester
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are also several herbal mixtures with abortifacient claims, though there are no available data on the efficacy of these plants in humans
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abortion is the ending of pregnancy by removing a fetus or embryo before it can survive outside the uterus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An abortion that occurs spontaneously is also known as a miscarriage
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An abortion may be caused purposely and is then called an induced abortion, or less frequently, "induced miscarriage"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abolitionism is a movement to end slavery, whether formal or informal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Western Europe and the Americas, abolitionism is a historical movement to end the African and Indian slave trade and set slaves free
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 King Charles I of Spain, usually known as Emperor Charles V, following the example of Louis X of France who abolished slavery within the Kingdom of France in 1315, passed a law which would have abolished colonial slavery in 1542, although this law was not passed in the largest colonial states, and so was not enforced
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the late 17th century, the Roman Catholic Church, taking up a plea by Lourenco da Silva de Mendouca, officially condemned the slave trade, which was affirmed vehemently by Pope Gregory XVI in 1839
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An abolitionist movement only started in the late 18th century, however, when English and American Quakers began to question the morality of slavery
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 James Oglethorpe was among the first to articulate the Enlightenment case against slavery, banning it in the Province of Georgia on humanitarian grounds, arguing against it in Parliament, and eventually encouraging his friends Granville Sharp and Hannah More to vigorously pursue the cause
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Soon after his death in 1785, they joined with William Wilberforce and others in forming the Clapham Sect
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Somersett Case in 1772, in which a fugitive slave was freed in England with the judgement that slavery did not exist under English common law and was thus prohibited in England, helped launch the British movement to abolish slavery
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Though anti-slavery sentiments were widespread by the late 18th century, the colonies and emerging nations that used slave labour continued to do so: Dutch, French, English, Spanish and Portuguese territories in the West Indies; South America; and the Southern United States
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 After the American Revolution established the United States, northern states, beginning with Pennsylvania in 1780, passed legislation during the next two decades abolishing slavery, sometimes by gradual emancipation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Massachusetts ratified a constitution that declared all men equal; freedom suits challenging slavery based on this principle brought an end to slavery in the state
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Vermont, which existed as an unrecognized state from 1777 to 1791, abolished adult slavery in 1777
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In other states, such as Virginia, similar declarations of rights were interpreted by the courts as not applicable to Africans
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During the following decades, the abolitionist movement grew in northern states, and Congress regulated the expansion of slavery in new states admitted to the union
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

France abolished slavery within the French Kingdom (continental France) in 1315
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Revolutionary France abolished slavery in France's colonies in 1794, although it was restored by Napoleon with the Law of 20 May 1802 as part of a program to ensure French sovereignty over its colonies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Haiti formally declared independence from France in 1804 and brought an end to slavery in its territory
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The northern states in the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 all abolished slavery by 1804
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The United Kingdom and the United States outlawed the international slave trade in 1807, after which Britain led efforts to block slave ships
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Britain abolished slavery throughout the British Empire with the Slavery Abolition Act 1833, the French colonies re-abolished it in 1848 and the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 abolished slavery in 1865 with the 13th Amendment to the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Constitution
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In Eastern Europe, groups organized to abolish the enslavement of the Roma in Wallachia and Moldavia; and to emancipate the serfs in Russia (Emancipation reform of 1861)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was declared illegal in 1948 under the Universal Declaration of Human Rights
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The last country to abolish legal slavery was Mauritania, where it was officially abolished by presidential decree in 1981
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Today, child and adult slavery and forced labour are illegal in most countries, as well as being against international law, but a high rate of human trafficking for labour and for sexual bondage continues to affect tens of millions of adults and children
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Grace Abounding to the Chief of Sinners, or The Brief Relation of the Exceeding Mercy of God in Christ to his Poor Servant John Bunyan is a Puritan spiritual autobiography written by John Bunyan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was composed while Bunyan was serving a twelve-year prison sentence in Bedford gaol for preaching without a license and was first published in 1666
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The title contains allusions to two Biblical passages: 'Grace Abounding' is a reference to the Epistle to the Romans 5:20, which states 'Where sin abounded, grace did much more abound' (KJV) and 'Chief of Sinners' refers to First Epistle to Timothy 1:15, where Paul refers to himself by the same appellation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Misunderstandings of p-values are an important problem in scientific research and scientific education
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 P-values are often used or interpreted incorrectly
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The data obtained by comparing the p-value to a significance level will yield one of two results: either the null hypothesis is rejected (which however does not imply that the null hypothesis is false), or the null hypothesis cannot be rejected at that significance level (which however does not imply that the null hypothesis is true)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Ronald Fisher's formulation, a low p-value means either that the null hypothesis is true and a highly improbable event has occurred or that the null hypothesis is false
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Manna (Hebrew: מָן‎‎) or al-Mann (Arabic: المَنّ ‎‎, Kurdish: gezo‎, Persian: گزانگبین‎‎), sometimes or archaically spelled mana, is an edible substance which, according to the Bible and the Quran, God provided for the Israelites during their travels in the desert during the forty-year period following the Exodus and prior to the conquest of Canaan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Openness is an overarching concept or philosophy that is characterized by an emphasis on transparency and free, unrestricted access to knowledge and information, as well as collaborative or cooperative management and decision-making rather than a central authority
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Openness can be said to be the opposite of secrecy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abracadabra is an incantation used as a magic word in stage magic tricks, and historically was believed to have healing powers when inscribed on an amulet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abacha is a town in Anambra State in the southeastern part of Nigeria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is bordered by Abatete, Nimo, Oraukwu and Eziowelle towns
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It forms part of the ten communities in the Idemili North Local Government Area of Anambra State, and it is also part of the Anambra central Senatorial Zone
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its people are among the Igbo speaking communities in the eastern part of Nigeria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abacha comprises six villages; Umudisi, Umuazu, Umuokpolonwu, Umuekpeli, Norgba and Ugwuma
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name of the king is Igwe Mbakwe one of Abacha
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abadeh (Persian: آباده ‎‎, also Romanized as Ābādeh) is a city in and the capital of Abadeh County, in Fars Province, Iran
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abadeh is situated at an elevation of 6,200 feet (1,890 m) in a fertile plain on the high road between Isfahan and Shiraz, 190 kilometres (120 mi) from the former and 270 kilometres (170 mi) from the latter
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At the 2006 census, its population was 52,042, in 14,184 families
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As of 2009, the population was estimated to be 59,042
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

It is the largest city in the Northern Fars Region (South Central-Iran), which is famed for its carved wood-work, made of the wood of pear and box trees
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Sesame oil, castor oil, grain, and various fruits are also produced there
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The area is famous for its Abadeh rugs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An interesting fact is that Abadeh is closer, road-distance-wise to 4 provincial capitals of Isfahan (193 km), Yasuj (197 km), Yazd (217 km), and Shahrekord (237 km) compared to the distance to the provincial capital of its corresponding province, Shiraz (260 km)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abadeh (Persian: آباده ‎‎, also Romanized as Ābādeh) is a city in and the capital of Abadeh County, in Fars Province, Iran
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abadeh is situated at an elevation of 6,200 feet (1,890 m) in a fertile plain on the high road between Isfahan and Shiraz, 190 kilometres (120 mi) from the former and 270 kilometres (170 mi) from the latter

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
