 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An abstract is a brief summary of a research article, thesis, review, conference proceeding, or any in-depth analysis of a particular subject and is often used to help the reader quickly ascertain the paper's purpose
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When used, an abstract always appears at the beginning of a manuscript or typescript, acting as the point-of-entry for any given academic paper or patent application
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abstracting and indexing services for various academic disciplines are aimed at compiling a body of literature for that particular subject
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The terms précis or synopsis are used in some publications to refer to the same thing that other publications might call an "abstract"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In management reports, an executive summary usually contains more information (and often more sensitive information) than the abstract does
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Obscurantism ( and ) is the practice of deliberately preventing the facts of some subject matter from becoming known
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are two historical and intellectual denotations of Obscurantism: (1) the deliberate restriction of knowledge—opposition to disseminating knowledge; and, (2) deliberate obscurity—an abstruse style (as in literature and art) characterized by deliberate vagueness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Therefore, an obscurantist is someone who actively opposes enlightenment and the consequent social reform, a type of anti-intellectual
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The term obscurantism derives from the title of the 16th-century satire Epistolæ Obscurorum Virorum (1515–19, Letters of Obscure Men), that was based upon the intellectual dispute between the German humanist Johann Reuchlin and the monk Johannes Pfefferkorn of the Dominican Order, about whether or not all Jewish books should be burned as un-Christian heresy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Earlier, in 1509, the monk Pfefferkorn had obtained permission from Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor (1486–1519), to burn all copies of the Talmud (Jewish law and Jewish ethics) known to be in the Holy Roman Empire (AD 926–1806); the Letters of Obscure Men satirized the Dominican arguments for burning "un–Christian" works
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the 18th century, Enlightenment philosophers applied the term obscurantist to any enemy of intellectual enlightenment and the liberal diffusion of knowledge
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the 19th century, in distinguishing the varieties of obscurantism found in metaphysics and theology from the "more subtle" obscurantism of the critical philosophy of Immanuel Kant, and of modern philosophical skepticism, Friedrich Nietzsche said: "The essential element in the black art of obscurantism is not that it wants to darken individual understanding, but that it wants to blacken our picture of the world, and darken our idea of existence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Obscurantism ( and ) is the practice of deliberately preventing the facts of some subject matter from becoming known
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are two historical and intellectual denotations of Obscurantism: (1) the deliberate restriction of knowledge—opposition to disseminating knowledge; and, (2) deliberate obscurity—an abstruse style (as in literature and art) characterized by deliberate vagueness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Therefore, an obscurantist is someone who actively opposes enlightenment and the consequent social reform, a type of anti-intellectual
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The term obscurantism derives from the title of the 16th-century satire Epistolæ Obscurorum Virorum (1515–19, Letters of Obscure Men), that was based upon the intellectual dispute between the German humanist Johann Reuchlin and the monk Johannes Pfefferkorn of the Dominican Order, about whether or not all Jewish books should be burned as un-Christian heresy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Earlier, in 1509, the monk Pfefferkorn had obtained permission from Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor (1486–1519), to burn all copies of the Talmud (Jewish law and Jewish ethics) known to be in the Holy Roman Empire (AD 926–1806); the Letters of Obscure Men satirized the Dominican arguments for burning "un–Christian" works
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the 18th century, Enlightenment philosophers applied the term obscurantist to any enemy of intellectual enlightenment and the liberal diffusion of knowledge
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the 19th century, in distinguishing the varieties of obscurantism found in metaphysics and theology from the "more subtle" obscurantism of the critical philosophy of Immanuel Kant, and of modern philosophical skepticism, Friedrich Nietzsche said: "The essential element in the black art of obscurantism is not that it wants to darken individual understanding, but that it wants to blacken our picture of the world, and darken our idea of existence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An absurdity is a thing that is extremely unreasonable, so as to be foolish or not taken seriously, or the state of being so
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "Absurd" is an adjective used to describe an absurdity, e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, "this encyclopedia article is absurd"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It derives from the Latin absurdum meaning "out of tune", hence irrational
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Latin surdus means "deaf", implying stupidity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Absurdity is contrasted with seriousness in reasoning
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In general usage, absurdity may be synonymous with ridiculousness and nonsense
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In specialized usage, absurdity is related to extremes in bad reasoning or pointlessness in reasoning; ridiculousness is related to extremes of incongruous juxtaposition, laughter, and ridicule; and nonsense is related to a lack of meaningfulness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Absurdism is a concept in philosophy related to the notion of absurdity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In philosophy, "the Absurd" refers to the conflict between the human tendency to seek inherent value and meaning in life and the human inability to find any
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In this context absurd does not mean "logically impossible", but rather "humanly impossible"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The universe and the human mind do not each separately cause the Absurd, but rather, the Absurd arises by the contradictory nature of the two existing simultaneously
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accordingly, absurdism is a philosophical school of thought stating that the efforts of humanity to find inherent meaning will ultimately fail (and hence are absurd) because the sheer amount of information as well as the vast realm of the unknown make total certainty impossible
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a philosophy, absurdism furthermore explores the fundamental nature of the Absurd and how individuals, once becoming conscious of the Absurd, should respond to it
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The absurdist philosopher Albert Camus stated that individuals should embrace the absurd condition of human existence while also defiantly continuing to explore and search for meaning
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Absurdism shares some concepts, and a common theoretical template, with existentialism and nihilism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It has its origins in the work of the 19th-century Danish philosopher Søren Kierkegaard, who chose to confront the crisis that humans face with the Absurd by developing his own existentialist philosophy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Absurdism as a belief system was born of the European existentialist movement that ensued, specifically when Camus rejected certain aspects of that philosophical line of thought and published his essay The Myth of Sisyphus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The aftermath of World War II provided the social environment that stimulated absurdist views and allowed for their popular development, especially in the devastated country of France
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In philosophy, "the Absurd" refers to the conflict between the human tendency to seek inherent value and meaning in life and the human inability to find any
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In this context absurd does not mean "logically impossible", but rather "humanly impossible"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The universe and the human mind do not each separately cause the Absurd, but rather, the Absurd arises by the contradictory nature of the two existing simultaneously
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accordingly, absurdism is a philosophical school of thought stating that the efforts of humanity to find inherent meaning will ultimately fail (and hence are absurd) because the sheer amount of information as well as the vast realm of the unknown make total certainty impossible
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a philosophy, absurdism furthermore explores the fundamental nature of the Absurd and how individuals, once becoming conscious of the Absurd, should respond to it
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The absurdist philosopher Albert Camus stated that individuals should embrace the absurd condition of human existence while also defiantly continuing to explore and search for meaning
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Absurdism shares some concepts, and a common theoretical template, with existentialism and nihilism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It has its origins in the work of the 19th-century Danish philosopher Søren Kierkegaard, who chose to confront the crisis that humans face with the Absurd by developing his own existentialist philosophy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Absurdism as a belief system was born of the European existentialist movement that ensued, specifically when Camus rejected certain aspects of that philosophical line of thought and published his essay The Myth of Sisyphus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The aftermath of World War II provided the social environment that stimulated absurdist views and allowed for their popular development, especially in the devastated country of France
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In logic, reductio ad absurdum (Latin for "reduction to absurdity"; or argumentum ad absurdum, "argument to absurdity") is a form of argument which attempts either to disprove a statement by showing it inevitably leads to a ridiculous, absurd, or impractical conclusion, or to prove one by showing that if it were not true, the result would be absurd or impossible
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Traced back to classical Greek philosophy in Aristotle's Prior Analytics (Greek: ἡ Εις άτοπον απαγωγή, translit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 hê eis atopon apagôgê, lit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 'reduction to the impossible'), this technique has been used throughout history in both formal mathematical and philosophical reasoning, as well as in debate
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Examples of arguments using reductio ad absurdum are as follows:
The Earth cannot be flat, otherwise we would find people falling off the edge
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There is no smallest positive rational number, because if there were, then it could be divided by two to get a smaller one
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The first example shows that it would be absurd to argue that the Earth is flat, because it would lead to an outcome that is impossible since it contradicts laws of nature
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The second example is a mathematical proof by contradiction directly bound to the mathematical concept of infinitesimals, which argues that the denial of the premise would result in a logical contradiction (there is a "smallest" number and yet there is a number smaller than it)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abudefduf also known as the sergeant-majors is a genus of fish in the family Pomacentridae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The name is from Arabic abu, "the one with"; and def, "side", and the intensive plural ending -duf
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name thus means "the one with prominent sides"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abdullah or Abdallah is the primary transliteration of the Arabic given name, Arabic: عبد الله‎‎, built from the Arabic words Abd and Allah (Allah itself composed of Al- and Ilah)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The first letter a in Al-Ilah in its native pronunciation is often unstressed and commonly transliterated by u, a stressed a is often used as well, although any vowel can also be used
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is one of many Arabic theophoric names, meaning servant of God or God's slave
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The feminine counterpart of this name is Amatullah
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Humility before God is an essential value of Islam, hence Abdullah is a common name among Muslims
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In particular, the name of the Islamic prophet Muhammad's father was Abdullah
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

It is also common among Arab Jews, especially Iraqi Jews
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name is cognate to and has the same meaning as the Hebrew Abdiel and, more commonly, Obadiah
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There were two Jewish Rabbis in Medina before Islam came; they were Abdullah ibn Salam and Abdullah ibn Shuria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abdullah ibn Saba was a Yemenite Jew during the spread of Islam
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The word Allah exists in the Arabic Talmud and other Jewish scriptures
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The variant used in the Russian language is "Абдулла́" (Abdulla) (cf
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Fedul, which has similar origins), with "Абду́л" (Abdul) and "Габдулла́" (Gabdulla) often used in Adyghe
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Christian Arabic Bible uses the word Allah for God
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Presently in the Middle East, the name is sometimes used by Christians, as a given or family name
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The continued use of this name is perhaps attributed to the passage in Matthew 25:14-30 which refers to the parable of talents and the three servants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The parable praises the good servants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abelia  is a genus of about 30 species and many hybrids in the honeysuckle family Caprifoliaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some authors, including the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group, consider Abelia and related genera to belong instead in the segregate family Linnaeaceae, also including such genera as Linnaea, Abelia, Dipelta, Kolkwitzia, and Zabelia, but not such others as Lonicera or Symphoricarpos, included by them instead in a more narrowly viewed Caprifoliaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Abelias are shrubs from 1–6 m tall, native to eastern Asia (Japan west to the Himalaya) and southern North America (Mexico); the species from warm climates are evergreen, and colder climate species deciduous
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The leaves are opposite or in whorls of three, ovate, glossy, dark green, 1
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5–8 cm long, turning purplish-bronze to red in autumn in the deciduous species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The flowers appear in the upper leaf axils and stem ends, 1-8 together in a short cyme; they are pendulous, white to pink, bell-shaped with a five-lobed corolla, 1–5 cm long, and usually scented
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Flowering continues over a long and continuous period from late spring to fall
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Type species of this genus is Abelia chinensis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The generic name commemorates Clarke Abel, a keen naturalist who accompanied Lord Amherst's unsuccessful embassy to China in 1816 as surgeon, under the sponsorship of Sir Joseph Banks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 All of Abel's seeds and plants were lost in a shipwreck on the homeward voyage, however; living plants of Abelia chinensis were first imported to England in 1844 by Robert Fortune, who introduced A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 uniflora the following year
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The showy semi-hardy Mexican A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 floribunda of the Cordillera of Oaxaca was introduced to English horticulture in 1841
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Selected species
Hybrids
Abelia x grandiflora Hort
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ex
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Bailey
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abun (in Europe erroneously known as Abuna, which is the status constructus form used when a name follows: Ge'ez አቡነ ’abuna/abune, 'our father'; Amharic and Tigrinya) is the honorific title used for any bishop of the Ethiopian Orthodox Tewahedo Church as well as of the Eritrean Orthodox Tewahedo Church
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was historically used solely for the head of the Coptic Orthodox Church in Ethiopia during the more than 1000 years when the Coptic Patriarchate of Alexandria appointed only one bishop at a time to serve its Ethiopian flock
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When referred to without a name following, it is Abun, and if a name follows, it becomes Abuna 
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, Abuna Paulos)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In number theory, an abundant number or excessive number is a number for which the sum of its proper divisors is greater than the number itself
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The integer 12 is the first abundant number
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its proper divisors are 1, 2, 3, 4 and 6 for a total of 16
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The amount by which the sum exceeds the number is the abundance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The number 12 has an abundance of 4, for example
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abuse is the improper usage or treatment of an entity, often to unfairly or improperly gain benefit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abuse can come in many forms, such as: physical or verbal maltreatment, injury, assault, violation, rape, unjust practices, crimes, or other types of aggression
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abuse is the improper usage or treatment of an entity, often to unfairly or improperly gain benefit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abuse can come in many forms, such as: physical or verbal maltreatment, injury, assault, violation, rape, unjust practices, crimes, or other types of aggression
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abuse is the improper usage or treatment of an entity, often to unfairly or improperly gain benefit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abuse can come in many forms, such as: physical or verbal maltreatment, injury, assault, violation, rape, unjust practices, crimes, or other types of aggression
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abuse is the improper usage or treatment of an entity, often to unfairly or improperly gain benefit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abuse can come in many forms, such as: physical or verbal maltreatment, injury, assault, violation, rape, unjust practices, crimes, or other types of aggression
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abuse is the improper usage or treatment of an entity, often to unfairly or improperly gain benefit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abuse can come in many forms, such as: physical or verbal maltreatment, injury, assault, violation, rape, unjust practices, crimes, or other types of aggression
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Premises are land and buildings together considered as a property
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This usage arose from property owners finding the word in their [title deed]s, where it originally correctly meant "the aforementioned; what this document is about", from [Latin] prae-missus = "placed before"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In this sense, the word is always used in the plural, but singular in construction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Note that a single house or a single other piece of property is "premises", not a "premise", although the word "premises" is plural in form; e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "The equipment is on the customer's premises", never "The equipment is on the customer's premise"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abutilon  is a large genus of flowering plants in the mallow family, Malvaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is distributed throughout the tropics and subtropics of the Americas, Africa, Asia, and Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 General common names include Indian mallow and velvetleaf; in Russian, ornamental varieties are commonly known as the room maple
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The genus name is an 18th-century New Latin word that came from the Arabic ’abū-ṭīlūn (أبو طيلون), the name given by Avicenna to this or a similar genus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In engineering, abutment refers to the substructure at the ends of a bridge span or dam whereon the structure's superstructure rests or contacts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Single-span bridges have abutments at each end which provide vertical and lateral support for the bridge, as well as acting as retaining walls to resist lateral movement of the earthen fill of the bridge approach
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Multi-span bridges require piers to support ends of spans unsupported by abutments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Dam abutments are generally either side of a valley or gorge but may be artificial in order to support arch dams such as Kurobe Dam in Japan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The term may also refer to the structure supporting one side of an arch, or masonry used to resist the lateral forces of a vault
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The impost or abacus of a column in classical architecture may also serve as an abutment to an arch
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The word derives from the verb "abut", meaning to "touch by means of a mutual border"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An abutter is a person (or entity) whose property is adjacent to the property of another
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In jurisdictions such as Massachusetts, New Hampshire, and Nova Scotia, it is a defined legal term
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some jurisdictions, such as Virginia, may use the term adjacent landowner, while others, such as California, use the term adjoining landowner, and the United States Environmental Protection Agency defines rights of contiguous property owners (CPO)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


In land use regulations, concerns of an abutter may be given special attention, being the one most likely to suffer specific harm from a hasty, uninformed decision
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, a developer requesting a subdivision may be required to notify (or pay to notify) all abutters of the proposal and invite them to a public hearing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Regulations may also provide an abutter with the right to be heard at the hearing, unlike others who must request permission to be heard, at the discretion of the board
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the spirit of land use politics, even the unified voices of the concerned abutters may sound only faintly against the machinery of "progress" or well-funded special interests
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, the courts will objectively consider a proper case brought by an abutter whose rights have been arguably under-appreciated
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Generally, the more abutters interested in a project, the more likely someone will object to it
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Some regulations otherwise expand or limit the participation of local owners, as where notice may be required for "anyone whose property is within 200 feet of any point of the parcel under consideration
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
" Another expansive definition would include those whose properties are across a public way or flowing waterway, where the parcels do not actually touch
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Contrarily, regulations may define "abutter" to include only those people who hold record title to an adjacent parcel, thus undermining the rights of tenants, associations and partial owners (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, mineral rights and easement owners) to be notified, let alone heard on a proposal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This would also eliminate participation of owners of unrecorded title, such as adverse possession or those who have simply failed to record a deed or settle an estate involving the adjacent property
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An abutter is a person (or entity) whose property is adjacent to the property of another
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Abuse is the improper usage or treatment of an entity, often to unfairly or improperly gain benefit

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The abvolt (abV) is one option for the unit of potential difference in the EMU-CGS system of units, and is equal to 10−8 volts in the SI system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A potential difference of 1 abV will drive a current of one abampere through a resistance of one abohm
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In most practical applications, the volt and its multiples are preferred
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The national standard in the United States  deprecates the use of the abvolt, suggesting the use of volts instead
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The other option in the cgs system is the statvolt
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aby is a village in the East Lindsey district of Lincolnshire, England
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is situated approximately 30 miles (48 km) east from the city and county town of Lincoln, and 8 miles (13 km) south-east from Louth
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aby is part of the civil parish of Aby with Greenfield 
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abuse is the improper usage or treatment of an entity, often to unfairly or improperly gain benefit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Abuse can come in many forms, such as: physical or verbal maltreatment, injury, assault, violation, rape, unjust practices, crimes, or other types of aggression
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Abysmal is the seventh studio album by American death metal band The Black Dahlia Murder
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was released on September 18, 2015 through Metal Blade Records
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was produced by Mark Lewis, who also produced The Black Dahlia Murder's albums Deflorate and Ritual, and the band's former bassist Ryan Williams, who also produced their preceding album Everblack
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is the band's final album to feature guitarist Ryan Knight before his departure in February 2016
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The abyssal zone or abyssopelagic is a layer of the pelagic zone of the ocean
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "Abyss" derives from the Greek word ἄβυσσος, meaning bottomless
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At depths of 4,000 to 6,000 metres (13,123 to 19,685 feet), this zone remains in perpetual darkness and never receives daylight
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These regions are also characterised by continuous cold and lack of nutrients
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The abyssal zone has temperatures around 2 °C to 3 °C (35 °F to 37 °F) through the large majority of its mass
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is the deeper part of the midnight zone which starts in the bathypelagic waters above
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its permanent inhabitants (for example, Riftia pachyptila, (the giant tube worm)) found near hydrothermal vents in the Pacific Ocean and the giant squid are able to withstand the immense pressures of the ocean depths, up to 76 megapascals (11,000 psi)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The area below the abyssal zone is the sparsely inhabited hadal zone
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The zone above is the bathyal zone
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Mimosa tenuiflora, syn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Mimosa hostilis (Jurema Preta, Calumbi (Brazil), Tepezcohuite (México), Carbonal, Cabrera ) is a perennial tree or shrub native to the northeastern region of Brazil (Paraíba, Rio Grande do Norte, Ceará, Pernambuco, Bahia) and found as far north as southern Mexico (Oaxaca and coast of Chiapas), and the following countries: El Salvador, Honduras, Panama, Colombia and Venezuela
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is most often found in lower altitudes, but it can be found as high as 1,000 m (3,300 ft)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An academy (Attic Greek: Ἀκαδήμεια; Koine Greek Ἀκαδημία) is an institution of secondary education, higher learning, research, or honorary membership
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The name traces back to Plato's school of philosophy, founded approximately 385 BC at Akademia, a sanctuary of Athena, the goddess of wisdom and skill, north of Athens, Greece
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Academy is a type of secondary or tertiary education institutions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Academy is a type of secondary or tertiary education institutions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Academy is a type of secondary or tertiary education institutions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An academician is a full member of an artistic, literary, or scientific academy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In many countries, it is an honorific title used to denote a full member of an academy that has a strong influence on national scientific life
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In systems such as the Academy of Sciences of the USSR, the title grants privileges and administrative responsibilities for funding allocation and research priorities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU; Chinese: 上海交通大学) is a public research university in Shanghai, China
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Established in 1896 as Nanyang Public School by an imperial edict issued by the Guangxu Emperor, the university is one of the first national institutions of higher learning in China, and renowned as one of the oldest, most prestigious and selective universities in China
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is one of the nine members in the C9 League of universities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Academy is a type of secondary or tertiary education institutions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An academy (Attic Greek: Ἀκαδήμεια; Koine Greek Ἀκαδημία) is an institution of secondary education, higher learning, research, or honorary membership
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The name traces back to Plato's school of philosophy, founded approximately 385 BC at Akademia, a sanctuary of Athena, the goddess of wisdom and skill, north of Athens, Greece
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acadia (French: Acadie) was a colony of New France in northeastern North America that included parts of eastern Quebec, the Maritime provinces, and modern-day Maine to the Kennebec River
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During much of the 17th and early 18th centuries, Norridgewock on the Kennebec River and Castine at the end of the Penobscot River were the southernmost settlements of Acadia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The actual specification by the French government for the territory refers to lands bordering the Atlantic coast, roughly between the 40th and 46th parallels
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Later, the territory was divided into the British colonies that became Canadian provinces and American states
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The population of Acadia included members of the Wabanaki Confederacy and descendants of emigrants from France (i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, Acadians)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The two communities intermarried, which resulted in a significant portion of the population of Acadia being Métis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The first capital of Acadia, established in 1605, was Port-Royal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A British force from Virginia attacked and burned down the town in 1613, but it was later rebuilt nearby, where it remained the longest serving capital of French Acadia until the British Siege of Port Royal in 1710
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Over seventy-four years there were six colonial wars, in which English and later British interests tried to capture Acadia starting with King William's War in 1689
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During these wars, along with some French troops from Quebec, some Acadians, the Wabanaki Confederacy, and French priests continuously raided New England settlements along the border in Maine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 While Acadia was officially conquered in 1710 during Queen Anne's War, present-day New Brunswick and much of Maine remained contested territory
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Present-day Prince Edward Island (Île Saint-Jean) and Cape Breton (Île Royale) as agreed under Article XIII of the Treaty of Utrecht remained under French control
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 By militarily defeating the Wabanaki Confederacy and the French priests, present-day Maine fell during Father Rale's War
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During King George's War, France and New France made significant attempts to regain mainland Nova Scotia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 After Father Le Loutre's War, present-day New Brunswick fell to the British
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Finally, during the French and Indian War (the North American theatre of the Seven Years' War), both Île Royale and Île Saint-Jean fell to the British in 1758
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Today, the term Acadia is used to refer to regions of North America that are historically associated with the lands, descendants, and/or culture of the former French region
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It particularly refers to regions of The Maritimes with French roots, language, and culture, primarily in New Brunswick, Nova Scotia, the Magdalen Islands and Prince Edward Island, as well as in Maine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can also be used to refer to the Acadian diaspora in southern Louisiana, a region also referred to as Acadiana
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the abstract, Acadia refers to the existence of a French culture in any of these regions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

People living in Acadia, and sometimes former residents and their descendants, are called Acadians, also later known as Cajuns after resettlement in Louisiana
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Acadians (French: Acadiens, IPA: [akadjɛ̃]) are the descendants of French colonists who settled in Acadia during the 17th and 18th centuries, some of whom are also descended from the Indigenous peoples of the region
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The colony was located in what is now Eastern Canada's Maritime provinces (Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, and Prince Edward Island), as well as part of Quebec, and present-day Maine to the Kennebec River
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although today most of the Acadians and Québécois are French-speaking (francophone) Canadians, Acadia was a distinctly separate colony of New France
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was geographically and administratively separate from the French colony of Canada (modern-day Quebec)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a result, the Acadians and Québécois developed two distinct histories and cultures
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They also developed a slightly different French language
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 France has one official language and to accomplish this they have an administration in charge of the language
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Since the Acadians were separated from this council, their French language evolved independently, and Acadians retain several elements of 17th-century French that have been lost in France
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The settlers whose descendants became Acadians came from many areas in France, but especially regions such as Île-de-France, Normandy, Brittany, Poitou and Aquitaine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acadian family names have come from many areas in France
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, the Maillets are from Paris; the LeBlancs of Normandy; the surname Melanson is from Brittany, and those with the surnames Bastarache and Basque came from Aquitaine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

During the French and Indian War (the North American theater of the Seven Years' War), British colonial officers suspected Acadians were aligned with France after finding some Acadians fighting alongside French troops at Fort Beausejour
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Though most Acadians remained neutral during the French and Indian War, the British, together with New England legislators and militia, carried out the Great Expulsion (Le Grand Dérangement) of the Acadians during the 1755–1764 period
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They deported approximately 11,500 Acadians from the maritime region
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Approximately one-third perished from disease and drowning
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The result was what one historian described as an ethnic cleansing of the Acadians from Maritime Canada
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other historians indicate that it was a deportation similar to other deportations of the time period
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Most Acadians were deported to various American colonies, where many were forced into servitude, or marginal lifestyles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some Acadians were deported to England, sent to the Caribbean, and some were deported to France
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 After being expelled to France, many Acadians were eventually recruited by the Spanish government to migrate to present day Louisiana state (known then as Spanish colonial Luisiana), where they developed what became known as Cajun culture
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In time, some Acadians returned to the Maritime provinces of Canada, mainly to New Brunswick because they were barred by the British from resettling their lands and villages in what became Nova Scotia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Before the US Revolutionary War, the Crown settled New England Planters in former Acadian communities and farmland as well as, after the war, Loyalists (including nearly 3,000 Black Loyalists, who were freed slaves)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 British policy was to assimilate Acadians with the local populations where they resettled
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acadians speak a dialect of French called Acadian French
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many of those in the Moncton area speak Chiac and English
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Louisiana Cajun descendants speak a dialect of American English called Cajun English, with several also speaking Cajun French, a close relative of the original dialect from Canada influenced by Spanish and West African languages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acalypha is a genus of flowering plants in the family Euphorbiaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is the sole genus of the subtribe Acalyphinae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is one of the largest euphorb genera, with approximately 450 to 462 species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The genus name Acalypha is from the Greek ακαλεφης, akalephes ("nettle"), and was inspired by the nettle-like leaves
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 General common names include copperleaf
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The genus is distributed mainly in the tropics and subtropics, with about 60% of species native to the Americas and about 30% in Africa
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthaceae is a family (the acanthus family) of dicotyledonous flowering plants containing almost 250 genera and about 2500 species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most are tropical herbs, shrubs, or twining vines; some are epiphytes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Only a few species are distributed in temperate regions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The four main centres of distribution are Indonesia and Malaysia, Africa, Brazil, and Central America
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The representatives of the family can be found in nearly every habitat, including dense or open forests, scrublands, wet fields and valleys, sea coast and marine areas, swamps, and mangrove forests
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The rifleman (Acanthisitta chloris) (Māori: tītipounamu) is a small insectivorous passerine bird that is endemic to New Zealand
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It belongs to the Acanthisittidae family, also known as the New Zealand wrens, of which it is one of only two surviving species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The rifleman resembles a wren in form, but is not related to the family of true wrens, Troglodytidae, nor the fairy-wrens of Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The rifleman is named after a colonial New Zealand regiment because its plumage drew similarities with the military uniform of a rifleman
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthocephala (Greek ἄκανθος, akanthos, thorn + κεφαλή, kephale, head) is a phylum of parasitic worms known as acanthocephalans, thorny-headed worms, or spiny-headed worms, characterized by the presence of an eversible proboscis, armed with spines, which it uses to pierce and hold the gut wall of its host
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acanthocephalans have complex life cycles, involving at least two hosts, which may include invertebrates, fish, amphibians, birds, and mammals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
  About 1150 species have been described
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Acanthocephala were thought to be a discrete phylum
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Recent genome analysis has shown that they are descended from, and should be considered as, highly modified rotifers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This finding is an example of molecular phylogenetics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This unified taxon is known as Syndermata
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthocephala (Greek ἄκανθος, akanthos, thorn + κεφαλή, kephale, head) is a phylum of parasitic worms known as acanthocephalans, thorny-headed worms, or spiny-headed worms, characterized by the presence of an eversible proboscis, armed with spines, which it uses to pierce and hold the gut wall of its host
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acanthocephalans have complex life cycles, involving at least two hosts, which may include invertebrates, fish, amphibians, birds, and mammals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
  About 1150 species have been described
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Acanthocephala were thought to be a discrete phylum
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Recent genome analysis has shown that they are descended from, and should be considered as, highly modified rotifers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This finding is an example of molecular phylogenetics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This unified taxon is known as Syndermata
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthocereus is a genus of cacti
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its species take the form of shrubs with arching or climbing stems up to several meters in height
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The generic name is derived from the Greek word άκανθα (acantha), meaning spine, and the Latin word cereus, meaning candle
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The six species occur in the tropical Americas from the southern tip of Florida to Colombia, including islands of the Caribbean
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Stems have 3 to 5 ribs, typically thin, with stout spines
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The pretty white funnel-shaped flowers are night-opening, 12–25 cm (4
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
7–9
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
8 in) long and 6–12 cm (2
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
4–4
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
7 in) in diameter
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


Acanthocereus tetragonus, commonly known as Barbed-wire Cactus, Chaco, Nun-tsusuy, or Órgano, is the most widespread of the genus and the largest, reaching 2–7 m (6
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
6–23
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
0 ft) tall
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The name was first used by George Engelmann in 1863, although he did not describe its characters, leaving it to Alwin Berger in 1905 to define it as a subsection of Cereus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 1909, Nathaniel Britton and Joseph Nelson Rose elevated Acanthocereus to a genus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Wahoo (Acanthocybium solandri) is a scombrid fish found worldwide in tropical and subtropical seas
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is best known to sports fishermen, as its speed and high-quality flesh make it a prize game fish
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Hawaii, the wahoo is known as ono
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many Hispanic areas of the Caribbean and Central America refer to this fish as peto
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The flesh of the wahoo is white to grey, delicate to dense, and highly regarded by many gourmets
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The taste has been said to be similar to mackerel
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This has created some demand for the wahoo as a premium-priced commercial food fish
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In many areas of its range, such as Hawaii, Bermuda and many parts of the Caribbean, local demand for wahoo is met by artisanal commercial fishermen, who take them primarily by trolling, as well as by recreational sports fishermen who sell their catch
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthocyte (from the Greek word ἄκανθα acantha, meaning 'thorn'), in biology and medicine, refers to a form of red blood cell that has a spiked cell membrane, due to abnormal thorny projections
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A similar term is spur cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Often they may be confused with echinocytes or schistocytes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acanthocytes have coarse, weirdly spaced, variably sized crenations, resembling many-pointed stars
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are seen on blood films in, among others abetalipoproteinemia, liver disease, chorea acanthocytosis, McLeod syndrome, and several inherited neurological and other disorders, such as neuroacanthocytosis, anorexia nervosa, infantile pyknocytosis, hypothyroidism, idiopathic neonatal hepatitis, alcoholism, congestive splenomegaly, Zieve syndrome, and chronic granulomatous disease
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthocyte (from the Greek word ἄκανθα acantha, meaning 'thorn'), in biology and medicine, refers to a form of red blood cell that has a spiked cell membrane, due to abnormal thorny projections
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A similar term is spur cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Often they may be confused with echinocytes or schistocytes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acanthocytes have coarse, weirdly spaced, variably sized crenations, resembling many-pointed stars
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are seen on blood films in, among others abetalipoproteinemia, liver disease, chorea acanthocytosis, McLeod syndrome, and several inherited neurological and other disorders, such as neuroacanthocytosis, anorexia nervosa, infantile pyknocytosis, hypothyroidism, idiopathic neonatal hepatitis, alcoholism, congestive splenomegaly, Zieve syndrome, and chronic granulomatous disease
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthosis is diffuse epidermal hyperplasia (thickening of the skin)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It implies increased thickness of the Malpighian layer (stratum basale and stratum spinosum)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acantholysis is the loss of intercellular connections, such as desmosomes, resulting in loss of cohesion between keratinocytes, seen in diseases such as pemphigus vulgaris
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is absent in bullous pemphigoid, making it useful for differential diagnosis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

This histological feature is also seen in herpes simplex infections (HSV 1 and 2) and varicella zoster infections (chicken pox and shingles)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acanthoma is a skin neoplasm composed of squamous or epidermal cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is located in the prickle cell layer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Types of acanthoma include pilar sheath acanthoma, a benign follicular tumor usually of the upper lip; clear cell acanthoma, a benign tumor found most frequently on the legs; and Degos acanthoma, often confused with but unrelated to Degos disease
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthophis is a genus of elapid snakes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Commonly called death adders, they are native to Australia, New Guinea and nearby islands, and are among the most venomous snakes in the world
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name of the genus derives from the Ancient Greek acanthos/ἄκανθος "spine" and ophis/ὄφις "snake", referring to the spine on the death adder's tail
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Seven species are listed by ITIS, though it remains unclear how many species this genus includes, with figures ranging from 4 to 15 species being quoted
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthopterygii (meaning "spiny finned one") is a superorder of bony fishes in the class Actinopterygii
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Members of this superorder are sometimes called ray-finned fishes for the characteristic sharp, bony rays in their fins; however this name is often given to the class Actinopterygii as a whole
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acanthoscelides is a genus of bean weevils of the subfamily Bruchinae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are native to the New World
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 About one third of them can be found in Mexico
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In 1946 this genus was populated with at least 322 species transferred from other genera, mainly Bruchus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some of these were later placed into other genera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Estimates of the current number of named species range from about 300 to 340, and there are over 200 undescribed species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

These beetles are generally 1
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
1 to 3
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5 millimeters long
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They have large, protruding eyes, and males often have larger eyes than females
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They sometimes also have longer antennae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The elytra are about twice as long as they are wide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The beetles of this genus are diverse and the characters used to classify them are not well defined; historically, Acanthoscelides is a wastebasket taxon, "used as a genus into which species are placed that do not fit within the limits of other genera"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Most of these beetles feed on legumes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The majority specialize on Faboideae, many on Mimosoideae, and fewer on Caesalpinioideae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some are known from non-legume host plants, such as mallows
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Familiar species include Acanthoscelides obtectus, a worldwide pest of beans, and Acanthoscelides macrophthalmus, which is employed as an agent of biological pest control against the invasive tree Leucaena leucocephala
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Species include:
