The accolade (also known as dubbing or adoubement) (Latin: benedictio militis) was the central act in the rite of passage ceremonies conferring knighthood in the Middle Ages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 From about 1852, the term accolade was used much more generally to mean "praise" or "award" or "honor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accompany is an American mobile and web relationship management app
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Known as a "personal chief-of-staff," it helps organize a person's contacts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The company is led by Amy Chang, former head of Google Analytics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was founded by Chang, Matthias Ruhl, a senior research scientist at Google, and Ryan McDonough, former CFO of Ning
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accompany has raised a total of $40 million+ in investments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They raised a round of $20
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
6 million in investment from Cowboy Ventures, Charles River Ventures, Iconic, and Dave Goldberg
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In December 2016, Accompany raised an additional round of $20 million from Ignition Partners
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accompaniment is the musical parts which provide the rhythmic and/or harmonic support for the melody or main themes of a song or instrumental piece
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are many different styles and types of accompaniment in different genres and styles of music
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In homophonic music, the main accompaniment approach used in popular music, a clear vocal melody is supported by subordinate chords
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In popular music and traditional music, the accompaniment parts typically provide the "beat" for the music and outline the chord progression of the song or instrumental piece
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The accompaniment for a vocal melody or instrumental solo can be played by a single musician playing an instrument such as piano, pipe organ, or guitar
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 While any instrument can in theory be used as an accompaniment instrument, keyboard and guitar-family instruments tend to be used if there is only a single instrument, as these instruments can play chords and basslines simultaneously (chords and a bassline are easier to play simultaneously on keyboard instruments, but a fingerpicking guitarist can play chords and a bassline simultaneously on guitar)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A solo singer can accompany herself by playing guitar or piano while she sings, and in some rare cases, a solo singer can even accompany himself or herself just using his or her voice and body (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, Bobby McFerrin)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Alternatively, the accompaniment to a vocal melody or instrumental solo can be provided by a musical ensemble, ranging in size from a duo (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, cello and piano; guitar and double bass; synthesizer and percussion); a trio (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, a rock power trio of electric guitar, electric bass and drum kit; an organ trio); a quartet (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, a string quartet in Classical music can accompany a solo singer; a rock band or rhythm section in rock and pop; a jazz quartet in jazz); all the way to larger ensembles, such as concert bands, Big Bands (in jazz), pit orchestras in musical theatre; and orchestras, which, in addition to playing symphonies, can also provide accompaniment to a concerto solo instrumentalist or to solo singers in opera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 With choral music, the accompaniment to a vocal solo can be provided by other singers in the choir, who sing harmony parts or countermelodies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accompaniment parts range from so simple that a beginner can play them (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, simple three-note triad chords in a traditional folk song) to so complex that only an advanced player or singer can perform them (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, the piano parts in Schubert's Lieder art songs from the 19th century or vocal parts from a Renaissance music motet)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accompaniment is the musical parts which provide the rhythmic and/or harmonic support for the melody or main themes of a song or instrumental piece
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are many different styles and types of accompaniment in different genres and styles of music
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In homophonic music, the main accompaniment approach used in popular music, a clear vocal melody is supported by subordinate chords
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In popular music and traditional music, the accompaniment parts typically provide the "beat" for the music and outline the chord progression of the song or instrumental piece
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The accompaniment for a vocal melody or instrumental solo can be played by a single musician playing an instrument such as piano, pipe organ, or guitar
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 While any instrument can in theory be used as an accompaniment instrument, keyboard and guitar-family instruments tend to be used if there is only a single instrument, as these instruments can play chords and basslines simultaneously (chords and a bassline are easier to play simultaneously on keyboard instruments, but a fingerpicking guitarist can play chords and a bassline simultaneously on guitar)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A solo singer can accompany herself by playing guitar or piano while she sings, and in some rare cases, a solo singer can even accompany himself or herself just using his or her voice and body (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, Bobby McFerrin)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Alternatively, the accompaniment to a vocal melody or instrumental solo can be provided by a musical ensemble, ranging in size from a duo (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, cello and piano; guitar and double bass; synthesizer and percussion); a trio (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, a rock power trio of electric guitar, electric bass and drum kit; an organ trio); a quartet (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, a string quartet in Classical music can accompany a solo singer; a rock band or rhythm section in rock and pop; a jazz quartet in jazz); all the way to larger ensembles, such as concert bands, Big Bands (in jazz), pit orchestras in musical theatre; and orchestras, which, in addition to playing symphonies, can also provide accompaniment to a concerto solo instrumentalist or to solo singers in opera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 With choral music, the accompaniment to a vocal solo can be provided by other singers in the choir, who sing harmony parts or countermelodies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accompaniment parts range from so simple that a beginner can play them (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, simple three-note triad chords in a traditional folk song) to so complex that only an advanced player or singer can perform them (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, the piano parts in Schubert's Lieder art songs from the 19th century or vocal parts from a Renaissance music motet)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accompany is an American mobile and web relationship management app
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Known as a "personal chief-of-staff," it helps organize a person's contacts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The company is led by Amy Chang, former head of Google Analytics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was founded by Chang, Matthias Ruhl, a senior research scientist at Google, and Ryan McDonough, former CFO of Ning
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accompany has raised a total of $40 million+ in investments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They raised a round of $20
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
6 million in investment from Cowboy Ventures, Charles River Ventures, Iconic, and Dave Goldberg
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In December 2016, Accompany raised an additional round of $20 million from Ignition Partners
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Under the English common law, an accomplice is a person who actively participates in the commission of a crime, even if they take no part in the actual criminal offense
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, in a bank robbery, the person who points the gun at the teller and asks for the money is guilty of armed robbery
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Anyone else directly involved in the commission of the crime, such as the lookout or the getaway car driver, is an accomplice, even if in the absence of an underlying offense keeping a lookout or driving a car would not be an offense
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An accomplice differs from an accessory in that an accomplice is present at the actual crime, and could be prosecuted even if the main criminal (the principal) is not charged or convicted
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An accessory is generally not present at the actual crime, and may be subject to lesser penalties than an accomplice or principal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

At law, an accomplice has lesser guilt than the person he or she is assisting, is subject to lesser prosecution for the same crime, and faces the smaller criminal penalties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As such, the three accomplices to the bank robbery above can also to a degree be found guilty of armed robbery even if only one stole money
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The fairness of the doctrine that the accomplice is still guilty has been subject to much discussion, particularly in cases of capital crimes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accomplices have been prosecuted for felony murder even if the actual person who committed the murder died at the crime scene or otherwise did not face capital punishment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In jurisdictions based on the common law, the concept of an accomplice has often been heavily modified by statute, or replaced by new concepts entirely
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Annabelle is a 2014 American supernatural horror film directed by John R
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Leonetti, written by Gary Dauberman and produced by Peter Safran and James Wan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a prequel to 2013's The Conjuring and the second installment in The Conjuring series
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film was inspired by a story of a doll named Annabelle told by Ed and Lorraine Warren
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film stars Annabelle Wallis, Ward Horton, and Alfre Woodard
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Annabelle premiered at the TCL Chinese Theatre in Los Angeles on September 29, 2014, and was theatrically released in the United States on October 3, 2014
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film received generally negative reviews from critics but was a box office success, grossing over $256 million against its $6
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5 million production budget
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A prequel, titled Annabelle: Creation, was released on August 11, 2017
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The 2003 Mission Accomplished speech gets its name from a banner that read "Mission Accomplished" displayed on the aircraft carrier USS Abraham Lincoln during a televised address by United States President George W
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Bush on May 1, 2003 and the controversy that followed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Although Bush stated at the time "Our mission continues" and "We have difficult work to do in Iraq," he also stated that it was the end to major combat operations in Iraq
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Bush never uttered the phrase "Mission Accomplished"; a banner stating "Mission Accomplished" was used as a backdrop to the speech
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Bush's assertion—and the sign itself—became controversial after guerrilla warfare in Iraq increased during the Iraqi insurgency
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The vast majority of casualties, both military and civilian, occurred after the speech
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accordance is a Bible study program for Apple Macintosh and iPhone, and now Windows developed by OakTree Software, Inc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Reviewers consider it a premium program
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Although originally written exclusively for the Mac OS (and then iOS), Accordance has now been released (October 1, 2013) in a Windows-native version, although it was available prior to this by using the Basilisk II emulator
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The program is used for both private and academic study
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The translators of the Holman Christian Standard Bible, completed in 2004, used it for word studies, comparisons and instant searches
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Commenting on the use of Accordance, the HCSB's editor Ed Blum said, "This project used far more computerization than anyone else has ever been able to do
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
According to Jim is an American sitcom television series starring Jim Belushi in the title role as a suburban father of three children (five children starting with the season-seven finale)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It originally ran on ABC from October 3, 2001 to June 2, 2009
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accordions (from 19th century German Akkordeon, from Akkord—"musical chord, concord of sounds") are a family of box-shaped musical instruments of the bellows-driven free-reed aerophone type, colloquially referred to as a squeezebox
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A person who plays the accordion is called an accordionist
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The concertina and bandoneón are related; the harmonium and American reed organ are in the same family
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The instrument is played by compressing or expanding the bellows while pressing buttons or keys, causing pallets to open, which allow air to flow across strips of brass or steel, called reeds
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These vibrate to produce sound inside the body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Valves on opposing reeds of each note are used to make the instrument's reeds sound louder without air leaking from each reed block
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The performer normally plays the melody on buttons or keys on the right-hand manual, and the accompaniment, consisting of bass and pre-set chord buttons, on the left-hand manual
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The accordion is widely spread across the world
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In some countries (for example Brazil, Colombia and Mexico) it is used in popular music (for example Forró, Sertanejo and B-Pop in Brazil), whereas in other regions (such as Europe, North America and other countries in South America) it tends to be more used for dance-pop and folk music and as well as in regional and is often used in folk music in Europe, North America and South America
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Nevertheless, in Europe and North America, some popular music acts also make use of the instrument
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Additionally, the accordion is also used in cajun, zydeco, jazz music and in both solo and orchestra performances of classical music
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The piano accordion is the official city instrument of San Francisco, California
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many conservatories in Europe have classical accordion departments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The oldest name for this group of instruments is harmonika, from the Greek harmonikos, meaning harmonic, musical
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Today, native versions of the name accordion are more common
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These names refer to the type of accordion patented by Cyrill Demian, which concerned "automatically coupled chords on the bass side"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
A sanitary napkin, sanitary towel, sanitary pad, menstrual pad, or pad is an absorbent item worn by a woman while she is menstruating, while she is recovering from vaginal surgery, for lochia (post-birth bleeding), after an abortion, or in any other situation where it is necessary to absorb a flow of blood from the vagina
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

These pads are not to be confused with generally higher absorbency incontinence pads, which are worn by men or women who have urinary incontinence problems or experience stress incontinence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Menstrual pads may be used by some people for this purpose
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Obstetrics and gynecology (commonly known as OB-GYN, OBG, O&G or obs and gynae) is the medical specialty that deals with obstetrics and gynecology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Postgraduate training programs for both aspects are usually combined, preparing the practicing obstetrician-gynecologist to be adept at the care of female reproductive organs' health and at the management of pregnancy, although many doctors go on to develop subspecialty interests in one field or the other
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Obstetrics and gynecology (commonly known as OB-GYN, OBG, O&G or obs and gynae) is the medical specialty that deals with obstetrics and gynecology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Postgraduate training programs for both aspects are usually combined, preparing the practicing obstetrician-gynecologist to be adept at the care of female reproductive organs' health and at the management of pregnancy, although many doctors go on to develop subspecialty interests in one field or the other
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In ethics and governance, accountability is answerability, blameworthiness, liability, and the expectation of account-giving
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As an aspect of governance, it has been central to discussions related to problems in the public sector, nonprofit and private (corporate) and individual contexts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In leadership roles, accountability is the acknowledgment and assumption of responsibility for actions, products, decisions, and policies including the administration, governance, and implementation within the scope of the role or employment position and encompassing the obligation to report, explain and be answerable for resulting consequences
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In governance, accountability has expanded beyond the basic definition of "being called to account for one's actions"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is frequently described as an account-giving relationship between individuals, e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "A is accountable to B when A is obliged to inform B about A's (past or future) actions and decisions, to justify them, and to suffer punishment in the case of eventual misconduct"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accountability cannot exist without proper accounting practices; in other words, an absence of accounting means an absence of accountability
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accountability is an element of a RACI to indicate who is ultimately answerable for the correct and thorough completion of the deliverable or task, and the one who delegates the work to those responsible
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There are various reasons (legitimate or excuses) why accountability fails
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accounting or accountancy is the measurement, processing, and communication of financial information about economic entities such as businesses and corporations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The modern field was established by the Italian mathematician Luca Pacioli in 1494
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accounting, which has been called the "language of business", measures the results of an organization's economic activities and conveys this information to a variety of users, including investors, creditors, management, and regulators
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Practitioners of accounting are known as accountants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The terms "accounting" and "financial reporting" are often used as synonyms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accounting can be divided into several fields including financial accounting, management accounting, external auditing, tax accounting and cost accounting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accounting information systems are designed to support accounting functions and related activities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Financial accounting focuses on the reporting of an organization's financial information, including the preparation of financial statements, to external users of the information, such as investors, regulators and suppliers; and management accounting focuses on the measurement, analysis and reporting of information for internal use by management
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The recording of financial transactions, so that summaries of the financials may be presented in financial reports, is known as bookkeeping, of which double-entry bookkeeping is the most common system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accounting is facilitated by accounting organizations such as standard-setters, accounting firms and professional bodies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Financial statements are usually audited by accounting firms, and are prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 GAAP is set by various standard-setting organizations such as the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) in the United States and the Financial Reporting Council in the United Kingdom
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As of 2012, "all major economies" have plans to converge towards or adopt the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An accountant is a practitioner of accounting or accountancy, which is the measurement, disclosure or provision of assurance about financial information that helps managers, investors, tax authorities and others make decisions about allocating resource(s)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In many jurisdictions, professional accounting bodies maintain standards of practice and evaluations for professionals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accountants who have demonstrated competency through their professional associations' certification exams are certified to use titles such as Chartered Accountant, Chartered Certified Accountant or Certified Public Accountant
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Such professionals are granted certain responsibilities by statute, such as the ability to certify an organization's financial statements, and may be held liable for professional misconduct
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Non-qualified accountants may be employed by a qualified accountant, or may work independently without statutory privileges and obligations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Big Four auditors are the largest employers of accountants worldwide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, most accountants are employed in commerce, industry and the public sector
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An accountant is a practitioner of accounting or accountancy, which is the measurement, disclosure or provision of assurance about financial information that helps managers, investors, tax authorities and others make decisions about allocating resource(s)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Non-qualified accountants may be employed by a qualified accountant, or may work independently without statutory privileges and obligations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Big Four auditors are the largest employers of accountants worldwide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, most accountants are employed in commerce, industry and the public sector
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Electronic mail (email or e-mail) is a method of exchanging messages between people using electronics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Email first entered substantial use in the 1960s and by the mid-1970s had taken the form now recognized as email
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Email operates across computer networks, which today is primarily the Internet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some early email systems required the author and the recipient to both be online at the same time, in common with instant messaging
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Today's email systems are based on a store-and-forward model
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Email servers accept, forward, deliver, and store messages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Neither the users nor their computers are required to be online simultaneously; they need to connect only briefly, typically to a mail server or a webmail interface, for as long as it takes to send or receive messages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Originally an ASCII text-only communications medium, Internet email was extended by Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) to carry text in other character sets and multimedia content attachments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 International email, with internationalized email addresses using UTF-8, has been standardized, but as of 2017 it has not been widely adopted
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The history of modern Internet email services reaches back to the early ARPANET, with standards for encoding email messages published as early as 1973 (RFC 561)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An email message sent in the early 1970s looks very similar to a basic email sent today
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Email had an important role in creating the Internet, and the conversion from ARPANET to the Internet in the early 1980s produced the core of the current services
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accounting or accountancy is the measurement, processing, and communication of financial information about economic entities such as businesses and corporations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The modern field was established by the Italian mathematician Luca Pacioli in 1494
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As of 2012, "all major economies" have plans to converge towards or adopt the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Serge Van Laeken (known as Marka), born on 27 May 1961 at Molenbeek-Saint-Jean (Sint-Jans-Molenbeek), is a Belgian singer, songwriter, composer and film-maker
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Alban Ceray (January 30, 1945) is a Monegasque pornographic actor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His career spans over 30 years, from the Golden Age of French porn in the 1970s to the Internet era in the early 2000s
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Robert James "Bobby" Fischer (March 9, 1943 – January 17, 2008) was an American chess grandmaster and the eleventh World Chess Champion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many consider him to be the greatest chess player of all time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 1972, he captured the World Chess Championship from Boris Spassky of the USSR in a match held in Reykjavík, Iceland, publicized as a Cold War confrontation, which attracted more worldwide interest than any chess championship before or since
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 1975, Fischer refused to defend his title when an agreement could not be reached with FIDE, the game's international governing body, over one of the conditions for the match
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This allowed Soviet GM Anatoly Karpov, who had won the qualifying Candidates' cycle, to become the new world champion by default under FIDE rules
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Fischer showed skill at an early age
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At age 13, he won a "brilliancy" that became known as "The Game of the Century"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Starting at age 14, Fischer played in eight United States Championships, winning each by at least a one-point margin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At age 15, Fischer became both the youngest grandmaster up to that time and the youngest candidate for the World Championship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

At age 20, Fischer won the 1963–64 U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Championship with 11/11, the only perfect score in the history of the tournament
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His book My 60 Memorable Games (published 1969) is regarded as a classic work of chess literature
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Fischer won the 1970 Interzonal Tournament by a record 3½-point margin and won 20 consecutive games, including two unprecedented 6–0 sweeps in the Candidates Matches
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In July 1971, he became the first official FIDE number-one-rated player
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

After losing his title as World Chess Champion, Fischer became reclusive and sometimes erratic, disappearing from both competitive chess and the public eye
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 1992, he reemerged to win an unofficial rematch against Spassky
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was held in Yugoslavia, which was under a United Nations embargo at the time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His participation led to a conflict with the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 government, which sought income tax on Fischer's match winnings, and ultimately issued a warrant for his arrest
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 After that, he lived his life as an émigré
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2004, he was arrested in Japan and held for several months for using a passport that had been revoked by the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 government
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Eventually, he was granted an Icelandic passport and citizenship by a special act of the Icelandic Althing, allowing him to live in Iceland until his death in 2008
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Fischer made numerous lasting contributions to chess
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the 1990s, he patented a modified chess timing system, which added a time increment after each move, now a standard practice in top tournament and match play
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He also invented a new variant of chess named Fischerandom (known today as "Chess960")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accoutrements are the personal/individual equipment of service people such as soldiers, sailors, police and firemen and employees of some private organizations such as security guards, other than their basic uniform and weapons
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accoutrements can be intended for field, garrison or ceremonial purposes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most accoutrements for field use are purely practical in nature
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Ceremonial accoutrements may no longer have a practical purpose in modern operations but may be retained to maintain a tradition
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Garrison accoutrements will vary in their usefulness and include both practical and ceremonial/traditional items
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Some accoutrements such as lanyards, have both a traditional/ceremonial and a practical purpose
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In these cases a different item may be worn in garrison or ceremonial occasions than that used in the field
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, in the Australian army different corps and units wear different coloured lanyards for service or ceremonial dress, but universally use drab natural fibre coloured lanyards for pistol retention in the field
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accoutrements are the personal/individual equipment of service people such as soldiers, sailors, police and firemen and employees of some private organizations such as security guards, other than their basic uniform and weapons
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accoutrements can be intended for field, garrison or ceremonial purposes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most accoutrements for field use are purely practical in nature
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Ceremonial accoutrements may no longer have a practical purpose in modern operations but may be retained to maintain a tradition
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Garrison accoutrements will vary in their usefulness and include both practical and ceremonial/traditional items
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In these cases a different item may be worn in garrison or ceremonial occasions than that used in the field
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, in the Australian army different corps and units wear different coloured lanyards for service or ceremonial dress, but universally use drab natural fibre coloured lanyards for pistol retention in the field
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An actor (often actress for females; see terminology) is a person who portrays a character in a performance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The actor performs "in the flesh" in the traditional medium of the theatre, or in modern mediums such as film, radio, and television
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The analogous Greek term is ὑποκριτής (hupokritḗs), literally "one who answers"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The actor's interpretation of their role pertains to the role played, whether based on a real person or fictional character
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Interpretation occurs even when the actor is "playing themselves", as in some forms of experimental performance art, or, more commonly; to act, is to create, a character in performance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Formerly, in some societies, only men could become actors, and women's roles were generally played by men or boys
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When used for the stage, women occasionally played the roles of prepubescent boys
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accra  is the capital and most populous city of Ghana, with an estimated urban population of 2
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
27 million as of 2012
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is also the capital of the Greater Accra Region and of the Accra Metropolis District, with which it is conterminous
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accra is furthermore the anchor of a larger metropolitan area, the Greater Accra Metropolitan Area (GAMA), which is inhabited by about 4 million people and is the thirteenth-largest metropolitan area in Africa
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accra stretches along the Ghanaian Atlantic coast and extends north inland
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Originally built around three different settlements, including a port (Jamestown), it served as the capital of the British Gold Coast between 1877 and 1957
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Once merely a 19th-century suburb of Victoriaborg, Accra has since transitioned into a modern metropolis; the city's architecture reflects this history, ranging from 19th-century architecture buildings to modern skyscrapers and apartment blocks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accra serves as the Greater Accra Region's economic and administrative hub
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is furthermore a centre of a wide range of nightclubs, restaurants and hotels
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Since the early 1990s, a number of new buildings have been built, including the multi-storey French-owned Novotel hotel
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The city's National Theatre was built with Chinese assistance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2010, the Globalization and World Cities Research Network think tank designated Accra a Gamma-minus-level world city, indicating a growing level of international influence and connectedness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Greater Accra region is the most urbanized region in the country with 87
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
4% of its total population living in urban centres
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The central business district of Accra contains the city's main banks and department stores, as well as an area known as the Ministries, where Ghana's government administration is concentrated
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Economic activities in Accra include the financial and commercial sectors, fishing and the manufacture of processed food, lumber, plywood, textiles, clothing and chemicals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Tourism is becoming a thriving source of business for those in arts and crafts, historical sites and local travel and tour agents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Oxford Street in the district of Osu has grown to become the hub of business and night life in Accra
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accreditation is the process in which certification of competency, authority, or credibility is presented
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Organizations that issue credentials or certify third parties against official standards are themselves formally accredited by accreditation bodies (such as UKAS); hence they are sometimes known as "accredited certification bodies"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The accreditation process ensures that their certification practices are acceptable, typically meaning that they are competent to test and certify third parties, behave ethically and employ suitable quality assurance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accreditation is the process in which certification of competency, authority, or credibility is presented
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Organizations that issue credentials or certify third parties against official standards are themselves formally accredited by accreditation bodies (such as UKAS); hence they are sometimes known as "accredited certification bodies"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The accreditation process ensures that their certification practices are acceptable, typically meaning that they are competent to test and certify third parties, behave ethically and employ suitable quality assurance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accreditation is the process in which certification of competency, authority, or credibility is presented
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Organizations that issue credentials or certify third parties against official standards are themselves formally accredited by accreditation bodies (such as UKAS); hence they are sometimes known as "accredited certification bodies"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
