 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An accretionary wedge or accretionary prism forms from sediments accreted onto the non-subducting tectonic plate at a convergent plate boundary
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most of the material in the accretionary wedge consists of marine sediments scraped off from the downgoing slab of oceanic crust, but in some cases the wedge includes the erosional products of volcanic island arcs formed on the overriding plate
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accretive Health is one of the United States' largest hospital revenue cycle management companies and sells this and other finance-related services to the healthcare industry
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The company is located in Chicago, Illinois
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The company provides end-to-end revenue cycle management solutions through proprietary operational processes, host-agnostic technology solutions and centralized shared service operations – capabilities include patient registration, insurance and benefit verification, clinical documentation and coding, billing and follow-up services
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In English history, praemunire or praemunire facias was a 14th-century law which prohibited the assertion or maintenance of papal jurisdiction, imperial or foreign, or some other alien jurisdiction or claim of supremacy in England, against the supremacy of the monarch
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This law was enforced by the writ of praemunire facias, a writ of summons from which the law takes its name
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The name praemunire may denote the statute, the writ, or the offence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Praemunire in classical Latin means to fortify
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In medieval Latin, praemunire was confused with and used for praemonere, to forewarn, as the writ commanded that the sheriff do (facias) warn (praemunire) the summoned person to appear before the Court
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accrual (accumulation) of something is, in finance, the adding together of interest or different investments over a period of time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It holds specific meanings in accounting, where it can refer to accounts on a balance sheet that represent liabilities and non-cash-based assets used in accrual-based accounting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These types of accounts include, among others, accounts payable, accounts receivable, goodwill, deferred tax liability and future interest expense
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Accrual (accumulation) of something is, in finance, the adding together of interest or different investments over a period of time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It holds specific meanings in accounting, where it can refer to accounts on a balance sheet that represent liabilities and non-cash-based assets used in accrual-based accounting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These types of accounts include, among others, accounts payable, accounts receivable, goodwill, deferred tax liability and future interest expense
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acculturation is the process of social, psychological, and cultural change that stems from blending between cultures
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The effects of acculturation can be seen at multiple levels in both the original (native) and newly adopted (host) cultures
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Historically speaking, acculturation is a direct change of one's culture through dominance over another's culture through either military or political conquest
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At this group level, acculturation often results in changes to culture, customs, religious practices, diet, healthcare, and other social institutions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some of the most noticeable group level effects of acculturation often include changes in food, clothing, and language
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At the individual level, the process of acculturation refers to the socialization process by which foreign-born individuals adopt the values, customs, norms, attitudes, and behaviors of the dominant host culture
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This process has been linked to changes in daily behavior, as well as numerous changes in psychological and physical well-being
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As enculturation is used to describe the process of first-culture learning, acculturation can be thought of as second-culture learning
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Since approximately one in four children in the United States live with at least one immigrant parent, this topic is worthy of understanding and discussing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Scholars in different disciplines have developed more than 100 different theories of acculturation, but the concept of acculturation has only been studied scientifically since 1918
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As it has been approached at different times from the fields of psychology, anthropology, and sociology, numerous theories and definitions have emerged to describe elements of the acculturative process
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Despite definitions and evidence that acculturation entails a two-way process of change, research and theory have primarily focused on the adjustments and adaptations made by minorities such as immigrants, refugees, and indigenous peoples in response to their contact with the dominant majority
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Contemporary research has primarily focused on different strategies of acculturation, how variations in acculturation affect individuals, and interventions to make this process easier
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The nucleus accumbens (NAc or NAcc), also known as the accumbens nucleus or as the nucleus accumbens septi (Latin for nucleus adjacent to the septum) is a region in the basal forebrain rostral to the preoptic area of the hypothalamus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The nucleus accumbens and the olfactory tubercle collectively form the ventral striatum, which is part of the striatum the main component of the basal ganglia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The dopaminergic neurons of the mesolimbic pathway project onto the GABAergic medium spiny neurons of the nucleus accumbens and olfactory tubercle
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Each cerebral hemisphere has its own nucleus accumbens, which can be divided into two structures: the nucleus accumbens core and the nucleus accumbens shell
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These substructures have different morphology and functions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Different NAcc subregions (core vs shell) and neuron subpopulations within each region (D1-type vs D2-type medium spiny neurons) are responsible for different cognitive functions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a whole, the nucleus accumbens has a significant role in the cognitive processing of aversion, motivation, reward (i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, incentive salience, pleasure, and positive reinforcement), and reinforcement learning; hence, it has a significant role in addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It plays a lesser role in processing fear (a form of aversion), impulsivity, and the placebo effect
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is involved in the encoding of new motor programs as well
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Precision is a description of random errors, a measure of statistical variability
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accuracy has two definitions:
More commonly, it is a description of systematic errors, a measure of statistical bias; as these cause a difference between a result and a "true" value, ISO calls this trueness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Alternatively, ISO defines accuracy as describing a combination of both types of observational error above (random and systematic), so high accuracy requires both high precision and high trueness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In simplest terms, given a set of data points from a series of measurements, the set can be said to be precise if the values are close to the average value of the quantity being measured, while the set can be said to be accurate if the values are close to the true value of the quantity being measured
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The two concepts are independent of each other, so a particular set of data can be said to be either accurate, or precise, or both, or neither
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Precision is a description of random errors, a measure of statistical variability
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Accuracy has two definitions:
More commonly, it is a description of systematic errors, a measure of statistical bias; as these cause a difference between a result and a "true" value, ISO calls this trueness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Alternatively, ISO defines accuracy as describing a combination of both types of observational error above (random and systematic), so high accuracy requires both high precision and high trueness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In simplest terms, given a set of data points from a series of measurements, the set can be said to be precise if the values are close to the average value of the quantity being measured, while the set can be said to be accurate if the values are close to the true value of the quantity being measured
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The two concepts are independent of each other, so a particular set of data can be said to be either accurate, or precise, or both, or neither
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
ACCURATE (A Center for Correct, Usable, Reliable, Auditable, and Transparent Elections) was established in 2005 by a group of computer scientists, psychologists and policy experts to address problems with electronic voting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The NSF-funded organization seeks to provide fundamental research and reference materials about electronic voting for use by policy makers, vendors, the elections community and the general public
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ronan the Accuser () is a fictional character appearing in American comic books published by Marvel Comics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He is a judicial officer of the fictional alien race known as the Kree
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Though usually portrayed as a supervillain, he is sometimes depicted as a more noble and honorable character
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Ronan has appeared in various forms of media, including several animated television series and video games
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most notably, actor Lee Pace played the character in the 2014 Marvel Cinematic Universe film Guardians of the Galaxy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The accusative case (abbreviated acc) of a noun is the grammatical case used to mark the direct object of a transitive verb
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The same case is used in many languages for the objects of (some or all) prepositions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a noun that is having something done to it, usually used together (such as in Latin) with the nominative case
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, "they" in English is nominative; "them" is accusative
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The sentence "They like them" shows the nominative case and accusative case working in conjunction using the same base word
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The syntactic functions of the accusative consist of designating the immediate object of an action, the intended result, the goal of a motion, and the extent of an action
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The accusative case existed in Proto-Indo-European and is present in some Indo-European languages (including Latin, Sanskrit, Greek, German, Icelandic, Bulgarian, Polish, Czech, Serbian, Romanian, Russian, Ukrainian), in the Uralic languages, in Altaic languages and in Semitic languages (such as Hebrew and Classical Arabic)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Finnic languages, such as Finnish and Estonian, have two cases to mark objects, the accusative and the partitive case
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In morphosyntactic alignment terms, both perform the accusative function, but the accusative object is telic, while the partitive is not
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Modern English, which almost entirely lacks declension in its nouns, does not have an explicitly marked accusative case even in the pronouns
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Such forms as whom, them, and her derive rather from the old Germanic dative forms, of which the -m and -r endings are characteristic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This conflation of the old accusative, dative, and (after prepositions) genitive cases is the oblique case
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most modern English grammarians no longer use the Latin accusative/dative model, though they tend to use the terms objective for oblique, subjective for nominative, and possessive for genitive (see declension in English)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hine, a true accusative masculine third person singular pronoun, is attested in some northern English dialects as late as the 19th century
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Laya Joneydi (Persian: لعیا جنیدی‎‎) is an Iranian lawyer and associate professor of private law at University of Tehran who is currently serving as the vice president for legal affairs in the administration of President Hassan Rouhani
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

From 2002 to 2003, she worked on research "A Comparative Study of Commercial Arbitration in Islamic Law and Other Major Contemporary Legal Systems" at Harvard Law School
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Niklas Frank (born 9 March 1939) is a German author and journalist best known for an intimate and strongly accusatory book about his father, Hans Frank, the Nazi lawyer who became Governor-General of occupied Poland during World War II
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me is a 1992 psychological horror film directed by David Lynch and written by Lynch and Robert Engels
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a prequel to the television series Twin Peaks (1990–91), created by Mark Frost and Lynch, who were also executive producers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film revolves around the investigation into the murder of Teresa Banks (Pamela Gidley) and the last seven days in the life of Laura Palmer (Sheryl Lee), a popular high school student in the fictional Washington town of Twin Peaks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Most of the television cast returned for the film, with the notable exceptions of Lara Flynn Boyle, who declined to return as Laura's best friend Donna Hayward (she was replaced by Moira Kelly); and Sherilyn Fenn, owing to scheduling conflicts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Kyle MacLachlan, who starred as Special Agent Dale Cooper in the TV series, was reluctant to return out of fear of getting typecast, so his presence in the film is smaller than originally planned
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Although it has long been reported that Fire Walk with Me was greeted at the 1992 Cannes Film Festival with booing and jeers from the audience, co-writer Robert Engels denies that this event ever happened
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film initially received negative reviews in the United States but has been met with a more positive reception in subsequent years, with some viewing it as one of Lynch's major works
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film fared poorly in the United States at the box office, although it was a commercial hit in Japan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"I've Grown Accustomed to Her Face" is a song from the 1956 musical My Fair Lady, with music by Frederick Loewe and lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was originally performed by Rex Harrison as Professor Henry Higgins
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He also performed in the 1964 film version
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The song expresses Professor Henry Higgins's rage at the fact that his pupil Eliza Doolittle has chosen to walk out of his life, and his growing realization of how much he will miss her
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An ace is a playing card
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the standard French deck, an ace has a single suit symbol (a heart, diamond, spade, or club) located in the middle of the card, sometimes large and decorated, especially in the case of the ace of spades
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This embellishment on the ace of spades started when King James VI of Scotland and I of England required an insignia of the printing house to be printed on the ace of spades
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This insignia was necessary for identifying the printing house and stamping it as having paid the new stamp tax
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although this requirement was abolished in 1960, the tradition has been kept by many card makers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In other countries the stamp and embellishments are usually found on ace cards; clubs in France, diamonds in Russia, and hearts in Genoa because they have the most blank space
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The word "ace" comes from the Old French word as (from Latin 'as') meaning 'a unit', from the name of a small Roman coin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It originally meant the side of a die with only one pip, before it was a term for a playing card
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Since this was the lowest roll of the die, it traditionally meant 'bad luck' in Middle English, but as the ace is often the highest playing card, its meaning has since changed to mean 'high-quality, excellence'
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acebutolol (trade names Sectral, Prent) is a beta blocker for the treatment of hypertension and arrhythmias
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aceldama, Akeldama or Hakeldama (Aramaic: חקל דמא; field of blood) is the Aramaic name for a place in Jerusalem associated with Judas Iscariot, one of the followers of Jesus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acetic acid , systematically named ethanoic acid , is a colourless liquid organic compound with the chemical formula CH3COOH (also written as CH3CO2H or C2H4O2)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When undiluted, it is sometimes called glacial acetic acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Vinegar is roughly 3–9% acetic acid by volume, making acetic acid the main component of vinegar apart from water
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acetic acid has a distinctive sour taste and pungent smell
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In addition to household vinegar, it is mainly produced as a precursor to polyvinyl acetate and cellulose acetate
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is classified as a weak acid since it only partially dissociates in solution, but concentrated acetic acid is corrosive and can attack the skin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acetic acid is the second simplest carboxylic acid (after formic acid)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It consists of a methyl group attached to a carboxyl group
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is an important chemical reagent and industrial chemical, used primarily in the production of cellulose acetate for photographic film, polyvinyl acetate for wood glue, and synthetic fibres and fabrics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In households, diluted acetic acid is often used in descaling agents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the food industry, acetic acid is controlled by the food additive code E260 as an acidity regulator and as a condiment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a food additive it is approved for usage in many countries, including Canada, the European Union, the United States, Australia and New Zealand
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In biochemistry, the acetyl group, derived from acetic acid, is fundamental to all forms of life
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When bound to coenzyme A, it is central to the metabolism of carbohydrates and fats
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The global demand for acetic acid is about 6
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5 million metric tons per year (Mt/a), of which approximately 1
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5 Mt/a is met by recycling; the remainder is manufactured from methanol
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Vinegar is mostly dilute acetic acid, often produced by fermentation and subsequent oxidation of ethanol
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Twin Reversed Arterial Perfusion sequence—also called TRAP sequence, TRAPS, or acardiac twinning—is a rare complication of monochorionic twin pregnancies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a severe variant of twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome (TTTS)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The twins' blood systems are connected instead of independent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 One twin, called the acardiac twin or TRAP fetus, is severely malformed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The heart is missing or deformed, hence the name acardiac, as are the upper structures of the body 
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The legs may be partially present or missing, and internal structures of the torso are often poorly formed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The other twin is usually normal in appearance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The normal twin, called the pump twin, drives blood through both fetuses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is called reversed arterial perfusion because in the acardiac twin the blood flows in a reversed direction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

TRAP sequence occurs in 1% of monochorionic twin pregnancies and in 1 in 35,000 pregnancies overall
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acequia (Spanish: [aˈθekja]) or séquia (Valencian: [ˈsɛkia]) is a community-operated watercourse used in Spain and former Spanish colonies in the Americas for irrigation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Particularly in Spain, the Andes, northern Mexico, and the modern-day American Southwest, acequias are usually historically engineered canals that carry snow runoff or river water to distant fields
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can also refer to the long central pool in a Moorish garden, such as the Generalife in the Alhambra in Southern Iberia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aceraceae were recognized as a family of flowering plants also called the maple family
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They contain two to four genera, depending upon the circumscription, of some 120 species of trees and shrubs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A common characteristic is that the leaves are opposite, and the fruit a schizocarp
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The maples have long been known to be closely related to the family Sapindaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Several taxonomists (including the Angiosperm Phylogeny Group) now include both the Aceraceae and the Hippocastanaceae in the Sapindaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Recent research (Harrington et al
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 2005) has shown that while both Aceraceae and Hippocastanaceae are monophyletic in themselves, their removal from Sapindaceae sensu lato would leave Sapindaceae sensu stricto as a paraphyletic group, particularly with reference to the genus Xanthoceras
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acetate  is a salt formed by the combination of acetic acid with an alkaline, earthy, or metallic base
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "Acetate" also describes the conjugate base or ion (specifically, the negatively charged ion called an anion) typically found in aqueous solution and written with the chemical formula C2H3O2−
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The neutral molecules formed by the combination of the acetate ion and a positive ion (called a cation) are also commonly called "acetates" (hence, acetate of lead, acetate of aluminum, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The simplest of these is hydrogen acetate (called acetic acid) with corresponding salts, esters, and the polyatomic anion CH3CO2−, or CH3COO−
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Most of the approximately 5 billion kilograms of acetic acid produced annually in industry is used in the production of acetates, which usually take the form of polymers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In nature, acetate is the most common building block for biosynthesis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, the fatty acids are produced by connecting the two carbon atoms from acetate to a growing fatty acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acetate  is a salt formed by the combination of acetic acid with an alkaline, earthy, or metallic base
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "Acetate" also describes the conjugate base or ion (specifically, the negatively charged ion called an anion) typically found in aqueous solution and written with the chemical formula C2H3O2−
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, the fatty acids are produced by connecting the two carbon atoms from acetate to a growing fatty acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Luis Sales (1745–1807) served as a Dominican missionary in Baja California, Mexico, between 1773 and 1790
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He is most notable for three long letters in which he described the history of the peninsula and the lifeways of the native peoples in its northwestern region
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Malpighia emarginata is a tropical fruit-bearing shrub or small tree in the family Malpighiaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Common names include acerola (Spanish pronunciation: [aseˈɾola], Brazilian Portuguese pronunciation [aseˈɾɔlɐ], European Portuguese pronunciation [ɐseˈɾɔlɐ]), Barbados cherry, West Indian cherry, wild crepe myrtle and Seriz (Haitian Creole)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acerola is native to South America, southern Mexico, Puerto Rico, Dominican Republic, Haiti, Brazil, and Central America, but is now also being grown as far north as Texas and in subtropical areas of Asia, such as India
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

It is known for being extremely rich in vitamin C, almost as much as camu camu, although it also contains vitamins A, B1, B2, and B3, as well as carotenoids and bioflavonoids, which provide important nutritive value and have antioxidant uses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acetate  is a salt formed by the combination of acetic acid with an alkaline, earthy, or metallic base
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "Acetate" also describes the conjugate base or ion (specifically, the negatively charged ion called an anion) typically found in aqueous solution and written with the chemical formula C2H3O2−
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The neutral molecules formed by the combination of the acetate ion and a positive ion (called a cation) are also commonly called "acetates" (hence, acetate of lead, acetate of aluminum, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The simplest of these is hydrogen acetate (called acetic acid) with corresponding salts, esters, and the polyatomic anion CH3CO2−, or CH3COO−
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Most of the approximately 5 billion kilograms of acetic acid produced annually in industry is used in the production of acetates, which usually take the form of polymers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In nature, acetate is the most common building block for biosynthesis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, the fatty acids are produced by connecting the two carbon atoms from acetate to a growing fatty acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Activation in (bio-)chemical sciences generally refers to the process whereby something is prepared or excited for a subsequent reaction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acervulus (pl
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 acervuli) is a small asexual fruiting body that erupts through the epidermis of host plants parasitised by mitosporic fungi of the form order Melanconiales (Deuteromycota, Coelomycetes)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It has the form of a small cushion at the bottom of which short crowded conidiophores are formed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The spores escape through an opening at the top
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acervus is a genus of fungi in the family Pyronemataceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They have cup-shaped fruitbodies that may be up to 1
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5 cm (0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
6 in) in diameter, with a bright yellow to orange-colored hymenium
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Fruitbodies occur on soil, duff, and plant debris
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Six of the seven species in the genus are found in China
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The acetabulum  (cotyloid cavity) is a concave surface of the pelvis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The head of the femur meets with the pelvis at the acetabulum, forming the hip joint
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The acetabulum  (cotyloid cavity) is a concave surface of the pelvis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The head of the femur meets with the pelvis at the acetabulum, forming the hip joint
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acetal is a functional group with the following connectivity R2C(OR')2, where both R' groups are organic fragments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The central carbon atom has four bonds to it, and is therefore saturated and has tetrahedral geometry
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The two R'O groups may be equivalent to each other or not
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The two R groups can be equivalent to each other (a "symmetric acetal") or not (a "mixed acetal"), and one or both can even be hydrogen atoms rather than organic fragments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acetals are formed from and convertible to carbonyl compounds (aldehydes or ketones R2C=O)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term ketal is sometimes used to identify structures associated with ketones rather than aldehydes and, historically, the term acetal was used specifically for the aldehyde cases
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Formation of an acetal occurs when the hydroxyl group of a hemiacetal becomes protonated and is lost as water
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The carbocation that is produced is then rapidly attacked by a molecule of alcohol
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Loss of the proton from the attached alcohol gives the acetal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


Acetals are stable compared to hemiacetals but their formation is a reversible equilibrium as with esters
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a reaction to create an acetal proceeds, water must be removed from the reaction mixture, for example, with a Dean-Stark apparatus, lest it will hydrolyse the product back to the hemiacetal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The formation of acetals reduces the total number of molecules present and therefore is not favourable with regards to entropy, unless one uses a diol rather than two discrete alcohol molecules
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A way to improve this is to use an orthoester as a source of alcohol
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aldehydes and ketones undergo a process called acetal exchange with orthoesters to give acetals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Water produced along with the acetal product is used up in hydrolysing the orthoester and producing more alcohol to be used in the reaction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acetals are used as protecting groups for carbonyl groups in organic synthesis because they are stable with respect to hydrolysis by bases and with respect to many oxidizing and reducing agents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They can either protect the carbonyl in a molecule (by temporarily reacting it with an alcohol) or a diol (by temporarily reacting it with a carbonyl)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 That is, either the carbonyl, or the alcohols, or both could be part of the molecule whose reactivity is to be controlled
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Various specific carbonyl compounds have special names for their acetal forms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, an acetal formed from formaldehyde is sometimes called a "formal" or the methylenedioxy group
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The acetal formed from acetone is sometimes called an acetonide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acetaldehyde (systematic name ethanal) is an organic chemical compound with the formula CH3CHO, sometimes abbreviated by chemists as MeCHO (Me = methyl)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is one of the most important aldehydes, occurring widely in nature and being produced on a large scale in industry
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acetaldehyde occurs naturally in coffee, bread, and ripe fruit, and is produced by plants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is also produced by the partial oxidation of alcohol (also known formally as ethanol) by the liver enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase and may be a contributing factor to hangovers from alcohol consumption
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Pathways of exposure include air, water, land, or groundwater, as well as drink and smoke
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Consumption of disulfiram inhibits acetaldehyde dehydrogenase, the enzyme responsible for the metabolism of acetaldehyde, thereby causing it to build up in the body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) has listed acetaldehyde as a Group 1 carcinogen
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acetaldehyde is "one of the most frequently found air toxins with cancer risk greater than one in a million"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acetamide (systematic name: ethanamide) is an organic compound with the formula CH3CONH2
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is the simplest amide derived from acetic acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It finds some use as a plasticizer and as an industrial solvent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The related compound N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMA) is more widely used, but it is not prepared from acetamide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Paracetamol, also known as acetaminophen or APAP, is a medication used to treat pain and fever
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is typically used for mild to moderate pain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The quality of the evidence regarding the use for fever relief in children is poor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is often sold in combination with other ingredients such as in many cold medications
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In combination with opioid pain medication, paracetamol is also used for more severe pain such as cancer pain and after surgery
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is typically used either by mouth or rectally but is also available intravenously
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Effects last between two and four hours
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Paracetamol is generally safe at recommended doses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Serious skin rashes may rarely occur, and too high a dose can result in liver failure
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It appears to be safe during pregnancy and when breastfeeding
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In those with liver disease, it may still be used, but in lower doses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Paracetamol is classified as a mild analgesic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It does not have significant anti-inflammatory activity and how it works is not entirely clear
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Paracetamol was discovered in 1877
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is the most commonly used medication for pain and fever in both the United States and Europe
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is on the World Health Organization's List of Essential Medicines, the most effective and safe medicines needed in a health system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Paracetamol is available as a generic medication with trade names including Tylenol and Panadol among others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The wholesale price in the developing world is less than 0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
01 USD per dose
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the United States it costs about 0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
04 USD per dose
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acetanilide is an odourless solid chemical of leaf or flake-like appearance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is also known as N-phenylacetamide, acetanil, or acetanilid, and was formerly known by the trade name Antifebrin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acetate  is a salt formed by the combination of acetic acid with an alkaline, earthy, or metallic base
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "Acetate" also describes the conjugate base or ion (specifically, the negatively charged ion called an anion) typically found in aqueous solution and written with the chemical formula C2H3O2−
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The neutral molecules formed by the combination of the acetate ion and a positive ion (called a cation) are also commonly called "acetates" (hence, acetate of lead, acetate of aluminum, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The simplest of these is hydrogen acetate (called acetic acid) with corresponding salts, esters, and the polyatomic anion CH3CO2−, or CH3COO−
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Most of the approximately 5 billion kilograms of acetic acid produced annually in industry is used in the production of acetates, which usually take the form of polymers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In nature, acetate is the most common building block for biosynthesis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, the fatty acids are produced by connecting the two carbon atoms from acetate to a growing fatty acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acetic acid , systematically named ethanoic acid , is a colourless liquid organic compound with the chemical formula CH3COOH (also written as CH3CO2H or C2H4O2)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When undiluted, it is sometimes called glacial acetic acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Vinegar is roughly 3–9% acetic acid by volume, making acetic acid the main component of vinegar apart from water
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acetic acid has a distinctive sour taste and pungent smell
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In addition to household vinegar, it is mainly produced as a precursor to polyvinyl acetate and cellulose acetate
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is classified as a weak acid since it only partially dissociates in solution, but concentrated acetic acid is corrosive and can attack the skin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acetic acid is the second simplest carboxylic acid (after formic acid)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It consists of a methyl group attached to a carboxyl group
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is an important chemical reagent and industrial chemical, used primarily in the production of cellulose acetate for photographic film, polyvinyl acetate for wood glue, and synthetic fibres and fabrics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In households, diluted acetic acid is often used in descaling agents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the food industry, acetic acid is controlled by the food additive code E260 as an acidity regulator and as a condiment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a food additive it is approved for usage in many countries, including Canada, the European Union, the United States, Australia and New Zealand
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In biochemistry, the acetyl group, derived from acetic acid, is fundamental to all forms of life
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When bound to coenzyme A, it is central to the metabolism of carbohydrates and fats
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The global demand for acetic acid is about 6
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5 million metric tons per year (Mt/a), of which approximately 1
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5 Mt/a is met by recycling; the remainder is manufactured from methanol
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Vinegar is mostly dilute acetic acid, often produced by fermentation and subsequent oxidation of ethanol
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acetone (systematically named propanone) is the organic compound with the formula (CH3)2CO
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a colorless, volatile, flammable liquid, and is the simplest ketone
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acetone is miscible with water and serves as an important solvent in its own right, typically for cleaning purposes in the laboratory
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 About 6
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
7 million tonnes were produced worldwide in 2010, mainly for use as a solvent and production of methyl methacrylate and bisphenol A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a common building block in organic chemistry
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Familiar household uses of acetone are as the active ingredient in nail polish remover, and as paint thinner
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acetone is produced and disposed of in the human body through normal metabolic processes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is normally present in blood and urine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 People with diabetes produce it in larger amounts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Reproductive toxicity tests show that it has low potential to cause reproductive problems
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Pregnant women, nursing mothers and children have higher levels of acetone
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Ketogenic diets that increase acetone in the body are used to counter epileptic attacks in infants and children who suffer from recalcitrant refractory epilepsy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Phenacetin (or acetophenetidin) is a pain-relieving and fever-reducing drug, which was widely used between its introduction in 1887 and the 1983 ban imposed by the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Food and Drug Administration
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In organic chemistry, acetyl is a moiety, the acyl with chemical formula CH3CO
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is sometimes represented by the symbol Ac (not to be confused with the element actinium)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The acetyl group contains a methyl group single-bonded to a carbonyl
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The carbonyl center of an acyl radical has one nonbonded electron with which it forms a chemical bond to the remainder R of the molecule
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In IUPAC nomenclature, acetyl is called ethanoyl, although this term is rarely heard
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The acetyl moiety is a component of many organic compounds, including acetic acid, the neurotransmitter acetylcholine, acetyl-CoA, acetylcysteine, and the analgesics acetaminophen (also known as paracetamol) and acetylsalicylic acid (better known as aspirin)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acetylcholine (ACh) is an organic chemical that functions in the brain and body of many types of animals, including humans, as a neurotransmitter—a chemical released by nerve cells to send signals to other cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its name is derived from its chemical structure: it is an ester of acetic acid and choline
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Parts in the body that use or are affected by acetylcholine are referred to as cholinergic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Substances that interfere with acetylcholine activity are called anticholinergics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acetylcholine is the neurotransmitter used at the neuromuscular junction—in other words, it is the chemical that motor neurons of the nervous system release in order to activate muscles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This property means that drugs that affect cholinergic systems can have very dangerous effects ranging from paralysis to convulsions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acetylcholine is also used as a neurotransmitter in the autonomic nervous system, both as an internal transmitter for the sympathetic nervous system and as the final product released by the parasympathetic nervous system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the brain, acetylcholine functions as a neurotransmitter and as a neuromodulator
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The brain contains a number of cholinergic areas, each with distinct functions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They play an important role in arousal, attention, memory and motivation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Partly because of its muscle-activating function, but also because of its functions in the autonomic nervous system and brain, a large number of important drugs exert their effects by altering cholinergic transmission
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Numerous venoms and toxins produced by plants, animals, and bacteria, as well as chemical nerve agents such as Sarin, cause harm by inactivating or hyperactivating muscles via their influences on the neuromuscular junction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Drugs that act on muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, such as atropine, can be poisonous in large quantities, but in smaller doses they are commonly used to treat certain heart conditions and eye problems
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Scopolamine, which acts mainly on muscarinic receptors in the brain, can cause delirium and amnesia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The addictive qualities of nicotine derive from its effects on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in the brain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acetylene (systematic name: ethyne) is the chemical compound with the formula C2H2
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a hydrocarbon and the simplest alkyne
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This colorless gas is widely used as a fuel and a chemical building block
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is unstable in its pure form and thus is usually handled as a solution
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Pure acetylene is odorless, but commercial grades usually have a marked odor due to impurities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

As an alkyne, acetylene is unsaturated because its two carbon atoms are bonded together in a triple bond
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The carbon–carbon triple bond places all four atoms in the same straight line, with CCH bond angles of 180°
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In organic chemistry, the term acetylenic designates
A doubly unsaturated position (sp-hybridized) on a molecular framework, for instance in an alkyne such as acetylene;
An ethynyl fragment, HC
  
    
      
        ≡
      
    
    {\displaystyle \equiv }
  C-, or substituted homologue
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acharnes (Greek: Αχαρνές, pronounced [axarˈnes], before 1915: Μενίδι Menidi, pronounced [meˈniði]) is a suburban town in Athens, Attica, Greece
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 With 106,943 inhabitants (2011 census), it is the most populous municipality in East Attica
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is part of the Athens Urban area
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Bahar Kimyongür was born 28 April 1974 in Berchem-Sainte-Agathe, Belgium
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He is a Belgian political writer of Arabian extraction, born in Samandağ
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He is perhaps most well known for his repeated arrests and releases on terrorism-related offences in the early twenty-first century
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In Greek and Roman mythology, Achates (Ancient Greek: Ἀχάτης) may refer to the following personages:
Achates, a companion of the exiled Aeneas
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Achates, a Sicilian who came to Aristaeus in order to join Dionysus in his Indian campaign
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An achene (Greek ἀ, a, privative + χαίνειν, chainein, to gape; also sometimes called akene and occasionally achenium or achenocarp) is a type of simple dry fruit produced by many species of flowering plants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Achenes are monocarpellate (formed from one carpel) and indehiscent (they do not open at maturity)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Achenes contain a single seed that nearly fills the pericarp, but does not adhere to it
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In many species, what is called the "seed" is an achene, a fruit containing the seed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The seed-like appearance is owed to the hardening of the wall of the seed-vessel, which encloses the solitary seed so closely as to seem like an outer coat
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Baldellia is a genus of aquatic plants commonly known as lesser water-plantains
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It includes three species found across much of Europe and the Mediterranean from Ireland and the Canary Islands to Turkey and Estonia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The genus is named in honor of the Italian nobleman Bartolomea Bartoloni-Baldelli
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Baldellia is very closely related to Echinodorus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Acheron (; Ancient Greek: Ἀχέρων (Acheron) or Ἀχερούσιος (Acherusius); Modern Greek: Αχέροντας (Acherontas)) is a river located in the Epirus region of northwest Greece
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its source is near the village Zotiko, in the southwestern part of the Ioannina regional unit it flows into the Ionian Sea in Ammoudia, near Parga
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acherontia atropos (Greater death's head hawkmoth) is the most widely known of the three species of death's-head hawkmoth
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acherontia species are notorious for a vaguely skull-shaped pattern on the thorax
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Calliotropis acherontis is a species of sea snail, a marine gastropod mollusk in the family Calliotropidae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acheta is a genus of field crickets
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It most notably contains the house cricket Acheta domestica
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 According to the Code of Zoological Nomenclature, this generic name is feminine in gender
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For this reason, the specific names (epithets) must agree in gender with the generic name, and therefore be written in the feminine gender
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
SMART is a mnemonic acronym, giving criteria to guide in the setting of objectives, for example in project management, employee-performance management and personal development
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The letters S and M usually mean specific and measurable
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Possibly the most common version has the remaining letters referring to achievable, relevant and time-bound
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, the term's inventor had a slightly different version and the letters have meant different things to different authors, as described below
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Additional letters have been added by some authors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The first-known use of the term occurs in the November 1981 issue of Management Review by George T
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Doran
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The principal advantage of SMART objectives is that they are easier to understand and to know when they have been done
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 SMART criteria are commonly associated with Peter Drucker's management by objectives concept
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
SMART is a mnemonic acronym, giving criteria to guide in the setting of objectives, for example in project management, employee-performance management and personal development
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The letters S and M usually mean specific and measurable
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Possibly the most common version has the remaining letters referring to achievable, relevant and time-bound
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, the term's inventor had a slightly different version and the letters have meant different things to different authors, as described below
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Additional letters have been added by some authors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The first-known use of the term occurs in the November 1981 issue of Management Review by George T
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Doran
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The principal advantage of SMART objectives is that they are easier to understand and to know when they have been done
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 SMART criteria are commonly associated with Peter Drucker's management by objectives concept
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Enneagram of Personality, or simply the Enneagram (from the Greek words ἐννέα [ennéa, meaning "nine"] and γράμμα [grámma, meaning something "written" or "drawn"]), is a model of the human psyche which is principally understood and taught as a typology of nine interconnected personality types
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although the origins and history of many of the ideas and theories associated with the Enneagram of Personality are a matter of dispute, contemporary Enneagram understandings are principally derived from the teachings of Oscar Ichazo and Claudio Naranjo
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Naranjo's theories were partly influenced by some earlier teachings of G
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 I
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Gurdjieff
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a typology the Enneagram defines nine personality types (sometimes referred to as "enneatypes"), which are represented by the points of a geometric figure called an enneagram, which, it is believed, also indicate some of the connections between the types
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are different schools of thought among Enneagram teachers, therefore their ideas on some theoretical aspects are not always in agreement
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Enneagram of Personality has been widely promoted in both business management and spiritual contexts through seminars, conferences, books, magazines, and DVDs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In business contexts it is generally used as a typology to gain insights into workplace dynamics; in spirituality it is more commonly presented as a path to higher states of being, essence, and enlightenment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It has been described as a method for self-understanding and self-development
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Achillea  is a group of flowering plants in the family Asteraceae described as a genus by Linnaeus in 1753
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The genus was named after the Greek mythological character Achilles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 According to legend, Achilles' soldiers used yarrow to treat their wounds, hence some of its common names such as allheal and bloodwort
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The genus is native primarily to Europe, temperate areas of Asia, and North America
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The common name "yarrow" is usually applied to Achillea millefolium, but may also be used for other species within the genus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

These plants typically have frilly, hairy, aromatic leaves
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The plants show large, flat clusters of small flowers at the top of the stem
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The flowers can be white, yellow, orange, pink or red and are generally visited by many insects, and are thus characterised by a generalised pollination system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Achillea species are used as food plants by the larvae of some Lepidoptera species - see list of Lepidoptera that feed on Achillea
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
