 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acneiform eruptions are a group of dermatoses including acne vulgaris, rosacea, folliculitis, and perioral dermatitis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Restated, acneiform eruptions are follicular eruptions characterized by papules and pustules resembling acne
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The hybrid term acneiform, literally, refers to an appearance similar to acne
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The terminology used in this field can be complex, and occasionally contradictory
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some sources consider acne vulgaris part of the differential diagnosis for an acneiform eruption
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other sources classified acne vulgaris under acneiform eruption
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 MeSH explicitly excludes perioral dermatitis from the category of "acneiform eruptions", though it does group acneiform eruptions and perioral dermatitis together under "facial dermatoses"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acianthera is a genus of orchids native to the tropical parts of the Western Hemisphere, especially Brazil
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was first described in 1842 but was not widely recognized until recently
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most of the species formerly placed under Pleurothallis subgenus Acianthera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This splitting is a result of recent DNA sequencing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acolyte is an assistant or follower assisting the celebrant in a religious service or procession
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In many Christian denominations, an acolyte is anyone who performs ceremonial duties such as lighting altar candles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In others, the term is used for one who has been inducted into a particular liturgical ministry, even when not performing those duties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acolyte is an assistant or follower assisting the celebrant in a religious service or procession
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In many Christian denominations, an acolyte is anyone who performs ceremonial duties such as lighting altar candles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In others, the term is used for one who has been inducted into a particular liturgical ministry, even when not performing those duties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acacia, commonly known as the wattles or acacias, is a large genus of shrubs and trees in the subfamily Mimosoideae of the pea family Fabaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Initially it comprised a group of plant species native to Africa and Australia, with the first species A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 nilotica described by Linnaeus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Controversy erupted in the early 2000s when it became evident that the genus as it stood was not monophyletic, and that several divergent lineages needed to be placed in separate genera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It turned out that one lineage comprising over 900 species mainly native to Australia was not closely related to the mainly African lineage that contained A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 nilotica—the first and type species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This meant that the Australian lineage (by far the most prolific in number of species) would need to be renamed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Botanist Les Pedley named this group Racosperma, which was inconsistently adopted
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Australian botanists proposed that this would be more disruptive than setting a different type species (A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 penninervis) and allowing this large number of species to remain Acacia, resulting in the two African lineages being renamed Vachellia and Senegalia, and the two New World lineages renamed Acaciella and Mariosousa
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This was officially adopted, but many botanists from Africa and elsewhere disagreed that this was necessary
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A number of species have been introduced to various parts of the world, and two million hectares of commercial plantations have been established
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The heterogeneous group varies considerably in habit, from mat-like subshrubs to canopy trees in forest
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aconcagua (Spanish pronunciation: [akoŋˈkaɣwa]) is the highest mountain outside Asia, at 6,961 metres (22,838 ft), and by extension the highest point in both the Western Hemisphere and the Southern Hemisphere
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is located in the Andes mountain range, in the Mendoza Province, Argentina, and lies 112 kilometres (70 mi) northwest of its capital, the city of Mendoza
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The summit is also located about five kilometres from San Juan Province and 15 kilometres from the international border with Chile
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The mountain itself lies entirely within Argentina and immediately east of Argentina's border with Chile
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its nearest higher neighbor is Tirich Mir in the Hindu Kush, 16,520 kilometres (10,270 mi) away
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is one of the Seven Summits
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Aconcagua is bounded by the Valle de las Vacas to the north and east and the Valle de los Horcones Inferior to the west and south
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The mountain and its surroundings are part of the Aconcagua Provincial Park
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The mountain has a number of glaciers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The largest glacier is the Ventisquero Horcones Inferior at about 10 kilometres long, which descends from the south face to about 3600 metres in altitude near the Confluencia camp
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Two other large glacier systems are the Ventisquero de las Vacas Sur and Glaciar Este/Ventisquero Relinchos system at about 5 kilometres long
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The most well-known is the north-eastern or Polish Glacier, as it is a common route of ascent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aconitum (), commonly known as aconite, monkshood, wolf's bane, leopard's bane, mousebane, women's bane, devil's helmet, queen of poisons, or blue rocket, is a genus of over 250 species of flowering plants belonging to the family Ranunculaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These herbaceous perennial plants are chiefly native to the mountainous parts of the Northern Hemisphere, growing in the moisture-retentive but well-draining soils of mountain meadows
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most species are extremely poisonous and must be dealt with carefully
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acorus calamus (also called sweet flag or calamus, among many common names) is a tall perennial wetland monocot of the Acoraceae family, in the genus Acorus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acraea (Ancient Greek: Ἀκραία) was a name that had several uses in Greek and Roman mythology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acraea was a daughter of the river-god Asterion near Mycenae, who together with her sisters Euboea and Prosymna (Πρόσυμνα) acted as nurses to Hera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A hill Acraea opposite the temple of Hera near Mycenae derived its name from her
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acraea and Acraeus are also epithets given to various goddesses and gods whose temples were situated upon hills, such as Zeus, Hera, Aphrodite, Pallas, Artemis, and others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The acorn, or oak nut, is the nut of the oaks and their close relatives (genera Quercus and Lithocarpus, in the family Fagaceae)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It usually contains a single seed (occasionally two seeds), enclosed in a tough, leathery shell, and borne in a cup-shaped cupule
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acorns are 1–6 cm (0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
39–2
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
36 in) long and 0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
8–4 cm (0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
31–1
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
57 in) broad
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acorns take between 6 and 24 months (depending on the species) to mature; see List of Quercus species for details of oak classification, in which acorn morphology and phenology are important factors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acorus is a genus of monocot flowering plants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This genus was once placed within the family Araceae (aroids), but more recent classifications place it in its own family Acoraceae and order Acorales, of which it is the sole genus of the oldest surviving line of monocots
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some older studies indicated that it was placed in a lineage (the order Alismatales), that also includes aroids (Araceae), Tofieldiaceae, and several families of aquatic monocots (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, Alismataceae, Posidoniaceae)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, modern phylogenetic studies demonstrate that Acorus is sister to all other monocots
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Common names include calamus and sweet flag
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The genus is native to North America and northern and eastern Asia, and naturalised in southern Asia and Europe from ancient cultivation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The known wild populations are diploid except for some tetraploids in eastern Asia, while the cultivated plants are sterile triploids, probably of hybrid origin between the diploid and tetraploid forms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acosta is a Spanish and Portuguese surname
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Originally it was used to refer to a person who lived by the seashore or from the mountains (encostas)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It comes from the Portuguese da Costa (cognate of English "coast"), which in Spanish became de Acosta
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acoustically is the fourth studio album by ARIA Award winning, Torres Strait Islander singer Christine Anu
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The album sees Anu perform acoustic versions of her hits as well as show cashing new material, including "Last to go", a song dedicated to a friend lost in Bali, and "Ocean of Regret", a Neil Murray composition originally demoed for her landmark debut Stylin' Up
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
  It was released in 2005 on the Liberation Blue label
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acoustics is the interdisciplinary science that deals with the study of all mechanical waves in gases, liquids, and solids including topics such as vibration, sound, ultrasound and infrasound
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A scientist who works in the field of acoustics is an acoustician while someone working in the field of acoustics technology may be called an acoustical engineer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The application of acoustics is present in almost all aspects of modern society with the most obvious being the audio and noise control industries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Hearing is one of the most crucial means of survival in the animal world, and speech is one of the most distinctive characteristics of human development and culture
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accordingly, the science of acoustics spreads across many facets of human society—music, medicine, architecture, industrial production, warfare and more
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Likewise, animal species such as songbirds and frogs use sound and hearing as a key element of mating rituals or marking territories
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Art, craft, science and technology have provoked one another to advance the whole, as in many other fields of knowledge
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Robert Bruce Lindsay's 'Wheel of Acoustics' is a well accepted overview of the various fields in acoustics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The word "acoustic" is derived from the Greek word ἀκουστικός (akoustikos), meaning "of or for hearing, ready to hear" and that from ἀκουστός (akoustos), "heard, audible", which in turn derives from the verb ἀκούω (akouo), "I hear"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Latin synonym is "sonic", after which the term sonics used to be a synonym for acoustics and later a branch of acoustics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Frequencies above and below the audible range are called "ultrasonic" and "infrasonic", respectively
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acoustics is the interdisciplinary science that deals with the study of all mechanical waves in gases, liquids, and solids including topics such as vibration, sound, ultrasound and infrasound
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A scientist who works in the field of acoustics is an acoustician while someone working in the field of acoustics technology may be called an acoustical engineer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The application of acoustics is present in almost all aspects of modern society with the most obvious being the audio and noise control industries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"Acquainted" is a song by Canadian singer The Weeknd recorded for his second studio album Beauty Behind the Madness (2015)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was written and produced by him along with Jason "DaHeala" Quenneville, Danny "Boy Styles" Schofield, Carlos "Illangelo" Montagnese and Ben "Billions" Diehl
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The track was sent to urban contemporary stations on November 17, 2015, by XO and Republic Records, serving as the record's fourth and final single (fifth overall), being also released to rhythmic contemporary on February 16, 2016
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was set to impact contemporary hit radio on April 12, 2016, though its release to those stations did not occur
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An interpersonal relationship is a strong, deep, or close association or acquaintance between two or more people that may range in duration from brief to enduring
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This association may be based on inference, love, solidarity, regular business interactions, or some other type of social commitment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Interpersonal relationships are formed in the context of social, cultural and other influences
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The context can and may and perhaps will vary from family or kinship relations, friendship, marriage, relations with associates, work, clubs, neighborhoods, and places of worship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They may be regulated by law, custom, or mutual agreement, and are the basis of social groups and society as a whole
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"Acquainted" is a song by Canadian singer The Weeknd recorded for his second studio album Beauty Behind the Madness (2015)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was written and produced by him along with Jason "DaHeala" Quenneville, Danny "Boy Styles" Schofield, Carlos "Illangelo" Montagnese and Ben "Billions" Diehl
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The track was sent to urban contemporary stations on November 17, 2015, by XO and Republic Records, serving as the record's fourth and final single (fifth overall), being also released to rhythmic contemporary on February 16, 2016
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was set to impact contemporary hit radio on April 12, 2016, though its release to those stations did not occur
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Percy Bysshe Shelley (; 4 August 1792 – 8 July 1822) was one of the major English Romantic poets, and is regarded by some as among the finest lyric poets in the English language, and one of the most influential
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A radical in his poetry as well as in his political and social views, Shelley did not see fame during his lifetime, but recognition for his poetry grew steadily following his death
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Shelley was a key member of a close circle of visionary poets and writers that included Lord Byron, Leigh Hunt, Thomas Love Peacock, and his own second wife, Mary Shelley, the author of Frankenstein
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Shelley is perhaps best known for classic poems such as Ozymandias, Ode to the West Wind, To a Skylark, Music, When Soft Voices Die, The Cloud and The Masque of Anarchy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His other major works include a groundbreaking verse drama The Cenci (1819) and long, visionary poems such as Queen Mab (later reworked as The Daemon of the World), Alastor, The Revolt of Islam, Adonaïs, Prometheus Unbound (1820)—widely considered to be his masterpiece—Hellas: A Lyrical Drama (1821), and his final, unfinished work, The Triumph of Life (1822)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Shelley's close circle of friends included some of the most important progressive thinkers of the day, including his father-in-law, the philosopher William Godwin, and Leigh Hunt
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Though Shelley's poetry and prose output remained steady throughout his life, most publishers and journals declined to publish his work for fear of being arrested for either blasphemy or sedition
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Shelley's poetry sometimes had only an underground readership during his day, but his poetic achievements are widely recognized today, and his political and social thought impacted the Chartist and other movements in England, and reach down to the present day
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Shelley's theories of economics and morality, for example, had a profound influence on Karl Marx; his early—perhaps first—writings on nonviolent resistance influenced both Leo Tolstoy and Mahatma Gandhi
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Shelley became a lodestone to the subsequent three or four generations of poets, including important Victorian and Pre-Raphaelite poets such as Robert Browning and Dante Gabriel Rossetti
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He was admired by Oscar Wilde, Thomas Hardy, George Bernard Shaw, Leo Tolstoy, Bertrand Russell, W
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 B
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Yeats, Upton Sinclair and Isadora Duncan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Henry David Thoreau's Civil Disobedience was apparently influenced by Shelley's writings and theories on non-violence in protest and political action
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Shelley's popularity and influence has continued to grow in contemporary poetry circles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An interpersonal relationship is a strong, deep, or close association or acquaintance between two or more people that may range in duration from brief to enduring
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This association may be based on inference, love, solidarity, regular business interactions, or some other type of social commitment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Interpersonal relationships are formed in the context of social, cultural and other influences
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The context can and may and perhaps will vary from family or kinship relations, friendship, marriage, relations with associates, work, clubs, neighborhoods, and places of worship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They may be regulated by law, custom, or mutual agreement, and are the basis of social groups and society as a whole
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"Acquainted" is a song by Canadian singer The Weeknd recorded for his second studio album Beauty Behind the Madness (2015)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was written and produced by him along with Jason "DaHeala" Quenneville, Danny "Boy Styles" Schofield, Carlos "Illangelo" Montagnese and Ben "Billions" Diehl
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The track was sent to urban contemporary stations on November 17, 2015, by XO and Republic Records, serving as the record's fourth and final single (fifth overall), being also released to rhythmic contemporary on February 16, 2016
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was set to impact contemporary hit radio on April 12, 2016, though its release to those stations did not occur
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Community acquis or acquis communautaire (; French: [aˌki kɔmynoˈtɛːʁ]), sometimes called the EU acquis and often shortened to acquis, is the accumulated legislation, legal acts, and court decisions which constitute the body of European Union law
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term is French: acquis meaning "that which has been acquired or obtained", and communautaire meaning "of the community"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"Acquiesce" is a song by the English rock band Oasis, written by Noel Gallagher
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The song originally appeared as a B-side to Oasis' first UK #1 single, "Some Might Say", in April 1995
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its popularity led to it being included on the B-sides compilation album The Masterplan, released in 1998, after being voted for inclusion by fans of the band on their official website
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In 1998, the song was issued as a radio single in the United States to promote the release of The Masterplan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It reached #24 in the US Modern Rock Chart, based on radio airplay
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

"Acquiesce" was also released as one of the lead tracks to the Stop the Clocks EP, in promotion of their compilation album of which it also appears on, Stop the Clocks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The verses to "Acquiesce" are sung by Liam Gallagher, with the chorus sung by Noel (because, he claims, Liam could not reach the high notes), making it the first song to ever feature both Gallagher brothers on lead vocals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The only other Oasis songs to feature both brothers on lead vocals are "Put Yer Money Where Yer Mouth Is", from their 2000 album Standing on the Shoulder of Giants, "Born on a Different Cloud", from their 2002 album Heathen Chemistry, and "Let There Be Love", from their 2005 album Don't Believe the Truth
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their cover version of The Who's My Generation also features both brothers on lead vocals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In law, acquiescence occurs when a person knowingly stands by without raising any objection to the infringement of their rights, while someone else unknowingly and without malice aforethought makes a claim on their rights
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Consequently, the person whose rights are infringed loses the ability to make a claim against the infringer, or succeed in an injunction suit due to the infringer's conduct
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term is most generally a kind of "permission" given by silence or passiveness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Hollis "Holly" Partridge Scott (née Flax) is a fictional character from the US television series The Office played by Amy Ryan
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She was an original character, and not based on a character from the British version of the show
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Initially, she served as a replacement HR Representative for the Scranton branch of Dunder Mifflin when Toby Flenderson left for Costa Rica
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Later, her character was developed into a friend and romantic interest for Steve Carell's character Michael Scott
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She and Michael have a shared sense of humor and similar personality traits, though Holly does prove to be more rational than Michael
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the office, she is noticeably more acquiescent to Michael's antics and ideas than was her predecessor, Toby
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At the office, Michael proposes to her with the help of their co-workers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She and Michael eventually get back together, move to Colorado, marry and start a family together
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acquire is a multi-player mergers and acquisitions themed board game
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is played with tiles representing hotels that are arranged on the board, play money and stock certificates
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The object of the game is to earn the most money by developing and merging hotel chains
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When a chain in which a player owns stock is acquired by a larger chain, players earn money based on the size of the acquired chain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At the end of the game, all players liquidate their stock in order to determine which player has the most money
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was one of the most popular games in the 1960s 3M bookshelf game series, and the only one still published in the United States
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acquiring bank (also known simply as an acquirer) is a bank or financial institution that processes credit or debit card payments on behalf of a merchant
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The acquirer allows merchants to accept credit card payments from the card-issuing banks within an association
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The best-known (credit) card associations are Visa, MasterCard, Discover, Indian Rupay, American Express, Diners Club, Japan Credit Bureau and China UnionPay
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The acquiring bank enters into a contract with a merchant and offers it a merchant account
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This arrangement provides the merchant with a line of credit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Under the agreement, the acquiring bank exchanges funds with issuing banks on behalf of the merchant, and pays the merchant for its daily payment-card activity's net balance—that is, gross sales minus reversals, interchange fees, and acquirer fees
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acquirer fees are an additional markup added to association interchange fees by the acquiring bank, varying at the acquirer's discretion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acquiring bank (also known simply as an acquirer) is a bank or financial institution that processes credit or debit card payments on behalf of a merchant
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The acquirer allows merchants to accept credit card payments from the card-issuing banks within an association
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The best-known (credit) card associations are Visa, MasterCard, Discover, Indian Rupay, American Express, Diners Club, Japan Credit Bureau and China UnionPay
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This arrangement provides the merchant with a line of credit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Under the agreement, the acquiring bank exchanges funds with issuing banks on behalf of the merchant, and pays the merchant for its daily payment-card activity's net balance—that is, gross sales minus reversals, interchange fees, and acquirer fees
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acquirer fees are an additional markup added to association interchange fees by the acquiring bank, varying at the acquirer's discretion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Mergers and acquisitions (M&A) are transactions in which the ownership of companies, other business organizations or their operating units are transferred or combined
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As an aspect of strategic management, M&A can allow enterprises to grow, shrink, and change the nature of their business or competitive position
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

From a legal point of view, a merger is a legal consolidation of two entities into one entity, whereas an acquisition occurs when one entity takes ownership of another entity's stock, equity interests or assets
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 From a commercial and economic point of view, both types of transactions generally result in the consolidation of assets and liabilities under one entity, and the distinction between a "merger" and an "acquisition" is less clear
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A transaction legally structured as an acquisition may have the effect of placing one party's business under the indirect ownership of the other party's shareholders, while a transaction legally structured as a merger may give each party's shareholders partial ownership and control of the combined enterprise
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A deal may be euphemistically called a "merger of equals" if both CEOs agree that joining together is in the best interest of both of their companies, while when the deal is unfriendly (that is, when the management of the target company opposes the deal) it may be regarded as an "acquisition"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acquisitiveness is a phrenological faculty
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acqui Terme (Piedmontese: Äich) is a city and comune of Piedmont, northern Italy, in the province of Alessandria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is about 35 kilometres (22 mi) south-southwest of Alessandria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is one of the principal winemaking communes of the Italian DOCG wine Brachetto d'Acqui
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The hot sulphur springs have been famous since this was the Roman town of Aquae Statiellae; the ancient baths are referred to by Paulus Diaconus and the chronicler Liutprand of Cremona
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 1870 Giovanni Ceruti designed a little pavilion, known as La Bollente, for the spot at the centre of the town where the waters bubble up at 75 °C (167 °F)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In the common law tradition, an acquittal formally certifies that the accused is free from the charge of an offense, as far as the criminal law is concerned
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This is so even where the prosecution is abandoned nolle prosequi
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The finality of an acquittal is dependent on the jurisdiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In some countries, such as the United States, under the rules of double jeopardy and autrefois acquit, an acquittal operates to bar the retrial of the accused for the same offense, even if new evidence surfaces that further implicates the accused
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The effect of an acquittal on criminal proceedings is the same whether it results from a jury verdict, or whether it results from the operation of some other rule that discharges the accused
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In other countries, the prosecuting authority may appeal an acquittal similar to how a defendant may appeal a conviction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The family Acrasidae (ICZN, or Acrasiomycota, ICBN) is a family of slime molds which belongs to the protist group Percolozoa
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name acrasio- comes from the Greek Akrasia, meaning "acting against one's judgement"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This group consists of cellular slime molds
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Some would also consider it as a kingdom unto itself, but the debate is as yet unsettled
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The terms "Acrasiomycota" or "Acrasiomycetes" have been used when the group was believed to be a fungus ("-mycota")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In some classifications, Dictyostelium was placed in Acrasiomycetes, an artificial group of cellular slime molds, which was characterized by the aggregation of individual amoebae into a multicellular fruiting body, making it an important factor that related the acrasids to the dictyostelids
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The acre is a unit of land area used in the imperial and US customary systems
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is defined as the area of 1 chain by 1 furlong (66 by 660 feet), which is exactly equal to  1⁄640 of a square mile, 43,560 square feet, approximately 4,047 m2, or about 40% of a hectare
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The acre is commonly used in Antigua and Barbuda, Australia, American Samoa, the Bahamas, Belize, the British Virgin Islands, the Cayman Islands, Canada, Dominica, the Falkland Islands, Grenada, Ghana, Guam, the Northern Mariana Islands, India, Sri Lanka,Bangladesh,Nepal, Ireland, Jamaica, Montserrat, Myanmar, Pakistan, Samoa, St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Lucia, St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Helena, St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Kitts and Nevis, St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Vincent and the Grenadines, Turks and Caicos, the United Kingdom, the United States and the US Virgin Islands
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The international symbol of the acre is ac
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The most commonly used acre today is the international acre
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the United States both the international acre and the US survey acre are in use, but differ by only two parts per million; see below
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The most common use of the acre is to measure tracts of land
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 One international acre is defined as exactly 4,046
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
8564224 square metres
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An acre was defined in the Middle Ages as the amount of land that could be ploughed in one day by a yoke of oxen
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The acre-foot is a unit of volume commonly used in the United States in reference to large-scale water resources, such as reservoirs, aqueducts, canals, sewer flow capacity, irrigation water, and river flows
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acid is a molecule or ion capable of donating a hydron (proton or hydrogen ion H+), or, alternatively, capable of forming a covalent bond with an electron pair (a Lewis acid)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The first category of acids is the proton donors or Brønsted acids
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the special case of aqueous solutions, proton donors form the hydronium ion H3O+ and are known as Arrhenius acids
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Brønsted and Lowry generalized the Arrhenius theory to include non-aqueous solvents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A Brønsted or Arrhenius acid usually contains a hydrogen atom bonded to a chemical structure that is still energetically favorable after loss of H+
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Aqueous Arrhenius acids have characteristic properties which provide a practical description of an acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acids form aqueous solutions with a sour taste, can turn blue litmus red, and react with bases and certain metals (like calcium) to form salts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The word acid is derived from the Latin acidus/acēre meaning sour
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An aqueous solution of an acid has a pH less than 7 and is colloquially also referred to as 'acid' (as in 'dissolved in acid'), while the strict definition refers only to the solute
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A lower pH means a higher acidity, and thus a higher concentration of positive hydrogen ions in the solution
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Chemicals or substances having the property of an acid are said to be acidic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Common aqueous acids include hydrochloric acid (a solution of hydrogen chloride which is found in gastric acid in the stomach and activates digestive enzymes), acetic acid (vinegar is a dilute aqueous solution of this liquid), sulfuric acid (used in car batteries), and citric acid (found in citrus fruits)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As these examples show, acids (in the colloquial sense) can be solutions or pure substances, and can be derived from acids (in the strict sense) that are solids, liquids, or gases
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Strong acids and some concentrated weak acids are corrosive, but there are exceptions such as carboranes and boric acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The second category of acids are Lewis acids, which form a covalent bond with an electron pair
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An example is boron trifluoride (BF3), whose boron atom has a vacant orbital which can form a covalent bond by sharing a lone pair of electrons on an atom in a base, for example the nitrogen atom in ammonia (NH3)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Lewis considered this as a generalization of the Brønsted definition, so that an acid is a chemical species that accepts electron pairs either directly or by releasing protons (H+) into the solution, which then accept electron pairs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, hydrogen chloride, acetic acid, and most other Brønsted-Lowry acids cannot form a covalent bond with an electron pair and are therefore not Lewis acids
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Conversely, many Lewis acids are not Arrhenius or Brønsted-Lowry acids
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In modern terminology, an acid is implicitly a Brønsted acid and not a Lewis acid, since chemists almost always refer to a Lewis acid explicitly as a Lewis acid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Acrididae are the predominant family of grasshoppers, comprising some 10,000 of the 11,000 species of the entire suborder Caelifera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Acrididae are best known because all locusts (swarming grasshoppers) are of the Acrididae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The subfamily Oedipodinae is sometimes classified as a distinct family Oedipodidae in the superfamily Acridoidea
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acrididae grasshoppers are characterized by relatively short and stout antennae, and tympana on the side of the first abdominal segment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acridotheres is a genus of starlings, the "typical" mynas, which are tropical members of the family Sturnidae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This genus has representatives in tropical southern Asia from Iran east to southern China and Indonesia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Two species have been introduced widely elsewhere
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The common myna has been introduced to South Africa, Israel, Hawaii, North America, Australia and New Zealand, and the crested myna to the Vancouver region of British Columbia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Acridotheres mynas are generally dark or dull birds with and fluted calls like most starlings; the sexes are similar
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They walk rather than hop, and have modifications to the skull and its muscles for open bill probing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They resemble the hill mynas (Gracula) with which they often co-occur, in having large white or buff wing patches which are obvious in flight and in some also naked areas on the head, but differ in that only the head plumage is glossy, and the underparts tend to be paler
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The naked head patches are different in arrangement
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acridotheres mynas are also much more terrestrial than Gracula
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

They have bowing courtship displays, whereas Gracula has no visual display
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They lay unmarked pale blue eggs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Several species have frontal crests which become covered with pollen when the birds take nectar from flowers, and may play a role in pollination
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Like most starlings, the Acridotheres mynas are fairly omnivorous, eating fruit, nectar and insects
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrylic fibers are synthetic fibers made from a polymer (polyacrylonitrile) with an average molecular weight of ~100,000, about 1900 monomer units
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For a fiber to be called "acrylic" in the US, the polymer must contain at least 85% acrylonitrile monomer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Typical comonomers are vinyl acetate or methyl acrylate
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 DuPont created the first acrylic fibers in 1941 and trademarked them under the name Orlon
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was first developed in the mid-1940s but was not produced in large quantities until the 1950s
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Strong and warm, acrylic fiber is often used for sweaters and tracksuits and as linings for boots and gloves, as well as in furnishing fabrics and carpets
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is manufactured as a filament, then cut into short staple lengths similar to wool hairs, and spun into yarn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Modacrylic is a modified acrylic fiber that contains at least 35% and at most 85% acrylonitrile monomer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The comonomers vinyl chloride, vinylidene chloride or vinyl bromide used in modacrylic give the fiber flame retardant properties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 End-uses of modacrylic include faux fur, wigs, hair extensions and protective clothing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Hatred or hate is a deep and extreme emotional dislike
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can be directed against individuals, groups, entities, objects, behaviors, or ideas
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hatred is often associated with feelings of anger, disgust and a disposition towards hostility
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrimony was a British heavy metal band who were active during the 1990s
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Releasing their debut album in 1994, they are regarded as the pioneers of stoner metal in the United Kingdom, and an important influence upon the scene
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although the band never achieved mainstream success, during their career they received much critical acclaim – they were nominated for the Kerrang! Best Newcomer award and earned top review ratings
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acrimony have maintained a cult following in the British metal scene, their records reportedly selling for vast sums as collectors items
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 AlMusic described their musical style as "typical mid-'90s stoner rock" that "combined Black Sabbath's heavy metal riffery, Hawkwind's space rock excursions, and Blue Cheer's fuzzed-out psychedelic feedback with extreme doses of volume 
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 particularly reminiscent of desert metal gods Kyuss
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Acritic songs (Greek: Ακριτικά τραγούδια "frontiersmen songs") are the heroic or epic poetry that emerged in the Byzantine Empire probably around the 9th century
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The songs celebrated the exploits of the Akrites, the frontier guards defending the eastern borders of the Byzantine Empire
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The historical background was the almost continuous Byzantine-Arab conflict between the 7th and 12th centuries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Against this background several romances were produced, the most famous of which is that of Digenis Acritas, considered by some to signal the beginnings of modern Greek literature
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
This is a list of Latin words with derivatives in English (and other modern languages)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Ancient orthography did not distinguish between i and j or between u and v
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many modern works distinguish u from v but not i from j
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In this article, both distinctions are shown as they are helpful when tracing the origin of English words
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 See also Latin spelling and pronunciation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acraea (Ancient Greek: Ἀκραία) was a name that had several uses in Greek and Roman mythology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acraea was a daughter of the river-god Asterion near Mycenae, who together with her sisters Euboea and Prosymna (Πρόσυμνα) acted as nurses to Hera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A hill Acraea opposite the temple of Hera near Mycenae derived its name from her
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acraea and Acraeus are also epithets given to various goddesses and gods whose temples were situated upon hills, such as Zeus, Hera, Aphrodite, Pallas, Artemis, and others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrobatics (from Greek ἀκροβατέω akrobateō, "walk on tiptoe, strut") is the performance of extraordinary human feats of balance, agility, and motor coordination
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can be found in many of the performing arts, sports (sporting) events, and martial arts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acrobatics is most often associated with activities that make extensive use of gymnastic elements, such as acro dance, circus, and gymnastics, but many other athletic activities — such as ballet and diving — may also employ acrobatics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although acrobatics is most commonly associated with human body performance, it may also apply to other types of performance, such as aerobatics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aristotle (; Greek: Ἀριστοτέλης, pronounced [aristotélɛːs], Aristotélēs; 384–322 BC) was an ancient Greek philosopher and scientist born in the city of Stagira, Chalkidice, on the northern periphery of Classical Greece
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His father, Nicomachus, died when Aristotle was a child, whereafter Proxenus of Atarneus became his guardian
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At seventeen or eighteen years of age, he joined Plato's Academy in Athens and remained there until the age of thirty-seven (c
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 347 BC)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His writings cover many subjects – including physics, biology, zoology, metaphysics, logic, ethics, aesthetics, poetry, theater, music, rhetoric, linguistics, politics and government – and constitute the first comprehensive system of Western philosophy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Shortly after Plato died, Aristotle left Athens and, at the request of Philip II of Macedon, tutored Alexander the Great beginning in 343 BC
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Teaching Alexander the Great gave Aristotle many opportunities and an abundance of supplies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He established a library in the Lyceum which aided in the production of many of his hundreds of books, which were written on papyrus scrolls
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The fact that Aristotle was a pupil of Plato contributed to his former views of Platonism, but, following Plato's death, Aristotle immersed himself in empirical studies and shifted from Platonism to empiricism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He believed all peoples' concepts and all of their knowledge was ultimately based on perception
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aristotle's views on natural sciences represent the groundwork underlying many of his works
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Aristotle's views on physical science profoundly shaped medieval scholarship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their influence extended from Late Antiquity and the Early Middle Ages into the Renaissance, and were not replaced systematically until the Enlightenment and theories such as classical mechanics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some of Aristotle's zoological observations, such as on the hectocotyl (reproductive) arm of the octopus, were not confirmed or refuted until the 19th century
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His works contain the earliest known formal study of logic, which was incorporated in the late 19th century into modern formal logic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In metaphysics, Aristotelianism profoundly influenced Jewish and Islamic philosophical and theological thought during the Middle Ages and continues to influence Christian theology, especially the Neoplatonism of the Early Church and the scholastic tradition of the Catholic Church
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aristotle was well known among medieval Muslim scholars, and has been revered as "The First Teacher" (Arabic: المعلم الأول‎‎)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

His ethics, though always influential, gained renewed interest with the modern advent of virtue ethics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 All aspects of Aristotle's philosophy continue to be the object of active academic study today
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Though Aristotle wrote many elegant treatises and dialogues – Cicero described his literary style as "a river of gold" – it is thought that only around a third of his original output has survived
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrobatics (from Greek ἀκροβατέω akrobateō, "walk on tiptoe, strut") is the performance of extraordinary human feats of balance, agility, and motor coordination
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can be found in many of the performing arts, sports (sporting) events, and martial arts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acrobatics is most often associated with activities that make extensive use of gymnastic elements, such as acro dance, circus, and gymnastics, but many other athletic activities — such as ballet and diving — may also employ acrobatics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although acrobatics is most commonly associated with human body performance, it may also apply to other types of performance, such as aerobatics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although acrobatics is most commonly associated with human body performance, it may also apply to other types of performance, such as aerobatics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adobe Acrobat is a family of application software and Web services developed by Adobe Systems to view, create, manipulate, print and manage files in Portable Document Format (PDF)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The family comprises Acrobat Reader (formerly Adobe Reader), Acrobat (formerly Acrobat Exchange) and Acrobat
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
com
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The basic Acrobat Reader, available for several desktop and mobile platforms, is freeware; it supports viewing, printing and annotating of PDF files
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Additional, "Premium", services are available for reader on paid subscription
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The commercial proprietary Acrobat, available for Microsoft Windows and macOS only, can also create, edit, convert, digitally sign, encrypt, export and publish PDF files
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acrobat
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
com complements the family with a variety of enterprise content management and file hosting services
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrobasis is a genus of moths of the Pyralidae family
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
