 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Dawsonia is a genus of acrocarpous mosses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Dawsonia, along with other members of the order Polytrichales, are taller than most mosses and have thicker leaves
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their sporophytes have conducting systems analogous to those of vascular plants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Dawsonia superba is found in New Zealand, Australia and New Guinea
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Dawsonia longifolia is found in the Philippines, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Dawsonia superba and Dawsonia longifolia may be the same species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrocarpus is a genus of flowering plants in the legume family, Fabaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It belongs to the sub family Caesalpinioideae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The genus includes two tree species found in south Asia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It has pinnate, compound leaves, with red flowers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 After blooming, the trees produce flat, long pods
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 fraxinifolius can reach up to 60 m (196 ft) in height and it is used for timber
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The centromere is the part of a chromosome that links sister chromatids or a dyad
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During mitosis, spindle fibers attach to the centromere via the kinetochore
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Centromeres were first thought to be genetic loci that direct the behavior of chromosomes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The physical role of the centromere is to act as the site of assembly of the kinetochore – a highly complex multiprotein structure that is responsible for the actual events of chromosome segregation – i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 binding microtubules and signalling to the cell cycle machinery when all chromosomes have adopted correct attachments to the spindle, so that it is safe for cell division to proceed to completion and for cells to enter anaphase
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There are, broadly speaking, two types of centromeres
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "Point centromeres" bind to specific proteins that recognise particular DNA sequences with high efficiency
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Any piece of DNA with the point centromere DNA sequence on it will typically form a centromere if present in the appropriate species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The best characterised point centromeres are those of the budding yeast, Saccharomyces cerevisiae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "Regional centromeres" is the term coined to describe most centromeres, which typically form on regions of preferred DNA sequence, but which can form on other DNA (Deoxyribonucleic acid ) sequences as well
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The signal for formation of a regional centromere appears to be epigenetic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most organisms, ranging from the fission yeast Schizosaccharomyces pombe to humans, have regional centromeres
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Regarding mitotic chromosome structure, centromeres represent a constricted region of the chromosome (often referred to as the primary constriction) where two identical sister chromatids are most closely in contact
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When cells enter mitosis, the sister chromatids (the two copies of each chromosomal DNA molecule resulting from DNA replication in chromatin form) are linked along their length by the action of the cohesin complex
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is now believed that this complex is mostly released from chromosome arms during prophase, so that by the time the chromosomes line up at the mid-plane of the mitotic spindle (also known as the metaphase plate), the last place where they are linked with one another is in the chromatin in and around the centromere
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Rhodanthe, also known as sunray or pink paper daisy, is a genus of Australian plants in the pussy's-toes tribe within the daisy family
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


The name Rhodanthe is derived from Greek rhodon, rose and anthos, flower
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Many Rhodanthe species were formerly classed under different genera, including Helipterum, Podotheca, Acroclinium and Waitzia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


Species


 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrocomia is a genus of palms which is native to the Neotropics, ranging from Mexico in the north, through Central America and the Caribbean, and through South America south to Argentina
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrocyanosis is persistent blue or cyanotic discoloration of the extremities, most commonly occurring in the hands, although it also occurs in the feet and distal parts of face
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
   Although described over 100 years ago and not uncommon in practice, the nature of this phenomenon is still uncertain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The very term "acrocyanosis" is often applied inappropriately in cases when blue discoloration of the hands, feet, or parts of the face is noted
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The principal (primary) form of acrocyanosis is that of a benign cosmetic condition, sometimes caused by a relatively benign neurohormonal disorder
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Regardless of its cause, the benign form typically does not require medical treatment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A medical emergency would ensue if the extremities experience prolonged periods of exposure to the cold, particularly in children and patients with poor general health
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, frostbite differs from acrocyanosis because pain (via thermal nociceptors) often accompanies the former condition, while the latter is very rarely associated with pain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are also a number of other conditions that affect hands, feet, and parts of the face with associated skin color changes that need to be differentiated from acrocyanosis: Raynaud’s phenomenon, pernio, acrorygosis, erythromelalgia, blue finger syndrome
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The diagnosis may be challenging in some cases, especially when these syndromes co-exist
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acrocyanosis may be a sign of a more serious medical problem, such as connective tissue diseases and diseases associated with central cyanosis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other causative conditions include infections, toxicities, antiphospholipid syndrome, cryoglobulinemia, neoplasms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In these cases, the observed cutaneous changes are known as "secondary acrocyanosis"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They may have a less symmetric distribution and may be associated with pain and tissue loss
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
A cryptogam (scientific name Cryptogamae) is a plant (in the wide sense of the word) that reproduces by spores, without flowers or seeds
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 "Cryptogamae" (Greek κρυπτός kryptos, "hidden" + γαμέω, gameein, "to marry") means hidden reproduction, referring to the fact that no seed is produced, thus cryptogams represent the non-seed bearing plants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other names, such as "thallophytes", "lower plants", and "spore plants" are also occasionally used
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a group, Cryptogamae are the opposite of the Phanerogamae (Greek φανερός, phaneros = "visible") or Spermatophyta (Greek σπέρμα, sperma = "seed" and φυτόν, phyton = "plant"), the seed plants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The best known groups of cryptogams are algae, lichens, mosses and ferns, but it also includes non-photosynthetic organisms traditionally classified as plants, such as fungi, slime molds, and bacteria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The classification is now deprecated in Linnaean taxonomy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

At one time, the cryptogams were formally recognised as a group within the plant kingdom
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In his system for classification of all known plants and animals, Carl Linnaeus (1707–1778) divided the plant kingdom into 24 classes, one of which was the "Cryptogamia"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This included all plants with concealed reproductive organs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He divided Cryptogamia into four orders: Algae, Musci (bryophytes), Filices (ferns), and Fungi
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Not all cryptogams are treated as part of the plant kingdom; the fungi, in particular, are regarded as a separate kingdom, more closely related to animals than plants, while blue-green algae are now regarded as a phylum of bacteria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Therefore, in contemporary plant systematics, "Cryptogamae" is not a taxonomically coherent group, but is cladistically polyphyletic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, all organisms known as cryptogams belong to the field traditionally studied by botanists and the names of all cryptogams are regulated by the International Code of Nomenclature for algae, fungi, and plants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

During World War II, the Government Code and Cypher School recruited Geoffrey Tandy, a marine biologist expert in cryptogams, to Station X, Bletchley Park when someone confused these with cryptograms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrobatics (from Greek ἀκροβατέω akrobateō, "walk on tiptoe, strut") is the performance of extraordinary human feats of balance, agility, and motor coordination
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can be found in many of the performing arts, sports (sporting) events, and martial arts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acrobatics is most often associated with activities that make extensive use of gymnastic elements, such as acro dance, circus, and gymnastics, but many other athletic activities — such as ballet and diving — may also employ acrobatics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although acrobatics is most commonly associated with human body performance, it may also apply to other types of performance, such as aerobatics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acromegaly is a disorder that results from excess growth hormone (GH) after the growth plates have closed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The initial symptom is typically enlargement of the hands and feet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There may also be enlargement of the forehead, jaw, and nose
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other symptoms may include joint pain, thicker skin, deepening of the voice, headaches, and problems with vision
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Complications of the disease may include type 2 diabetes, sleep apnea, and high blood pressure
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acromegaly is typically due to the pituitary gland producing too much growth hormone
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In more than 95% of cases the excess production is due to a benign tumor, known as a pituitary adenoma
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The condition is not inherited from a person's parents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Rarely acromegaly is due to tumors in other parts of the body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Diagnosis is by measuring growth hormone after a person has drunk glucose or by measuring insulin-like growth factor I in the blood
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 After diagnosis, medical imaging of the pituitary is carried out to look for an adenoma
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 If excess growth hormone is produced during childhood the result is gigantism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Treatment options include surgery to remove the tumor, medications, and radiation therapy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Surgery is usually the preferred treatment and is most effective when the tumor is smaller
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In those in whom surgery is not effective, medications of the somatostatin analogue or GH receptor antagonist type may be used
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The effects of radiation therapy are more gradual than that of surgery or medication
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Without treatment those affected live on average 10 years less; however, with treatment life expectancy is typically normal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acromegaly affects about 6 per 100,000 people
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is most commonly diagnosed in middle age
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Males and females are affected with equal frequency
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The first medical description of the disorder occurred in 1772 by Nicolas Saucerotte
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term is from Greek ἄκρον akron meaning "extremity" and μέγα mega meaning "large"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acromegaly is a disorder that results from excess growth hormone (GH) after the growth plates have closed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The initial symptom is typically enlargement of the hands and feet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There may also be enlargement of the forehead, jaw, and nose
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other symptoms may include joint pain, thicker skin, deepening of the voice, headaches, and problems with vision
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The term Mongolian idiocy and similar terms have been used to refer to a specific type of mental deficiency associated with the genetic disorder now more commonly referred to as Down syndrome
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The use of these terms has largely been abandoned because of their offensive and misleading implications about those with the disorder
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

English physician John Langdon Down first characterized the syndrome that now bears his name as a separate form of mental disability in 1862, and in a more widely published report in 1866
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Due to his perception that children with Down syndrome shared facial similarities with the populations that Johann Friedrich Blumenbach described as the "Mongolian race", Down used the term mongoloid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Mongolism and its Pathology was the title used by W
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Bertram Hill for a published study in 1908 and the term mongolism was used by psychiatrist and geneticist Lionel Penrose as late as 1961
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The racist connotations of the term were both popularized and exacerbated by F
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 G
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Crookshank in a long-discredited work of scientific racism entitled The Mongol in our Midst first published in 1924
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In 1961, a prestigious group of genetic experts wrote a joint letter to the medical journal The Lancet which read:

It has long been recognised that the terms Mongolian Idiocy, Mongolism, Mongoloid, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 as applied to a specific type of mental deficiency have misleading connotations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The importance of this anomaly among Europeans and their descendants is not related to the segregation of genes derived from Asians; its appearance among members of Asian populations suggests such ambiguous designations as 'Mongol Mongoloid'; increasing participation of Chinese and Japanese in investigation of the condition imposes on them the use of an embarrassing term
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 We urge, therefore, that the expressions which imply a racial aspect of the condition be no longer used
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some of the undersigned are inclined to replace the term Mongolism by such designations as 'Langdon Down Anomaly', or 'Down's Syndrome or Anomaly', or 'Congenital Acromicria'
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Several of us believe that this is an appropriate time to introduce the term 'Trisomy 21 Anomaly', which would include cases of simple Trisomy as well as translocations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is hoped that agreement on a specific phrase will soon crystallise once the term 'Mongolism' has been abandoned
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


The World Health Organization (WHO) resolved to abandon the term in 1965 at the request of the Mongolian People's Republic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Despite several decades of inaction and resistance, the term thereafter began to fade from use, in favor of the term such as Down's Syndrome, Down syndrome and Trisomy 21 disorder
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Steven J
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Gould reported in 1980 that the term "mongolism" still remained in common use in the United States, despite its being "defamatory" and "wrong on all counts"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the 21st century, all the older terms are considered unacceptable in the English-speaking world, are no longer in common use, and have been largely forgotten
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In French, "mongolisme" is still in common use in the media to refer to Down syndrome
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In human anatomy, the acromion (from Greek: akros, "highest", ōmos, "shoulder", plural: acromia) is a bony process on the scapula (shoulder blade)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Together with the coracoid process it extends laterally over the shoulder joint
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The acromion is a continuation of the scapular spine, and hooks over anteriorly
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It articulates with the clavicle (collar bone) to form the acromioclavicular joint
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acronym is a word or name formed as an abbreviation from the initial components in a phrase or a word, usually individual letters (as in NATO or laser) and sometimes syllables (as in Benelux), that can be pronounced as a word
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There are no universal standards of the multiple names for such abbreviations and of their orthographic styling
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In English and most other languages, such abbreviations historically had limited use, but they became much more common in the 20th century
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acronyms are a type of word formation process, and they are viewed as a subtype of blending
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acronym is a word or name formed as an abbreviation from the initial components in a phrase or a word, usually individual letters (as in NATO or laser) and sometimes syllables (as in Benelux), that can be pronounced as a word
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There are no universal standards of the multiple names for such abbreviations and of their orthographic styling
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acronyms are a type of word formation process, and they are viewed as a subtype of blending
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acropetal Technologies is a mid-sized business technology Solutions Company headquartered in Bangalore, India
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The company operates as a provider of on-demand technology solutions across various sectors including Education, Manufacturing, Consumer Goods, Retail, Health Care
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The company has offices in 4 geographies namely Asia Pac, North America, Europe and Middle East
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrophobia (from the Greek: ἄκρον, ákron, meaning "peak, summit, edge" and φόβος, phóbos, "fear") is an extreme or irrational fear or phobia of heights, especially when one is not particularly high up
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It belongs to a category of specific phobias, called space and motion discomfort, that share both similar causes and options for treatment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Most people experience a degree of natural fear when exposed to heights, known as the fear of falling
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 On the other hand, those who have little fear of such exposure are said to have a head for heights
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A head for heights is advantageous for those hiking or climbing in mountainous terrain and also in certain jobs e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 steeplejacks or wind turbine mechanics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acrophobia sufferers can experience a panic attack in high places and become too agitated to get themselves down safely
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Approximately 2–5% of the general population suffers from acrophobia, with twice as many women affected as men
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrophobia (from the Greek: ἄκρον, ákron, meaning "peak, summit, edge" and φόβος, phóbos, "fear") is an extreme or irrational fear or phobia of heights, especially when one is not particularly high up

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
New Acropolis (NA; official name: Organización Internacional Nueva Acrópolis "OINA" - Organisation Internationale Nouvelle Acropole, association internationale sans but lucratif) is a worldwide non-profit organisation founded in 1957 by Jorge Ángel Livraga Rizzi (died 1991) first as a school of philosophy and later on as an international organization devoted to philosophical studies and practice
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Registered in Belgium as international organization since 1981, number 3/12-941/S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acropora is a genus of small polyp stony coral in the phylum Cnidaria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some of its species are known as table coral, elkhorn coral, and staghorn coral
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Over 149 species are described
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acropora species are some of the major reef corals responsible for building the immense calcium carbonate substructure that supports the thin living skin of a reef
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The acrosome is an organelle that develops over the anterior half of the head in the spermatozoa (sperm cells) of many animals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a cap-like structure derived from the Golgi apparatus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acrosome formation is fully completed 5–10 years after testicular maturation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Eutherian mammals the acrosome contains digestive enzymes (including hyaluronidase and acrosin)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These enzymes break down the outer membrane of the ovum, called the zona pellucida, allowing the haploid nucleus in the sperm cell to join with the haploid nucleus in the ovum
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

This shedding of the acrosome, or acrosome reaction, can be stimulated in vitro by substances a sperm cell may encounter naturally such as progesterone or follicular fluid, as well as the more commonly used calcium ionophore A23187
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This can be done to serve as a positive control when assessing the acrosome reaction of a sperm sample by flow cytometry or fluorescence microscopy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This is usually done after staining with a fluoresceinated lectin such as FITC-PNA, FITC-PSA, FITC-ConA, or fluoresceinated antibody such as FITC-CD46
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


In the case of globozoospermia (sperm with round heads), the Golgi apparatus is not transformed into the acrosome, causing male infertility
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Across the Universe is a 2007 British-American jukebox musical romantic drama film directed by Julie Taymor, centered on songs by the English rock band the Beatles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The script is based on an original story credited to Taymor, Dick Clement, and Ian La Frenais
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It incorporates 34 compositions originally written by members of the Beatles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film stars Jim Sturgess, Evan Rachel Wood, Joe Anderson and T
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
V
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Carpio, and introduces Dana Fuchs and Martin Luther McCoy as actors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Cameo appearances are made by Bono, Eddie Izzard, Joe Cocker, and Salma Hayek, among others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Opening to mixed reviews, Across the Universe was nominated for both a Golden Globe and an Academy Award
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Two members of the supporting cast, Carol Woods and Timothy T
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Mitchum, performed as part of a special Beatles tribute at the 50th Grammy Awards
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An acrostic is a poem (or other form of writing) in which the first letter (or syllable, or word) of each line (or paragraph, or other recurring feature in the text) spells out a word, message or the alphabet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The word comes from the French acrostiche from post-classical Latin acrostichis, from Koine Greek ἀκροστιχίς, from Ancient Greek ἄκρος "highest, topmost" and στίχος "verse")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a form of constrained writing, an acrostic can be used as a mnemonic device to aid memory retrieval
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Relatively simple acrostics may merely spell out the letters of the alphabet in order; such an acrostic may be called an 'alphabetical acrostic' or Abecedarius
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These acrostics occur in the first four of the five songs that make up the Book of Lamentations, in the praise of the good wife in Proverbs 31, 10-31, and in Psalms 25, 34, 37, 111, 112, 119 and 145 of the Hebrew Bible
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Notable among the acrostic Psalms is the long Psalm 119, which typically is printed in subsections named after the 22 letters of the Hebrew alphabet, each section consisting of 8 verses, each of which begins with the same letter of the alphabet and the entire psalm consisting of 22 x 8 = 176 verses; and Psalm 145, which is recited three times a day in the Jewish services
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some acrostic psalms are technically imperfect
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 E
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Psalm 9 and Psalm 10 appear to constitute a single acrostic psalm together, but the length assigned to each letter is unequal and five of the 22 letters of the Hebrew alphabet are not represented and the sequence of two letters is reversed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Psalm 25 one Hebrew letter is not represented, the following letter (Resh) repeated
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Psalm 34 the current final verse, 23, does fit verse 22 in content, but makes line too long
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Psalms 37 and 111 the numbering of verses and the division into lines are interfering with each other; as a result in Psalm 37, for the letters Daleth and Kaph there is only one verse, and the letter Ayin is not represented
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Psalm 111 and 112 have 22 lines, but 10 verses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Psalm 145 does not represent the letter Nun, having 21 one verses, but one Qumran manuscript of this Psalm does have that missing line, which agrees with the Septuagint
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acrostics prove that the texts in question were originally composed in writing, rather than having existed in oral tradition before being put into writing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acrostics are common in medieval literature, where they usually serve to highlight the name of the poet or his patron, or to make a prayer to a saint
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are most frequent in verse works but can also appear in prose
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Middle High German poet Rudolf von Ems for example opens all his great works with an acrostic of his name, and his world chronicle marks the beginning of each age with an acrostic of the key figure (Moses, David, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In chronicles, acrostics are common in German and English but rare in other languages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Often the ease of detectability of an acrostic can depend on the intention of its creator
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In some cases an author may desire an acrostic to have a better chance of being perceived by an observant reader, such as the acrostic contained in the Hypnerotomachia Poliphili (where the key capital letters are decorated with ornate embellishments)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, acrostics may also be used as a form of steganography, where the author seeks to conceal the message rather than proclaim it
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This might be achieved by making the key letters uniform in appearance with the surrounding text, or by aligning the words in such a way that the relationship between the key letters is less obvious
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This is referred to as null ciphers in steganography, using the first letter of each word to form a hidden message in an otherwise innocuous text
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Using letters to hide a message, as in acrostic ciphers, was popular during the Renaissance, and could employ various methods of enciphering, such as selecting other letters than initials based on a repeating pattern (equidistant letter sequences), or even concealing the message by starting at the end of the text and working backwards
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acrostichum is a fern genus in the Ceratopteridoideae subfamily of the Pteridaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was one of the original pteridophyte genera delineated by Linnaeus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was originally drawn very broadly, including all ferns that had sori apparently "acrostichoid", or distributed in a uniform mass across the back of the frond, rather than organized in discrete sori
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This led Linnaeus to include such species as Asplenium platyneuron in the genus, because the specimen he received had sori so crowded that it appeared acrostichoid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Since Acrostichum aureum is regarded as the type for the genus, it is now narrowly circumscribed only to the natural genus of three species, that are allied to the genus Ceratopteris
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are collectively known as the leather ferns or leather swamp ferns, genus members commonly being found in swamps
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The species of Acrostichum are massive ferns, with fronds up to 12 feet (3
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5 meters) tall, that depend on a semi-aquatic existence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They do not withstand prolonged immersion, but require wet roots
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The species Acrostichum aureum is known to have a high saltwater tolerance, growing in mangroves
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Pets Evacuation and Transportation Standards Act (PETS) was a bi-partisan initiative in the United States House of Representatives to require states seeking Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) assistance to accommodate pets and service animals in their plans for evacuating residents facing disasters
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Introduced by Congressmen Tom Lantos (D-California) and Christopher Shays (R-Connecticut) on September 22, 2005, the bill passed the House of Representatives on May 22, 2006 by a margin of 349 to 29
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Technically an amendment to the Stafford Act, it was signed into law by President George W
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Bush on October 6, 2006
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The bill is now Public Law 109-308
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
ACTED (French: Agence d'Aide à la Coopération Technique Et au Développement), formerly 'Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development', is a French humanitarian NGO set up in 1993
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a non-governmental, non-political and non-profit organization committed to supporting vulnerable populations across the world
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ACTED’s teams take action in 35 countries, responding to emergency situations, supporting rehabilitation projects and accompanying the dynamics of development
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ACTED develops more than 450 projects a year towards 8 million people, with a €160 million budget
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The organization employs more than 400 international staff and over 4300 national staff
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is the second largest French NGO
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The headquarters are in Paris, France
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Computer-assisted telephone interviewing (CATI) is a telephone surveying technique in which the interviewer follows a script provided by a software application
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a structured system of microdata collection by telephone that speeds up the collection and editing of microdata and also permits the interviewer to educate the respondents on the importance of timely and accurate data
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The software is able to customize the flow of the questionnaire based on the answers provided, as well as information already known about the participant
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is used in B2B services and corporate sales
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

CATI may function in the following manner:
A computerized questionnaire is administered to respondents over the telephone
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The interviewer sits in front of a computer screen
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Upon command, the computer dials the telephone number to be called
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

When contact is made, the interviewer reads the questions posed on the computer screen and records the respondent's answers directly into the computer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Interim and update reports can be compiled instantaneously, as the data are being collected
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

CATI software has built-in logic, which also enhances data accuracy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The program will personalize questions and control for logically incorrect answers, such as percentage answers that do not add up to 100 percent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The software has built-in branching logic, which will skip questions that are not applicable or will probe for more detail when warranted
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actias is a genus of Saturniid moths, which contains the Asian-American moon moths
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Long tails on their hindwings are among their distinctive traits
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other moths with similar appearance are Copiopteryx, Argema and Eudaemonia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The majority of species in this genus feed on the leaves of sweetgum, pine, or similar trees
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As with all Saturniids, adult Actias moths lack functional mouthparts so their lifespan after emergence from the cocoon only ranges from a few days to a week
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actifed is a registered trademark for a combination antihistamine and nasal decongestant medication used for cold and allergy symptoms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Developed in 1958 by Burroughs Wellcome & Company (now part of GlaxoSmithKline), the product was later acquired by Pfizer, and was most recently sold by Johnson & Johnson
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, the formula was changed in 2006 due to a change in the legal environment; at the same time, distribution of the product was limited to certain stores
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The United States Food and Drug Administration, FDA, lists Actifed as discontinued
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actin is a family of globular multi-functional proteins that form microfilaments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is found in essentially all eukaryotic cells (the only known exception being nematode sperm), where it may be present at a concentration of over 100 μM
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An actin protein's mass is roughly 42-kDa, with a diameter of 4 to 7 nm, and it is the monomeric subunit of two types of filaments in cells: microfilaments, one of the three major components of the cytoskeleton, and thin filaments, part of the contractile apparatus in muscle cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can be present as either a free monomer called G-actin (globular) or as part of a linear polymer microfilament called F-actin (filamentous), both of which are essential for such important cellular functions as the mobility and contraction of cells during cell division
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Actin participates in many important cellular processes, including muscle contraction, cell motility, cell division and cytokinesis, vesicle and organelle movement, cell signaling, and the establishment and maintenance of cell junctions and cell shape
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many of these processes are mediated by extensive and intimate interactions of actin with cellular membranes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In vertebrates, three main groups of actin isoforms, alpha, beta, and gamma have been identified
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The alpha actins, found in muscle tissues, are a major constituent of the contractile apparatus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The beta and gamma actins coexist in most cell types as components of the cytoskeleton, and as mediators of internal cell motility
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is believed that the diverse range of structures formed by actin enabling it to fulfill such a large range of functions is regulated through the binding of tropomyosin along the filaments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A cell’s ability to dynamically form microfilaments provides the scaffolding that allows it to rapidly remodel itself in response to its environment or to the organism’s internal signals, for example, to increase cell membrane absorption or increase cell adhesion in order to form cell tissue
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other enzymes or organelles such as cilia can be anchored to this scaffolding in order to control the deformation of the external cell membrane, which allows endocytosis and cytokinesis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can also produce movement either by itself or with the help of molecular motors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actin therefore contributes to processes such as the intracellular transport of vesicles and organelles as well as muscular contraction and cellular migration
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It therefore plays an important role in embryogenesis, the healing of wounds and the invasivity of cancer cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The evolutionary origin of actin can be traced to prokaryotic cells, which have equivalent proteins
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actin homologs from prokaryotes and archaea polymerize into different helical or linear filaments consisting of one or multiple strands
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However the in-strand contacts and nucleotide binding sites are preserved in prokaryotes and in archaea
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Lastly, actin plays an important role in the control of gene expression
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A large number of illnesses and diseases are caused by mutations in alleles of the genes that regulate the production of actin or of its associated proteins
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The production of actin is also key to the process of infection by some pathogenic microorganisms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Mutations in the different genes that regulate actin production in humans can cause muscular diseases, variations in the size and function of the heart as well as deafness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The make-up of the cytoskeleton is also related to the pathogenicity of intracellular bacteria and viruses, particularly in the processes related to evading the actions of the immune system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ambulacral is a term typically used in the context of anatomical parts of the phylum Echinodermata or class Asteroidea and Edrioasteroidea
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Echinoderms can have ambulacral parts that include ossicles, plates, spines, and suckers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, sea stars or "star fish" have an ambulacral groove on their oral side (underside)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This ambulacral groove extends from the mouth to the end of each ray or arm
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Each groove of each arm in turn has four rows of hollow tube feet that can be extended or withdrawn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Opposite the ambulacral groove is an ambulacral ridge on the aboral side of each ray, known as an ambulacrum
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These have interambulacra between them
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acting is an activity in which a story is told by means of its enactment by an actor or actress who adopts a character—in theatre, television, film, radio, or any other medium that makes use of the mimetic mode
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acting involves a broad range of skills, including a well-developed imagination, emotional facility, physical expressivity, vocal projection, clarity of speech, and the ability to interpret drama
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acting also demands an ability to employ dialects, accents, improvisation, observation and emulation, mime, and stage combat
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many actors train at length in specialist programmes or colleges to develop these skills
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The vast majority of professional actors have undergone extensive training
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actors and actresses will often have many instructors and teachers for a full range of training involving singing, scene-work, audition techniques, and acting for camera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Most early sources in the West that examine the art of acting (Greek: ὑπόκρισις, hypokrisis) discuss it as part of rhetoric
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinia is a genus of sea anemones in the family Actiniidae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Sea anemones are a group of marine, predatory animals of the order Actiniaria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are named for the anemone, a terrestrial flowering plant, because of their colourful appearance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Sea anemones are classified in the phylum Cnidaria, class Anthozoa, subclass Hexacorallia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As cnidarians, sea anemones are related to corals, jellyfish, tube-dwelling anemones, and Hydra
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Unlike jellyfish, sea anemones do not have a medusa stage in their life cycle
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A typical sea anemone is a single polyp attached to a hard surface by its base, but some species live in soft sediment and a few float near the surface of the water
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The polyp has a columnar trunk topped by an oral disc with a ring of tentacles and a central mouth
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The tentacles can be retracted inside the body cavity or expanded to catch passing prey
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are armed with cnidocytes (stinging cells)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In many species, additional nourishment comes from a symbiotic relationship with single-celled dinoflagellates, zooxanthellae or with green algae, zoochlorellae, that live within the cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some species of sea anemone live in association with hermit crabs, small fish or other animals to their mutual benefit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Sea anemones breed by liberating sperm and eggs through the mouth into the sea
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The resulting fertilized eggs develop into planula larvae which, after being planktonic for a while, settle on the seabed and develop directly into juvenile polyps
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Sea anemones also breed asexually, by breaking in half or into smaller pieces which regenerate into polyps
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Sea anemones are sometimes kept in reef aquariums; the global trade in marine ornamentals for this purpose is expanding and threatens sea anemone populations in some localities, as the trade depends on collection from the wild
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinism () is the property of solar radiation that leads to the production of photochemical and photobiological effects
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actinism is derived from the Greek ακτίς, ακτῖνος (a ray or beam)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The word actinism is found, for example, in the terminology of imaging technology (esp
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 photography), medicine (concerning sunburn), and chemistry (concerning containers that protect from photo-degradation), and the concept of actinism is applied, for example, in chemical photography and X-ray imaging
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Actinic () chemicals include silver salts used in photography and other light sensitive chemicals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinidia  is a genus of woody and, with a few exceptions, dioecious plants native to temperate eastern Asia, occurring throughout most of China, Taiwan, Korea, and Japan, and extending north to southeast Siberia and south into Indochina
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The genus includes shrubs growing to 6 m (20 ft) tall, and vigorous, strong-growing vines, growing up to 30 m (98 ft) in tree canopies
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They mostly tolerate temperatures down to around −15°C (5°F), and some are much hardier
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The leaves are alternate and simple, with a dentated margin and a long petiole
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The flowers are solitary or in axillary cymes, usually white, with five small petals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most of the species are dioecious with separate male and female plants, but some are monoecious
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The fruit is a large berry containing numerous small seeds; in most species, the fruit is edible
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In particular, this genus is known for the species Actinidia deliciosa, the kiwifruit or Chinese gooseberry, and for the hardy ornamental A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 kolomikta
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Actinidiaceae are a small family of flowering plants commonly known as the Chinese gooseberry family
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The family has three genera and about 360 species and is a member of the order Ericales
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actiniopteris is a plant genus in the fern family Pteridaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinism () is the property of solar radiation that leads to the production of photochemical and photobiological effects
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actinism is derived from the Greek ακτίς, ακτῖνος (a ray or beam)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The word actinism is found, for example, in the terminology of imaging technology (esp
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 photography), medicine (concerning sunburn), and chemistry (concerning containers that protect from photo-degradation), and the concept of actinism is applied, for example, in chemical photography and X-ray imaging
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Actinic () chemicals include silver salts used in photography and other light sensitive chemicals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinium is a chemical element with symbol Ac and atomic number 89
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actinium gave the name to the actinide series, a group of 15 similar elements between actinium and lawrencium in the periodic table
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is also sometimes considered the first of the 7th-period transition metals, although lawrencium is less commonly given that position
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Discovered in 1899, it was the first non-primordial radioactive element to be isolated
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Polonium, radium and radon were observed before actinium, but they were not isolated until 1902
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A soft, silvery-white radioactive metal, actinium reacts rapidly with oxygen and moisture in air forming a white coating of actinium oxide that prevents further oxidation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As with most lanthanides and many actinides, actinium assumes oxidation state +3 in nearly all its chemical compounds
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actinium is found only in traces in uranium and thorium ores as the isotope 227Ac, which decays with a half-life of 21
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
772 years, predominantly emitting beta and sometimes alpha particles, and 228Ac, which is beta active with a half-life of 6
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
15 hours
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 One tonne of natural uranium in ore contains about 0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
2 milligrams of actinium-227, and one tonne of natural thorium contains about 5 nanograms of actinium-228
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The close similarity of physical and chemical properties of actinium and lanthanum makes separation of actinium from the ore impractical
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Instead, the element is prepared, in milligram amounts, by the neutron irradiation of 226Ra in a nuclear reactor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Owing to its scarcity, high price and radioactivity, actinium has no significant industrial use
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its current applications include a neutron source and an agent for radiation therapy targeting cancer cells in the body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The actinide  or actinoid  (IUPAC nomenclature) series encompasses the 15 metallic chemical elements with atomic numbers from 89 to 103, actinium through lawrencium
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Strictly speaking, both actinium and lawrencium have been labeled as group 3 elements, but both elements are often included in any general discussion of the chemistry of the actinide elements
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actinium is the more often omitted of the two, because its placement as a group 3 element is somewhat more common in texts and for semantic reasons: since "actinide" means "like actinium", it has been argued that actinium cannot logically be a actinide, even though IUPAC acknowledges its inclusion based on common usage
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The actinide series derives its name from the first element in the series, actinium
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The informal chemical symbol An is used in general discussions of actinide chemistry to refer to any actinide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 All but one of the actinides are f-block elements, with the exception being either actinium or lawrencium
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The series mostly corresponds to the filling of the 5f electron shell, although actinium and thorium lack any f-electrons, and curium and lawrencium have the same number as the proceeding element
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In comparison with the lanthanides, also mostly f-block elements, the actinides show much more variable valence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They all have very large atomic and ionic radii and exhibit an unusually large range of physical properties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 While actinium and the late actinides (from americium onwards) behave similarly to the lanthanides, the elements thorium, protactinium, and uranium are much more similar to transition metals in their chemistry, with neptunium and plutonium occupying an intermediate position
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

All actinides are radioactive and release energy upon radioactive decay; naturally occurring uranium and thorium, and synthetically produced plutonium are the most abundant actinides on Earth
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These are used in nuclear reactors and nuclear weapons
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Uranium and thorium also have diverse current or historical uses, and americium is used in the ionization chambers of most modern smoke detectors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Of the actinides, primordial thorium and uranium occur naturally in substantial quantities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The radioactive decay of uranium produces transient amounts of actinium and protactinium, and atoms of neptunium and plutonium are occasionally produced from transmutation reactions in uranium ores
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The other actinides are purely synthetic elements
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Nuclear weapons tests have released at least six actinides heavier than plutonium into the environment; analysis of debris from a 1952 hydrogen bomb explosion showed the presence of americium, curium, berkelium, californium, einsteinium and fermium
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In presentations of the periodic table, the lanthanides and the actinides are customarily shown as two additional rows below the main body of the table, with placeholders or else a selected single element of each series (either lanthanum or lutetium, and either actinium or lawrencium, respectively) shown in a single cell of the main table, between barium and hafnium, and radium and rutherfordium, respectively
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This convention is entirely a matter of aesthetics and formatting practicality; a rarely used wide-formatted periodic table inserts the lanthanide and actinide series in their proper places, as parts of the table's sixth and seventh rows (periods)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinolite is an amphibole silicate mineral with the chemical formula Ca2(Mg4
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5-2
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5Fe2+0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5-2
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
5)Si8O22(OH)2
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Verbesina, or crownbeard, is a genus of flowering plants, in the daisy family (Asteraceae)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a large genus of over 300 species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

All the species bear yellow flowers similar to small sunflowers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name Verbesina very likely refers to the similarity of the foliage to that of the (unrelated) Verbena
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Verbesina species are used as food plants by the larvae of some Lepidoptera species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These include Schinia bina, which has been recorded from V
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 encelioides, and Schinia siren which feeds exclusively on that species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinometers are instruments used to measure the heating power of radiation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are used in meteorology to measure solar radiation as pyranometers, pyrheliometers and net radiometers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An actinometer is a chemical system or physical device which determines the number of photons in a beam integrally or per unit time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This name is commonly applied to devices used in the ultraviolet and visible wavelength ranges
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, solutions of iron(III) oxalate can be used as a chemical actinometer, while bolometers, thermopiles, and photodiodes are physical devices giving a reading that can be correlated to the number of photons detected
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
A solarimeter is a pyranometer, a type of measuring device used to measure combined direct and diffuse solar radiation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An integrating solarimeter measures energy developed from solar radiation based on the absorption of heat by a black body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The principle this instrument was designed on was first developed by the Italian priest, Father Angelo Bellani
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He invented the actinometric method which is based on physical and chemical techniques
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinometers are instruments used to measure the heating power of radiation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are used in meteorology to measure solar radiation as pyranometers, pyrheliometers and net radiometers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An actinometer is a chemical system or physical device which determines the number of photons in a beam integrally or per unit time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This name is commonly applied to devices used in the ultraviolet and visible wavelength ranges
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, solutions of iron(III) oxalate can be used as a chemical actinometer, while bolometers, thermopiles, and photodiodes are physical devices giving a reading that can be correlated to the number of photons detected
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Floral symmetry describes whether, and how, a flower, in particular its perianth, can be divided into two or more identical or mirror-image parts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Uncommonly, flowers may have no axis of symmetry at all, typically because their parts are spirally arranged
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinomyces is a genus of the Actinobacteria class of bacteria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are all gram-positive
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actinomyces species are facultatively anaerobic (except A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 meyeri and A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 israelii both obligate anaerobe), and they grow best under anaerobic conditions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actinomyces species may form endospores, and, while individual bacteria are rod-shaped, Actinomyces colonies form fungus-like branched networks of hyphae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The aspect of these colonies initially led to the incorrect assumption that the organism was a fungus and to the name Actinomyces, "ray fungus" (from Greek actis, ray, beam and mykes, fungus)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Actinomyces species are ubiquitous, occurring in soil and in the microbiota of animals, including the human microbiota
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are known for the important role they play in soil ecology; they produce a number of enzymes that help degrade organic plant material, lignin, and chitin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Thus their presence is important in the formation of compost
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Certain species are commensal in the skin flora, oral flora, gut flora, and vaginal flora of humans and livestock
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are also known for causing diseases in humans and livestock, usually when they get an opportunity to gain access to the body's interior through wounds
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As with other opportunistic infections, people with immunodeficiency are at higher risk
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In all of the preceding traits and in their branching filament formation, they bear similarities to Nocardia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Like various other anaerobes, Actinomyces species are fastidious and thus not easy to culture and isolate
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Clinical laboratories do culture and isolate them, but a negative result does not rule out infection, because it may be due simply to reluctance to grow in vitro
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Actinomycetales are an order of Actinobacteria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A member of the order is often called an actinomycete
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The actinomycetes are very diverse and contain a variety of subdivisions, as well as yet-unclassified isolates, mainly because some genera are very difficult to classify because of a highly niche-dependent phenotype
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, Nocardia contains several phenotypes first believed to be distinct species before their differences were shown to be entirely dependent on their growth conditions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinomyces is a genus of the Actinobacteria class of bacteria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are all gram-positive
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actinomyces species are facultatively anaerobic (except A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 meyeri and A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 israelii both obligate anaerobe), and they grow best under anaerobic conditions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actinomyces species may form endospores, and, while individual bacteria are rod-shaped, Actinomyces colonies form fungus-like branched networks of hyphae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The aspect of these colonies initially led to the incorrect assumption that the organism was a fungus and to the name Actinomyces, "ray fungus" (from Greek actis, ray, beam and mykes, fungus)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
