 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Clinical laboratories do culture and isolate them, but a negative result does not rule out infection, because it may be due simply to reluctance to grow in vitro
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Dactinomycin, also known as actinomycin D, is a chemotherapy medication used to treat a number of types of cancer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This includes Wilms tumor, rhabdomyosarcoma, Ewing's sarcoma, trophoblastic neoplasm, testicular cancer, and certain types of ovarian cancer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is given by injection into a vein
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Most people develop side effects
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Common side effects include bone marrow suppression, vomiting, mouth ulcers, hair loss, liver problems, infections, and muscle pains
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other serious side effects include future cancers, allergic reactions, and tissue death at the site of injection
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Use in pregnancy may harm the baby
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Dactinomycin is in the cytotoxic antibiotic family of medications
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is believed to work by blocking the creation of RNA
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Dactinomycin was approved for medical use in the United States in 1964
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is on the World Health Organization's List of Essential Medicines, the most effective and safe medicines needed in a health system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The wholesale cost in the developing world is about 24
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
73 USD per 500 mcg vial
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is produced from bacteria Streptomyces parvullus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinomycosis is a rare infectious bacterial disease caused by Actinomyces species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 About 70% of infections are due to either Actinomyces israelii or A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 gerencseriae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Infection can also be caused by other Actinomyces species, as well as Propionibacterium propionicus, which presents similar symptoms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The condition is likely to be polymicrobial aerobic anaerobic infection
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actinomycosis is a rare infectious bacterial disease caused by Actinomyces species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 About 70% of infections are due to either Actinomyces israelii or A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 gerencseriae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Infection can also be caused by other Actinomyces species, as well as Propionibacterium propionicus, which presents similar symptoms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The condition is likely to be polymicrobial aerobic anaerobic infection
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Max Auerbach (26 January 1879 in Elberfeld – 21 November 1968 in Karlsruhe-Durlach) was a German zoologist known for his research of Cnidospora
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

From 1897 to 1902, he studied medicine and zoology at the University of Basel, where following graduation, he served as an assistant to Friedrich Zschokke (1860–1936)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Soon afterwards, he obtained his habilitation in zoology and anthropology at the Technischen Hochschule Karlsruhe (1904)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Karlsruhe, he gave lectures at the technical school (until 1934) and also at the Hochschule der Bildenden Künste Karlsruhe (1926–1945)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In 1918 he was named director of the Badische Landessammlungen für Naturkunde (Baden State Collections of Natural History), and during the following year, founded the Anstalt für Bodenseeforschung der Stadt Konstanz (Max Auerbach Institute) in Konstanz
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An amoeba (/əˈmiːbə/; rarely spelled amœba, US English rarely spelled ameba; plural am(o)ebas or am(o)ebae /əˈmiːbiː/), often called amoeboid, is a type of cell or organism which has the ability to alter its shape, primarily by extending and retracting pseudopods
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Amoebas do not form a single taxonomic group; instead, they are found in every major lineage of eukaryotic organisms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Amoeboid cells occur not only among the protozoa, but also in fungi, algae, and animals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Microbiologists often use the terms "amoeboid" and "amoeba" interchangeably for any organism that exhibits amoeboid movement
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In older classification systems, most amoebas were placed in the class or subphylum Sarcodina, a grouping of single-celled organisms that possess pseudopods or move by protoplasmic flow
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, molecular phylogenetic studies have shown that Sarcodina is not a monophyletic group whose members share common descent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Consequently, amoeboid organisms are no longer classified together in one group
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The best known amoeboid protists are the "giant amoebae" Chaos carolinense and Amoeba proteus, both of which are widely cultivated and studied in classrooms and laboratories
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other well known species include the so-called "brain-eating amoeba" Naegleria fowleri, the intestinal parasite Entamoeba histolytica, which causes amoebic dysentery, and the multicellular "social amoeba" or slime mould Dictyostelium discoideum
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An amoeba (/əˈmiːbə/; rarely spelled amœba, US English rarely spelled ameba; plural am(o)ebas or am(o)ebae /əˈmiːbiː/), often called amoeboid, is a type of cell or organism which has the ability to alter its shape, primarily by extending and retracting pseudopods
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Amoebas do not form a single taxonomic group; instead, they are found in every major lineage of eukaryotic organisms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Amoeboid cells occur not only among the protozoa, but also in fungi, algae, and animals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Microbiologists often use the terms "amoeboid" and "amoeba" interchangeably for any organism that exhibits amoeboid movement
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In older classification systems, most amoebas were placed in the class or subphylum Sarcodina, a grouping of single-celled organisms that possess pseudopods or move by protoplasmic flow
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, molecular phylogenetic studies have shown that Sarcodina is not a monophyletic group whose members share common descent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Consequently, amoeboid organisms are no longer classified together in one group
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In the law, a cause of action is a set of facts sufficient to justify a right to sue to obtain money, property, or the enforcement of a right against another party
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term also refers to the legal theory upon which a plaintiff brings suit (such as breach of contract, battery, or false imprisonment)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The legal document which carries a claim is often called a Statement of Claim in English law, or a Complaint in U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 federal practice and in many U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 states
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can be any communication notifying the party to whom it is addressed of an alleged fault which resulted in damages, often expressed in amount of money the receiving party should pay/reimburse
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

To pursue a cause of action, a plaintiff pleads or alleges facts in a complaint, the pleading that initiates a lawsuit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A cause of action generally encompasses both the legal theory (the legal wrong the plaintiff claims to have suffered) and the remedy (the relief a court is asked to grant)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Often the facts or circumstances that entitle a person to seek judicial relief may create multiple causes of action
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although it is fairly straightforward to file a Statement of Claim in most jurisdictions, if it is not done properly, then the filing party may lose his case due to simple technicalities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There are a number of specific causes of action, including: contract-based actions; statutory causes of action; torts such as assault, battery, invasion of privacy, fraud, slander, negligence, intentional infliction of emotional distress; and suits in equity such as unjust enrichment and quantum meruit
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The points a plaintiff must prove to win a given type of case are called the "elements" of that cause of action
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, for a claim of negligence, the elements are: the (existence of a) duty, breach (of that duty), proximate cause (by that breach), and damages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 If a complaint does not allege facts sufficient to support every element of a claim, the court, upon motion by the opposing party, may dismiss the complaint for failure to state a claim for which relief can be granted
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The defendant to a cause of action must file an "Answer" to the complaint in which the claims can be admitted or denied (including denial on the basis of insufficient information in the complaint to form a response)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The answer may also contain counterclaims in which the "Counterclaim Plaintiff" states its own causes of action
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Finally, the answer may contain affirmative defenses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most defenses must be raised at the first possible opportunity either in the answer or by motion or are deemed waived
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A few defenses, in particular a court's lack of subject matter jurisdiction, need not be pleaded and may be raised at any time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actitis is a small genus of waders, comprising just two very similar bird species:
Common sandpiper, Actitis hypoleucos, of Eurasia
Spotted sandpiper, Actitis macularia of North America
The genus name Actitis is from Ancient Greek aktites, "coast-dweller" from akte, "coast"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

These are both small migratory waders, greyish brown on top and white underneath, with a distinctive stiff-winged flight low over the water
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The plumages are very similar, apart from spotted sandpipers' distinctive breeding plumage, and suspected out-of-range vagrants must be carefully observed for identification to species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Both species have short yellow or yellowish legs and a medium bill
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These are not gregarious birds and are seldom seen in large flocks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

They nest on the ground, and their habitat is near fresh water
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These birds forage on the ground or in water, picking up food by sight
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They may also catch insects in flight
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They eat insects, crustaceans and other invertebrates
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Actitis is part of the shank-tattler-phalarope clade and less closely related to the calidrid sandpipers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Based on the degree of DNA sequence divergence and putative shank and phalarope fossils from around the Oligocene/Miocene boundary some 23-22 million years ago, presumably Actitis diverged from its closest relatives in the Late Oligocene; given the much higher diversity of the prehistoric members of the group in Eurasia it is likely that they originated there, possibly being isolated as the remains of the Turgai Sea dried up, which happened just around this time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Late Pliocene fossil described as Actitis balcanica  appears to be actually from some indeterminate charadriid
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actium (Greek: Ἄκτιον) was the name of an ancient town on a promontory of western Greece in northwestern Acarnania, at the mouth of the Ambracian Gulf)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actium is chiefly famous as the name given to the nearby naval Battle of Actium, in which Octavian won a decisive victory over Mark Antony on September 2, 31 BC
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Actium was situated on the southern side of the strait opposite the later city of Nicopolis built by Octavian
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Since 2002 the peninsular of Actium has been linked with Preveza on the north shore of the Ambracian Gulf by the Aktio-Preveza Undersea Tunnel
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"Activated" is a song by English singer Cher Lloyd for her upcoming third studio album
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was released on 22 July 2016 through Vixen Records
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The song was made available to stream exclusively on Rolling Stone on 21 July 2016
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The reticular activating system (RAS), also known as the extrathalamic control modulatory system, is a set of connected nuclei in the brains of vertebrates that is responsible for regulating wakefulness and sleep-wake transitions, and also for promoting motor control of posture
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a part of the reticular formation, and includes other brainstem nuclei including the locus coeruleus and some of the raphe nuclei
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The reticular activation system includes ascending pathways to the cortex in the ascending reticular activating system, and descending pathways to the spinal cord in the descending reticular activating system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Activation in (bio-)chemical sciences generally refers to the process whereby something is prepared or excited for a subsequent reaction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The following is a list of ongoing armed conflicts that are taking place around the world and continue to result in violence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Activism consists of efforts to promote, impede, or direct social, political, economic, or environmental reform or stasis with the desire to make improvements in society
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Forms of activism range from writing letters to newspapers or to politicians, political campaigning, economic activism such as boycotts or preferentially patronizing businesses, rallies, street marches, strikes, sit-ins, and hunger strikes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

One can also express activism through different forms of art (artivism)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Daily acts of protest such as not buying clothes from a certain clothing company because they exploit workers is another form of activism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 One view holds that acknowledging privileges and oppressions on a daily basis ranks as a form of activism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Research has begun to explore how activist groups use social media to facilitate civic engagement and collective action
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Online Etymology Dictionary records the English words "activism" and "activist" (in the political sense) from 1920 and from 1915 respectively
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Activism consists of efforts to promote, impede, or direct social, political, economic, or environmental reform or stasis with the desire to make improvements in society
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
A myofibril (also known as a muscle fibril) is a basic rod-like unit of a muscle cell
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Muscles are composed of tubular cells called myocytes, known as muscle fibers in striated muscle, and these cells in turn contain many chains of myofibrils
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are created during embryonic development in a process known as myogenesis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Myofibrils are composed of long proteins including actin, myosin, and titin, and other proteins that hold them together
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These proteins are organized into thick and thin filaments called myofilaments, which repeat along the length of the myofibril in sections called sarcomeres
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Muscles contract by sliding the thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments along each other
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An actor (often actress for females; see terminology) is a person who portrays a character in a performance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The actor performs "in the flesh" in the traditional medium of the theatre, or in modern mediums such as film, radio, and television
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The analogous Greek term is ὑποκριτής (hupokritḗs), literally "one who answers"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The actor's interpretation of their role pertains to the role played, whether based on a real person or fictional character
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Interpretation occurs even when the actor is "playing themselves", as in some forms of experimental performance art, or, more commonly; to act, is to create, a character in performance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Formerly, in some societies, only men could become actors, and women's roles were generally played by men or boys
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When used for the stage, women occasionally played the roles of prepubescent boys
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An actor (often actress for females; see terminology) is a person who portrays a character in a performance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acts of the Apostles (Ancient Greek: Πράξεις τῶν Ἀποστόλων, Práxeis tôn Apostólōn; Latin: Actūs Apostolōrum), often referred to simply as Acts, is the fifth book of the New Testament; it tells of the founding of the Christian church and the spread of its message to the Roman Empire
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acts and the Gospel of Luke make up a two-part work, Luke–Acts, by the same anonymous author, usually dated to around 80–90 AD
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The first part, the Gospel of Luke, tells how God fulfilled his plan for the world's salvation through the life, death, and resurrection of Jesus of Nazareth, the promised Messiah
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acts continues the story of Christianity in the 1st century, beginning with Jesus's Ascension to Heaven
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The early chapters, set in Jerusalem, describe the Day of Pentecost (the coming of the Holy Spirit) and the growth of the church in Jerusalem
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Initially, the Jews are receptive to the Christian message, but soon they turn against the followers of Jesus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Rejected by the Jews, under the guidance of the Apostle Peter the message is taken to the Gentiles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The later chapters tell of Paul's conversion, his mission in Asia Minor and the Aegean, and finally his imprisonment in Rome, where, as the book ends, he awaits trial
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Luke–Acts is an attempt to answer a theological problem, namely how the Messiah of the Jews came to have an overwhelmingly non-Jewish church; the answer it provides, and its central theme, is that the message of Christ was sent to the Gentiles because the Jews rejected it
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Luke–Acts can be also seen as a defense of (or "apology" for) the Jesus movement addressed to the Jews: the bulk of the speeches and sermons in Acts are addressed to Jewish audiences, with the Romans featuring as external arbiters on disputes concerning Jewish customs and law
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 On the one hand Luke portrays the Christians as a sect of the Jews, and therefore entitled to legal protection as a recognised religion; on the other, Luke seems unclear as to the future God intends for Jews and Christians, celebrating the Jewishness of Jesus and his immediate followers while also stressing how the Jews had rejected God's promised Messiah
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) is the largest peak body representing workers in Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a national trade union centre of 46 affiliated unions and nine trades and labour councils
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The ACTU is a member of the International Trade Union Confederation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The current President of the ACTU is Ged Kearney, and the current Secretary is Sally McManus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Not the Actual Events is an extended play by American industrial rock band Nine Inch Nails
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was released physically on December 23, 2016, under Trent Reznor's own label The Null Corporation, while those who had pre-ordered received a download link a day early
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The second Nine Inch Nails EP of original material following Broken in 1992, it marks long-time collaborator Atticus Ross's first appearance as an official member of the band
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The digital pre-orders included a "physical component" that was shipped in early March 2017
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In June 2017, in an email that was issued out to customers waiting on delayed vinyl orders, Reznor confirmed that Not The Actual Events would actually make up the first part of a trilogy of EPs, with the second installment entitled Add Violence being released July 2017, and the third and final EP of the trilogy expected by the end of 2017
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In philosophy, potentiality and actuality are principles of a dichotomy which Aristotle used to analyze motion, causality, ethics, and physiology in his Physics, Metaphysics, Nicomachean Ethics and De Anima, which is about the human psyche
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The concept of potentiality, in this context, generally refers to any "possibility" that a thing can be said to have
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aristotle did not consider all possibilities the same, and emphasized the importance of those that become real of their own accord when conditions are right and nothing stops them
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actuality, in contrast to potentiality, is the motion, change or activity that represents an exercise or fulfillment of a possibility, when a possibility becomes real in the fullest sense
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

These concepts, in modified forms, remained very important into the middle ages, influencing the development of medieval theology in several ways
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Going further into modern times, while the understanding of nature and, according to some interpretations, deity implied by the dichotomy lost importance, the terminology has found new uses, developing indirectly from the old
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This is most obvious in words like "energy" and "dynamic"--words first used in modern physics by the German scientist and philosopher, Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Another example is the biological concept of an "entelechy"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Self-actualization is a term that has been used in various psychology theories, often in slightly different ways
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term was originally introduced by the organismic theorist Kurt Goldstein for the motive to realize one's full potential
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Expressing one's creativity, quest for spiritual enlightenment, pursuit of knowledge, and the desire to give to and/or positively transform society are examples of self-actualization
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Goldstein's view, it is the organism's master motive, the only real motive: "the tendency to actualize itself as fully as possible is the basic drive
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 the drive of self-actualization
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
" Carl Rogers similarly wrote of "the curative force in psychotherapy – man's tendency to actualize himself, to become his potentialities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 to express and activate all the capacities of the organism
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
" The concept was brought most fully to prominence in Abraham Maslow's hierarchy of needs theory as the final level of psychological development that can be achieved when all basic and mental needs are essentially fulfilled and the "actualization" of the full personal potential takes place, although he adapted this viewpoint later on in life, and saw it more flexibly
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Self-actualization can be seen as similar to words and concepts such as self-discovery, self-reflection, self-realization and self-exploration
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

As Abraham Maslow noted, the basic needs of humans must be met (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 food, shelter, warmth, security, sense of belonging) before a person can achieve self-actualization – the need to be good, to be fully alive and to find meaning in life
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Yet, Maslow argued that reaching a state of true self-actualization in everyday society was fairly rare
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Research shows that when people live lives that are different from their true nature and capabilities, they are less likely to be happy than those whose goals and lives match
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, someone who has inherent potential to be a great artist or teacher may never realize his/her talents if their energy is focused on attaining the basic needs of humans
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actually (stylised as Pet Shop Boys, actually
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
) is the second album by English pop duo Pet Shop Boys, released on 7 September 1987 by Parlophone in the United Kingdom and by EMI Manhattan in the United States and Canada
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 According to Neil Tennant and music historian Wayne Studer, the album is a loose critique of Thatcherism, the political zeitgeist of the 1980s, and had been recorded in anticipation of Margaret Thatcher's re-election
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Actually is featured in the 2005 musical reference book 1001 Albums You Must Hear Before You Die, and in 2006 Q magazine placed the album at No
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 22 in its list of "40 Best Albums of the '80s"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2012 Slant Magazine listed the album at No
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 88 on its list of "Best Albums of the 1980s"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Actuarial science is the discipline that applies mathematical and statistical methods to assess risk in insurance, finance and other industries and professions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Actuaries are professionals who are qualified in this field through intense education and experience
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In many countries, actuaries must demonstrate their competence by passing a series of rigorous professional examinations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Actuarial science includes a number of interrelated subjects, including mathematics, probability theory, statistics, finance, economics, and computer science
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Historically, actuarial science used deterministic models in the construction of tables and premiums
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The science has gone through revolutionary changes during the last 30 years due to the proliferation of high speed computers and the union of stochastic actuarial models with modern financial theory (Frees 1990)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Many universities have undergraduate and graduate degree programs in actuarial science
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2010, a study published by job search website CareerCast ranked actuary as the #1 job in the United States (Needleman 2010)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The study used five key criteria to rank jobs: environment, income, employment outlook, physical demands, and stress
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A similar study by U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 News & World Report in 2006 included actuaries among the 25 Best Professions that it expects will be in great demand in the future (Nemko 2006)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The actuarial credentialing and exam process usually requires passing a rigorous series of professional examinations, most often taking several years in total, before one can become recognized as a credentialed actuary
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In some countries, such as Denmark, most study takes place in a university setting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In others, such as the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, most study takes place during employment through a series of examinations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the UK, and countries based on its process, there is a hybrid university-exam structure
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An actuator is a component of a machine that is responsible for moving or controlling a mechanism or system, for example by actuating (opening or closing) a valve; in simple terms, it is a "mover"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An actuator requires a control signal and a source of energy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The control signal is relatively low energy and may be electric voltage or current, pneumatic or hydraulic pressure, or even human power
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The supplied main energy source may be electric current, hydraulic fluid pressure, or pneumatic pressure
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When the control signal is received, the actuator responds by converting the energy into mechanical motion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An actuator is the mechanism by which a control system acts upon an environment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The control system can be simple (a fixed mechanical or electronic system), software-based (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 a printer driver, robot control system), a human, or any other input
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Achim (German pronunciation: [ˈaxɪm]) is a municipality and the largest town (population 30
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
059 (December 2006)) in the district of Verden, in Lower Saxony, Germany
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is situated on the right bank of the Weser, approx
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 17 km northwest of Verden, and 16 km southeast of Bremen
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acraea (Ancient Greek: Ἀκραία) was a name that had several uses in Greek and Roman mythology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acraea was a daughter of the river-god Asterion near Mycenae, who together with her sisters Euboea and Prosymna (Πρόσυμνα) acted as nurses to Hera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A hill Acraea opposite the temple of Hera near Mycenae derived its name from her
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acraea and Acraeus are also epithets given to various goddesses and gods whose temples were situated upon hills, such as Zeus, Hera, Aphrodite, Pallas, Artemis, and others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aculeata is a subclade of Hymenoptera
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name is a reference to the defining feature of the group, which is the modification of the ovipositor into a stinger (thus, the group could be called "stinging wasps", though the group also contains the ants and the bees)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In other words, the structure that was originally used to lay eggs is modified instead to deliver venom
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Not all members of the group can sting; a great many cannot, either because the ovipositor is modified in a different manner (such as for laying eggs in crevices), or because it is lost altogether
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

This group includes the bees and ants and all of the eusocial Hymenopterans
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is commonly believed that the possession of a venomous sting was one of the important features promoting the evolution of social behavior, as it confers a level of anti-predator defense rarely approached by other invertebrates
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name is a reference to the defining feature of the group, which is the modification of the ovipositor into a stinger (thus, the group could be called "stinging wasps", though the group also contains the ants and the bees)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Butterfly Cluster (cataloged as Messier 6 or M6, and as NGC 6405) is an open cluster of stars in the constellation of Scorpius
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its name derives from the vague resemblance of its shape to a butterfly
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The first astronomer to record the Butterfly Cluster's existence was Giovanni Battista Hodierna in 1654
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, Robert Burnham, Jr
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 has proposed that the 1st century astronomer Ptolemy may have seen it with the naked eye while observing its neighbor the Ptolemy Cluster (M7)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Charles Messier catalogued the cluster as M6 in 1764 and it wasn't till the 20th century that star counts, distance, and other properties were measured
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Tapering to a long point, such as in the shape of leaves or other botanical features such as the stamen filaments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Tapering to a long point, such as in the shape of leaves or other botanical features such as the stamen filaments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Baimaclia is a commune in Cantemir District, Moldova
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is composed of three villages: Acui, Baimaclia and Suhat
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acupressure [from Latin acus "needle" (see acuity) + pressure (n
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
)] is an alternative medicine technique similar in principle to acupuncture
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is based on the concept of life energy which flows through "meridians" in the body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In treatment, physical pressure is applied to acupuncture points with the aim of clearing blockages in these meridians
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Pressure may be applied by hand, by elbow, or with various devices
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Some medical studies have suggested that acupressure may be effective at helping manage nausea and vomiting, for helping lower back pain, tension headaches, stomach ache, among other things, although such studies have been found to have a high likelihood of bias
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Like many alternative medicines, it may benefit from a placebo effect
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

According to Quackwatch, acupressure is a dubious practice and its practitioners use irrational methods
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Acupuncture is a form of alternative medicine in which thin needles are inserted into the body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a key component of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 TCM theory and practice are not based upon scientific knowledge, and acupuncture is a pseudoscience
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are a diverse range of acupuncture theories based on different philosophies, and techniques vary depending on the country
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The method used in TCM is likely the most widespread in the US
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is most often used for pain relief, though it is also used for a wide range of other conditions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acupuncture is generally used only in combination with other forms of treatment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The conclusions of many trials and numerous systematic reviews of acupuncture are largely inconsistent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An overview of Cochrane reviews found that acupuncture is not effective for a wide range of conditions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A systematic review of systematic reviews found little evidence of acupuncture's effectiveness in treating pain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The evidence suggests that short-term treatment with acupuncture does not produce long-term benefits
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some research results suggest acupuncture can alleviate pain, though the majority of research suggests that acupuncture's effects are mainly due to the placebo effect
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A systematic review concluded that the analgesic effect of acupuncture seemed to lack clinical relevance and could not be clearly distinguished from bias
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A meta-analysis found that acupuncture for chronic low back pain was cost-effective as an adjunct to standard care, while a systematic review found insufficient evidence for the cost-effectiveness of acupuncture in the treatment of chronic low back pain
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Acupuncture is generally safe when done by an appropriately trained practitioner using clean needle technique and single-use needles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When properly delivered, it has a low rate of mostly minor adverse effects
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Accidents and infections are associated with infractions of sterile technique or neglect of the practitioner
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A review stated that the reports of infection transmission increased significantly in the prior decade
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The most frequently reported adverse events were pneumothorax and infections
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Since serious adverse events continue to be reported, it is recommended that acupuncturists be trained sufficiently to reduce the risk
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Scientific investigation has not found any histological or physiological evidence for traditional Chinese concepts such as qi, meridians, and acupuncture points, and many modern practitioners no longer support the existence of life force energy (qi) flowing through meridians, which was a major part of early belief systems
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acupuncture is believed to have originated around 100 BC in China, around the time The Yellow Emperor's Classic of Internal Medicine (Huangdi Neijing) was published, though some experts suggest it could have been practiced earlier
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Over time, conflicting claims and belief systems emerged about the effect of lunar, celestial and earthly cycles, yin and yang energies, and a body's "rhythm" on the effectiveness of treatment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acupuncture grew and diminished in popularity in China repeatedly, depending on the country's political leadership and the favor of rationalism or Western medicine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acupuncture spread first to Korea in the 6th century AD, then to Japan through medical missionaries, and then to Europe, starting with France
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the 20th century, as it spread to the United States and Western countries, the spiritual elements of acupuncture that conflict with Western beliefs were abandoned in favor of tapping needles into nerves
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In photography, the term "acutance" describes a subjective perception of sharpness that is related to the edge contrast of an image
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acutance is related to the amplitude of the derivative of brightness with respect to space
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Due to the nature of the human visual system, an image with higher acutance appears sharper even though an increase in acutance does not increase real resolution
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Historically, acutance was enhanced chemically during development of a negative (High Acutance Developers), or by optical means in printing (Unsharp Masking)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In digital photography, onboard camera software and image postprocessing tools such as Photoshop or GIMP offer various sharpening facilities, the most widely used of which is known as "unsharp mask" because the algorithm is derived from the eponymous analog processing method
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the example image, two light gray lines were drawn on a gray background
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As the transition is instantaneous, the line is as sharp as can be represented at this resolution
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acutance in the left line was artificially increased by adding a one-pixel-wide darker border on the outside of the line and a one-pixel-wide brighter border on the inside of the line
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The actual sharpness of the image is unchanged, but the apparent sharpness is increased because of the greater acutance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Artificially increased acutance has drawbacks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In this somewhat overdone example most viewers will also be able to see the borders separately from the line, which create two halos around the line, one dark and one shimmering bright
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In photography, the term "acutance" describes a subjective perception of sharpness that is related to the edge contrast of an image
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Acutance is related to the amplitude of the derivative of brightness with respect to space
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Due to the nature of the human visual system, an image with higher acutance appears sharper even though an increase in acutance does not increase real resolution
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Historically, acutance was enhanced chemically during development of a negative (High Acutance Developers), or by optical means in printing (Unsharp Masking)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In digital photography, onboard camera software and image postprocessing tools such as Photoshop or GIMP offer various sharpening facilities, the most widely used of which is known as "unsharp mask" because the algorithm is derived from the eponymous analog processing method
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the example image, two light gray lines were drawn on a gray background
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aciclovir (ACV), also known as acyclovir, is an antiviral medication
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is primarily used for the treatment of herpes simplex virus infections, chickenpox, and shingles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other uses include prevention of cytomegalovirus infections following transplant and severe complications of Epstein-Barr virus infection
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It can be taken by mouth, applied as a cream, or injected
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Common side effects include nausea and diarrhea
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Potentially serious side effects include kidney problems and low platelets
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Greater care is recommended in those with poor liver or kidney function
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is generally considered safe for use in pregnancy with no harm having been observed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It appears to be safe during breastfeeding
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aciclovir is a nucleic acid analogue made from guanosine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It works by decreasing the production of the virus's DNA
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The discovery of aciclovir was announced in 1977
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is on the World Health Organization's List of Essential Medicines, the safest and most effective medicines needed in a health system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is available as a generic medication and is marketed under many brand names worldwide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The wholesale cost as of 2014 to 2016 was between US$0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
03 and US$0
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
12 for a typical dose by mouth
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The cost of a typical course of treatment in the United States is less than US$25
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The terms anno Domini (AD) and before Christ (BC) are used to label or number years in the Julian and Gregorian calendars
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term anno Domini is Medieval Latin and means "in the year of the Lord", but is often translated as "in the year of our Lord"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

This calendar era is based on the traditionally reckoned year of the conception or birth of Jesus of Nazareth, with AD counting years from the start of this epoch, and BC denoting years before the start of the era
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There is no year zero in this scheme, so the year AD 1 immediately follows the year 1 BC
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This dating system was devised in 525 by Dionysius Exiguus of Scythia Minor, but was not widely used until after 800
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Gregorian calendar is the most widely used calendar in the world today
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For decades, it has been the unofficial global standard, adopted in the pragmatic interests of international communication, transportation, and commercial integration, and recognized by international institutions such as the United Nations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Traditionally, English followed Latin usage by placing the "AD" abbreviation before the year number
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, BC is placed after the year number (for example: AD 2017, but 68 BC), which also preserves syntactic order
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The abbreviation is also widely used after the number of a century or millennium, as in "fourth century AD" or "second millennium AD" (although conservative usage formerly rejected such expressions)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Because BC is the English abbreviation for Before Christ, it is sometimes incorrectly concluded that AD means After Death, i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, after the death of Jesus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, this would mean that the approximate 33 years commonly associated with the life of Jesus would not be included in either of the BC and the AD time scales
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Terminology that is viewed by some as being more neutral and inclusive of non-Christian people is to call this the Current or Common Era (abbreviated as CE), with the preceding years referred to as Before the Common or Current Era (BCE)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Astronomical year numbering and ISO 8601 avoid words or abbreviations related to Christianity, but use the same numbers for AD years
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ad libitum () is Latin for "at one's pleasure" or "as you desire"; it is often shortened to "ad lib" (as an adjective or adverb) or "ad-lib" (as a verb or noun)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The roughly synonymous phrase a bene placito ("in accordance with [one's] good pleasure") is less common but, in its Italian form a piacere, entered the musical lingua franca (see below)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The phrase "at liberty" is often associated mnemonically (because of the alliteration of the lib- syllable), although it is not the translation (there is no cognation between libitum and liber)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Libido is the etymologically closer cognate known in English
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Agdistis is a genus of moth in the Pterophoridae family and only genus in the Agdistinae subfamily
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adam (Hebrew: אָדָם‎‎ [ʼādām]; Arabic: آدَم [ãdam]; Greek: Αδάμ [Athām/ Adām]) is the name used in the opening chapters of the Book of Genesis for the first man created by God, but it is also used in a collective sense as "mankind" and individually as "a human"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Biblical Adam (man, mankind) is created from adamah (earth), and Genesis 1-8 makes considerable play of the bond between them, for Adam is estranged from the earth through his disobedience
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adana (pronounced [aˈda
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
na]; Armenian: Ադանա) is a major city in southern Turkey
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The city is situated on the Seyhan river, 35 km (22 mi) inland from the Mediterranean, in south-central Anatolia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is the administrative seat of the Adana Province and has a population of 1
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
7 million, making it the fifth most populous city in Turkey
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Adana-Mersin polycentric metropolitan area, with a population of 3 million, stretches over 70 km (43 mi) east-west and 25 km (16 mi) north-south; encompassing the cities of Mersin, Tarsus and Adana
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adana lies in the heart of Çukurova, a geo-cultural region alternatively known as Cilicia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Home to six million people, Çukurova is one of the largest population concentrations in Turkey, as well as the most agriculturally productive area, owing to its large stretch of flat, fertile land
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The region includes the provinces of Mersin, Adana, Osmaniye, and Hatay
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An adage (; Latin: adagium) is a short, usually philosophical, but memorable saying which holds some important fact of experience that is considered true by many people, or that has gained some credibility through its long memetic use
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

It often involves a planning failure such as "don't count your chickens before they hatch" or "don't burn your bridges"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adages may be interesting observations, practical or ethical guidelines, or skeptical comments on life
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Some adages are products of folk wisdom that attempt to summarize some form of basic truth; these are generally known as proverbs or bywords
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An adage that describes a general rule of conduct is a "maxim"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A pithy expression that has not necessarily gained credit through long use, but is distinguished by particular depth or good style is an aphorism, while one distinguished by wit or irony is an epigram
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Through overuse, an adage may become a cliché or truism, or be described as an "old saw
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
" Adages coined in modernity are often given proper names and called "laws" in imitation of physical laws, or "principles"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some adages, such as Murphy's Law, are first formulated informally and given proper names later, while others, such as the Peter Principle, have proper names in their initial formulation; it might be argued that the latter sort does not represent "true" adages, but the two types are often difficult to distinguish
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adages which were collected and used by ancient writers in their work and writings inspired the Dutch humanist scholar Desiderius Erasmus to publish his own collection
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He would revise his moderate volume of 800 adages multiple times until the final edition of Adagia published in 1536 included over 4,000
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There have been many such collections since, usually in vernacular languages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adages formulated in popular works of fiction often find their way into popular culture, especially when there exists a subculture devoted to the work or its genre, as is the case with science fiction novels
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Many professions and subcultures create their own adages, which may be seen as a sort of jargon; such adages may find their way into popular usage, sometimes becoming altered in the process
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Online communities, such as those that develop in Internet forums or Usenet newsgroups, are known for generating their own adages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adam (Hebrew: אָדָם‎‎ [ʼādām]; Arabic: آدَم [ãdam]; Greek: Αδάμ [Athām/ Adām]) is the name used in the opening chapters of the Book of Genesis for the first man created by God, but it is also used in a collective sense as "mankind" and individually as "a human"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Biblical Adam (man, mankind) is created from adamah (earth), and Genesis 1-8 makes considerable play of the bond between them, for Adam is estranged from the earth through his disobedience
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adamant and similar words are used to refer to any especially hard substance, whether composed of diamond, some other gemstone, or some type of metal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Both adamant and diamond derive from the Greek word ἀδάμας, ἀδάμαντος (adamas, adamantos), meaning "untameable"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adamantite and adamantium (a metallic name derived from the Neo-Latin ending -ium) are also common variants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adamantine has, throughout ancient history, referred to anything that was made of a very hard material
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Virgil describes Tartarus as having a screeching gate protected by columns of solid adamantine (Aeneid book VI)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Later, by the Middle Ages, the term came to refer to diamond, as it was the hardest material then known
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

It was in the Middle Ages, too, that adamantine hardness and the lodestone's magnetic properties became confused and combined, leading to an alternate definition in which "adamant" means magnet, falsely derived from the Latin adamare, which means to love or be attached to
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Another connection was the belief that adamant (the diamond definition) could block the effects of a magnet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This was addressed in chapter III of Pseudodoxia Epidemica, for instance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Since the word diamond is now used for the hardest gemstone, the increasingly archaic term "adamant" has a mostly poetic or figurative use
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In that capacity, the name is frequently used in popular media and fiction to refer to a very hard substance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adamant and similar words are used to refer to any especially hard substance, whether composed of diamond, some other gemstone, or some type of metal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Both adamant and diamond derive from the Greek word ἀδάμας, ἀδάμαντος (adamas, adamantos), meaning "untameable"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adamantite and adamantium (a metallic name derived from the Neo-Latin ending -ium) are also common variants

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In that capacity, the name is frequently used in popular media and fiction to refer to a very hard substance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Baobab is the common name for each of the nine species of tree in the genus Adansonia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The generic name honours Michel Adanson, the French naturalist and explorer who described Adansonia digitata
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Of the nine species, six are native to Madagascar, two are native to mainland Africa and the Arabian Peninsula, and one is native to Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 One of the mainland African species also occurs on Madagascar, but it is not a native of that island
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was introduced in ancient times to south Asia and during the colonial era to the Caribbean
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is also present in the island nation of Cape Verde
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The ninth species was described in 2012, and is found in upland populations of southern and eastern Africa
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The African and Australian baobabs are almost identical despite having separated more than 100 million years ago, probably by oceanic dispersal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Baobabs reach heights of 5 to 30 m (16 to 98 ft) and have trunk diameters of 7 to 11 m (23 to 36 ft)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Glencoe baobab, a specimen of A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 digitata in Limpopo Province, South Africa, was considered to be the largest living individual, with a maximum circumference of 47 m (154 ft) and a diameter of about 15
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
9 m (52 ft)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The tree has since split into two parts, so the widest individual trunk may now be that of the Sunland baobab, or Platland tree, also in South Africa
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The diameter of this tree at ground level is 9
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
3 m (31 ft) and its circumference at breast height is 34 m (112 ft)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adansonia trees produce faint growth rings, probably annually, but they are not reliable for aging specimens, because they are difficult to count and may fade away as the wood ages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Radiocarbon dating has provided data on a few individuals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A specimen of A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 digitata known as Grootboom was dated and found to be at least 1275 years old, making it one of the oldest known angiosperm trees
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adapa, the first of the Mesopotamian seven sages (apkallu), was a mythical figure who unknowingly refused the gift of immortality
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The story is first attested in the Kassite period (14th century BC), in fragmentary tablets from Tell el-Amarna, and from Assur, of the late second millennium BC
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Mesopotamian myth tells of seven antediluvian sages, who were sent by Ea, the wise god of Eridu, to bring the arts of civilisation to humankind
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The first of these, Adapa, also known as Uan, the name given as Oannes by Berossus, introduced the practice of the correct rites of religious observance as priest of the E'Apsu temple, at Eridu
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The sages are described in Mesopotamian literature as 'pure parādu-fish, probably carp, whose bones are found associated with the earliest shrine, and still kept as a holy duty in the precincts of Near Eastern mosques and monasteries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adapa as a fisherman was iconographically portrayed as a fish-man composite
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adaptability (Latin: adaptō "fit to, adjust") is a feature of a system or of a process
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This word has been put to use as a specialised term in different disciplines and in business operations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Word definitions of adaptability as a specialised term differ little from dictionary definitions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 According to Andresen and Gronau adaptability in the field of organizational management can in general be seen as an ability to change something or oneself to fit to occurring changes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In ecology, adaptability has been described as the ability to cope with unexpected disturbances in the environment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

With respect to business and manufacturing systems and processes adaptability has come to be seen increasingly as an important factor for their efficiency and economic success
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In contrast, adaptability and efficiency are held to be in opposition to each other in biological and ecological systems, requiring a trade-off, since both are important factors in the success of such systems
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 To determine the adaptability of a process or a system, it should be validated concerning some criteria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adaptability (Latin: adaptō "fit to, adjust") is a feature of a system or of a process
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This word has been put to use as a specialised term in different disciplines and in business operations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Word definitions of adaptability as a specialised term differ little from dictionary definitions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
