 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In contrast, adaptability and efficiency are held to be in opposition to each other in biological and ecological systems, requiring a trade-off, since both are important factors in the success of such systems
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 To determine the adaptability of a process or a system, it should be validated concerning some criteria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In biology, adaptation has three related meanings
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Firstly it is the dynamic evolutionary process that fits a population of organisms to their environment, enhancing their evolutionary fitness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Secondly, it is a state reached by the population during that process
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Thirdly, it is a phenotypic or adaptive trait, with a functional role in each individual organism, that is maintained and has been evolved by natural selection
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Organisms face a succession of environmental challenges as they grow, and show adaptive plasticity as traits develop in response to the imposed conditions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This gives them resilience to varying environments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In biology, adaptation has three related meanings
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Firstly it is the dynamic evolutionary process that fits a population of organisms to their environment, enhancing their evolutionary fitness
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Secondly, it is a state reached by the population during that process
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Thirdly, it is a phenotypic or adaptive trait, with a functional role in each individual organism, that is maintained and has been evolved by natural selection
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Organisms face a succession of environmental challenges as they grow, and show adaptive plasticity as traits develop in response to the imposed conditions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This gives them resilience to varying environments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An (electrical) adapter or adaptor is a device that converts attributes of one electrical device or system to those of an otherwise incompatible device or system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some modify power or signal attributes, while others merely adapt the physical form of one electrical connector to another
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Addition (often signified by the plus symbol "+") is one of the four basic operations of arithmetic, with the others being subtraction, multiplication and division
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The addition of two whole numbers is the total amount of those quantities combined
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, in the picture on the right, there is a combination of three apples and two apples together, making a total of five apples
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This observation is equivalent to the mathematical expression "3 + 2 = 5" i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, "3 add 2 is equal to 5"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Besides counting fruits, addition can also represent combining other physical objects
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Using systematic generalizations, addition can also be defined on more abstract quantities, such as integers, rational numbers, real numbers and complex numbers and other abstract objects such as vectors and matrices
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In arithmetic, rules for addition involving fractions and negative numbers have been devised amongst others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In algebra, addition is studied more abstractly
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Addition has several important properties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is commutative, meaning that order does not matter, and it is associative, meaning that when one adds more than two numbers, the order in which addition is performed does not matter (see Summation)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Repeated addition of 1 is the same as counting; addition of 0 does not change a number
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Addition also obeys predictable rules concerning related operations such as subtraction and multiplication
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Performing addition is one of the simplest numerical tasks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Addition of very small numbers is accessible to toddlers; the most basic task, 1 + 1, can be performed by infants as young as five months and even some members of other animal species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In primary education, students are taught to add numbers in the decimal system, starting with single digits and progressively tackling more difficult problems
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Mechanical aids range from the ancient abacus to the modern computer, where research on the most efficient implementations of addition continues to this day
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adaptive behavior refers to behavior that enables a person (usually used in the context of children) to get along in his or her environment with greatest success and least conflict with others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This is a term used in the areas of psychology and special education
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adaptive behavior relates to every day skills or tasks that the average person is able to complete, similar to the term life skills
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Nonconstructive or disruptive social or personal behaviors can sometimes be used to achieve a constructive outcome
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, a constant repetitive action could be re-focused on something that creates or builds something
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In other words, the behavior can be adapted to something else
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In contrast, maladaptive behavior is a type of behavior that is often used to reduce one's anxiety, but the result is dysfunctional and non-productive
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, avoiding situations because you have unrealistic fears may initially reduce your anxiety, but it is non-productive in alleviating the actual problem in the long term
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Maladaptive behavior is frequently used as an indicator of abnormality or mental dysfunction, since its assessment is relatively free from subjectivity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, many behaviors considered moral can be maladaptive, such as dissent or abstinence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Maladaptive behavior may be affected by mechanisms in the brain that lead to addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Regarding addiction as a disease provides opportunities for its treatment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adaptive behavior reflects an individual’s social and practical competence to meet the demands of everyday living
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Behavior patterns change throughout a person's development, across life settings and social constructs, changes in personal values, and the expectations of others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is important to assess adaptive behavior in order to determine how well an individual functions in daily life: vocationally, socially and educationally
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adar (Hebrew: אֲדָר‎ Adar; from Akkadian adaru) is the sixth month of the civil year and the twelfth month of the ecclesiastical year on the Hebrew calendar, roughly corresponding to the month of March in the Gregorian calendar
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a winter month of 29 days
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Month of Adar in the Holy Scriptures comprises in Esther 09, 21
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In leap years, it is preceded by a 30-day intercalary month named Adar Aleph (Hebrew: אדר א'‎, Aleph being the first letter of the Hebrew alphabet, also known as "Adar Rishon" (First Adar) or "Adar I") and it is then itself called Adar Bet (Hebrew: אדר ב'‎, Bet being the second letter of the Hebrew Alphabet, also known as "Adar Sheni" (Second Adar) or "Adar II")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Occasionally instead of Adar I and Adar II, "Adar" and "Ve'Adar" are used (Ve means 'and' thus: And Adar)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adar I and II occur during February–March on the Gregorian calendar
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Based on a line in the Mishnah declaring that Purim must be celebrated in Adar II in a leap year (Megillah 1:4), Adar I is considered the "extra" month
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As a result, someone born in Adar during a non leap year would celebrate his birthday in Adar II during a leap year
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, someone born during either Adar in a leap year will celebrate his birthday during Adar in a non-leap year, except that someone born on 30 Adar I will celebrate his birthday on 1 Nisan in a non-leap year because Adar in a non-leap year has only 29 days
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

During the Second Temple period, there was a Jewish custom to make a public proclamation on the first day of the lunar month Adar, reminding the people that they are to prepare their annual monetary offering to the Temple treasury, known as the half-Shekel
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a mental disorder of the neurodevelopmental type
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is characterized by problems paying attention, excessive activity, or difficulty controlling behavior which is not appropriate for a person's age
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The symptoms appear before a person is twelve years old, are present for more than six months, and cause problems in at least two settings (such as school, home, or recreational activities)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In children, problems paying attention may result in poor school performance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although it causes impairment, particularly in modern society, many children with ADHD have a good attention span for tasks they find interesting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Despite being the most commonly studied and diagnosed mental disorder in children and adolescents, the exact cause is unknown in the majority of cases
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It affects about 5–7% of children when diagnosed via the DSM-IV criteria and 1–2% when diagnosed via the ICD-10 criteria
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As of 2015 it is estimated to affect about 51
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
1 million people
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Rates are similar between countries and depend mostly on how it is diagnosed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ADHD is diagnosed approximately three times more often in boys than in girls, although the disorder is often overlooked in girls due to their symptoms differing from those of boys
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 About 30–50% of people diagnosed in childhood continue to have symptoms into adulthood and between 2–5% of adults have the condition
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The condition can be difficult to tell apart from other disorders, as well as to distinguish from high levels of activity that are still within the normal-range
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

ADHD management recommendations vary by country and usually involve some combination of counseling, lifestyle changes, and medications
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The British guideline only recommends medications as a first-line treatment in children who have severe symptoms and for medication to be considered in those with moderate symptoms who either refuse or fail to improve with counseling, though for adults medications are a first-line treatment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Canadian and American guidelines recommend that medications and behavioral therapy be used together as a first-line therapy, except in preschool-aged children
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Stimulant medication therapy is not recommended as a first-line therapy in preschool-aged children in either guideline
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Treatment with stimulants is effective for up to 14 months; however, its long term effectiveness is unclear
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adolescents and adults tend to develop coping skills which make up for some or all of their impairments
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The medical literature has described symptoms similar to ADHD since the 19th century
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ADHD, its diagnosis, and its treatment have been considered controversial since the 1970s
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The controversies have involved clinicians, teachers, policymakers, parents, and the media
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Topics include ADHD's causes and the use of stimulant medications in its treatment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most healthcare providers accept ADHD as a genuine disorder in children and adults, and the debate in the scientific community mainly centers on how it is diagnosed and treated
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The condition was officially known as attention deficit disorder (ADD) from 1980 to 1987 while before this it was known as hyperkinetic reaction of childhood
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
For the GP2 Series racing team, see Addax Team
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The addax (Addax nasomaculatus), also known as the white antelope and the screwhorn antelope, is an antelope of the genus Addax, that lives in the Sahara desert
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was first described by Henri de Blainville in 1816
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As suggested by its alternative name, this pale antelope has long, twisted horns - typically 55 to 80 cm (22 to 31 in) in females and 70 to 85 cm (28 to 33 in) in males
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Males stand from 105 to 115 cm (41 to 45 in) at the shoulder, with females at 95 to 110 cm (37 to 43 in)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are sexually dimorphic, as the females are smaller than males
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The colour of the coat depends on the season - in the winter, it is greyish-brown with white hindquarters and legs, and long, brown hair on the head, neck, and shoulders; in the summer, the coat turns almost completely white or sandy blonde
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The addax mainly eats grasses and leaves of any available shrubs, leguminous herbs and bushes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These animals are well-adapted to exist in their desert habitat, as they can live without water for long periods of time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Addax form herds of five to 20 members, consisting of both males and females
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are led by the oldest female
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Due to its slow movements, the antelope is an easy target for its predators: lions, humans, African wild dogs, cheetahs, and leopards
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Breeding season is at its peak during winter and early spring
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The natural habitat of the addax are arid regions, semideserts and sandy and stony deserts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The addax is a critically endangered species of antelope, as classified by the IUCN
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although extremely rare in its native habitat due to unregulated hunting, it is quite common in captivity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The addax was once abundant in North Africa, native to Chad, Mauritania and Niger
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is extinct in Algeria, Egypt, Libya, Sudan and Western Sahara
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It has been reintroduced in Morocco and Tunisia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
A value chain is a set of activities that a firm operating in a specific industry performs in order to deliver a valuable product or service for the market
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The concept comes through business management and was first described by Michael Porter in his 1985 best-seller, Competitive Advantage: Creating and Sustaining Superior Performance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


The idea of the value chain is based on the process view of organizations, the idea of seeing a manufacturing (or service) organization as a system, made up of subsystems each with inputs, transformation processes and outputs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Inputs, transformation processes, and outputs involve the acquisition and consumption of resources – money, labour, materials, equipment, buildings, land, administration and management
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 How value chain activities are carried out determines costs and affects profits
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


The concept of value chains as decision support tools, was added onto the competitive strategies paradigm developed by Porter as early as 1979
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Porter's value chains, Inbound Logistics, Operations, Outbound Logistics, Marketing and Sales, and Service are categorized as primary activities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Secondary activities include Procurement, Human Resource management, Technological Development and Infrastructure (Porter 1985, pp
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 11–15)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

According to the OECD Secretary-General (Gurría 2012) the emergence of global value chains (GVCs) in the late 1990s provided a catalyst for accelerated change in the landscape of international investment and trade, with major, far-reaching consequences on governments as well as enterprises (Gurría 2012)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An addendum, in general, is an addition required to be made to a document by its author subsequent to its printing or publication
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It comes from the Latin verbal phrase addendum est, being the gerundive form of the verb addo, addere, addidi, additum, "to give to, add to", meaning "(that which) must be added"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Addenda is from the plural form addenda sunt, "(those things) which must be added"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 (See also memorandum, agenda, corrigenda
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
)


 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Addiction is a brain disorder characterized by compulsive engagement in rewarding stimuli, despite adverse consequences
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Despite the involvement of a number of psychosocial factors, a biological process – one which is induced by repeated exposure to an addictive stimulus – is the core pathology that drives the development and maintenance of an addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The two properties that characterize all addictive stimuli are that they are reinforcing (i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, they increase the likelihood that a person will seek repeated exposure to them) and intrinsically rewarding (i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, they are perceived as being inherently positive, desirable, and pleasurable)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Addiction is a disorder of the brain's reward system which arises through transcriptional and epigenetic mechanisms and occurs over time from chronically high levels of exposure to an addictive stimulus (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, morphine, cocaine, sexual intercourse, gambling, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ΔFosB, a gene transcription factor, is a critical component and common factor in the development of virtually all forms of behavioral and drug addictions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Two decades of research into ΔFosB's role in addiction have demonstrated that addiction arises, and the associated compulsive behavior intensifies or attenuates, along with the overexpression of ΔFosB in the D1-type medium spiny neurons of the nucleus accumbens
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Due to the causal relationship between ΔFosB expression and addictions, it is used preclinically as an addiction biomarker
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ΔFosB expression in these neurons directly and positively regulates drug self-administration and reward sensitization through positive reinforcement, while decreasing sensitivity to aversion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

As described by two groups of researchers, addiction exacts an "astoundingly high financial and human toll" on individuals and society as a whole through the direct adverse effects of drugs, associated healthcare costs, long-term complications (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, lung cancer with smoking tobacco, liver cirrhosis with drinking alcohol, or meth mouth from intravenous methamphetamine), the functional consequences of altered neural plasticity in the brain, and the consequent loss of productivity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Classic hallmarks of addiction include impaired control over substances or behavior, preoccupation with substance or behavior, and continued use despite consequences
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Habits and patterns associated with addiction are typically characterized by immediate gratification (short-term reward), coupled with delayed deleterious effects (long-term costs)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Examples of drug and behavioral addictions include: alcoholism, amphetamine addiction, cocaine addiction, nicotine addiction, opiate addiction, food addiction, gambling addiction, and sexual addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The only behavioral addiction recognized by the DSM-5 is gambling addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term addiction is misused frequently to refer to other compulsive behaviors or disorders, particularly dependence, in news media
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An important distinction between drug addiction and dependence is that drug dependence is a disorder in which cessation of drug use results in an unpleasant state of withdrawal, which can lead to further drug use
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Addiction is the compulsive use of a substance or performance of a behavior that is independent of withdrawal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Addition (often signified by the plus symbol "+") is one of the four basic operations of arithmetic, with the others being subtraction, multiplication and division
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The addition of two whole numbers is the total amount of those quantities combined
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, in the picture on the right, there is a combination of three apples and two apples together, making a total of five apples
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This observation is equivalent to the mathematical expression "3 + 2 = 5" i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, "3 add 2 is equal to 5"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Besides counting fruits, addition can also represent combining other physical objects
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Using systematic generalizations, addition can also be defined on more abstract quantities, such as integers, rational numbers, real numbers and complex numbers and other abstract objects such as vectors and matrices
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In arithmetic, rules for addition involving fractions and negative numbers have been devised amongst others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In algebra, addition is studied more abstractly
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Addition has several important properties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is commutative, meaning that order does not matter, and it is associative, meaning that when one adds more than two numbers, the order in which addition is performed does not matter (see Summation)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Repeated addition of 1 is the same as counting; addition of 0 does not change a number
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Addition also obeys predictable rules concerning related operations such as subtraction and multiplication
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Performing addition is one of the simplest numerical tasks
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Addition of very small numbers is accessible to toddlers; the most basic task, 1 + 1, can be performed by infants as young as five months and even some members of other animal species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In primary education, students are taught to add numbers in the decimal system, starting with single digits and progressively tackling more difficult problems
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Mechanical aids range from the ancient abacus to the modern computer, where research on the most efficient implementations of addition continues to this day
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Epigenetics are stable heritable traits (or "phenotypes") that cannot be explained by changes in DNA sequence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Greek prefix epi- (ἐπι- "over, outside of, around") in epigenetics implies features that are "on top of" or "in addition to" the traditional genetic basis for inheritance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Epigenetics often refers to changes in a chromosome that affect gene activity and expression, but can also be used to describe any heritable phenotypic change that does not derive from a modification of the genome, such as prions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Such effects on cellular and physiological phenotypic traits may result from external or environmental factors, or be part of normal developmental program
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The standard definition of epigenetics requires these alterations to be heritable, either in the progeny of cells or of organisms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The term also refers to the changes themselves: functionally relevant changes to the genome that do not involve a change in the nucleotide sequence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Examples of mechanisms that produce such changes are DNA methylation and histone modification, each of which alters how genes are expressed without altering the underlying DNA sequence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Gene expression can be controlled through the action of repressor proteins that attach to silencer regions of the DNA
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These epigenetic changes may last through cell divisions for the duration of the cell's life, and may also last for multiple generations even though they do not involve changes in the underlying DNA sequence of the organism; instead, non-genetic factors cause the organism's genes to behave (or "express themselves") differently
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

One example of an epigenetic change in eukaryotic biology is the process of cellular differentiation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 During morphogenesis, totipotent stem cells become the various pluripotent cell lines of the embryo, which in turn become fully differentiated cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In other words, as a single fertilized egg cell – the zygote – continues to divide, the resulting daughter cells change into all the different cell types in an organism, including neurons, muscle cells, epithelium, endothelium of blood vessels, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, by activating some genes while inhibiting the expression of others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Historically, some phenomena not necessarily heritable have also been described as epigenetic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, the term epigenetic has been used to describe any modification of chromosomal regions, especially histone modifications, whether or not these changes are heritable or associated with a phenotype
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The consensus definition now requires a trait to be heritable for it to be considered epigenetic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Misuse of the scientific term by quack authors has created misinformation and controversy in the public
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Order of Australia is an order of chivalry established on 14 February 1975 by Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, to recognise Australian citizens and other persons for achievement or meritorious service
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Before the establishment of the order, Australian citizens received British honours
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Queen of Australia is Sovereign Head of the Order, while the Governor-General is Principal Companion/Dame/Knight (as relevant at the time) and Chancellor of the Order
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Governor-General's Official Secretary is Secretary of the Order
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adele Laurie Blue Adkins MBE (born 5 May 1988) () is an English singer-songwriter
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 After graduating from the BRIT School for Performing Arts and Technology in 2006, Adele was given a recording contract by XL Recordings after a friend posted her demo on Myspace the same year
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2007, she received the Brit Awards "Critics' Choice" award and won the BBC Sound of 2008 poll
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Her debut album, 19, was released in 2008 to commercial and critical success
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is certified seven times platinum in the UK, and three times platinum in the US
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The album contains her first song, "Hometown Glory", written when she was 16, which is based on her home suburb of West Norwood in London
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An appearance she made on Saturday Night Live in late 2008 boosted her career in the US
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 At the 51st Grammy Awards in 2009, Adele received the awards for Best New Artist and Best Female Pop Vocal Performance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

She released her second studio album, 21, in early 2011
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The album was critically well received and surpassed the success of her debut, earning the singer numerous awards in 2012, among them a record-tying six Grammy Awards, including Album of the Year; two Brit Awards, including British Album of the Year, and three American Music Awards
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The album has been certified 16 times platinum in the UK, and is the fourth best-selling album in the UK of all time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the US, it has held the top position longer than any album since 1985, and is certified diamond
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The album has sold over 31 million copies worldwide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The success of 21 earned Adele numerous mentions in the Guinness Book of World Records
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She was the first woman in the history of the Billboard Hot 100 to have three simultaneous top 10 singles as a lead artist, and the first female artist to simultaneously have two albums in the top five of the Billboard 200 and two singles in the top five of the Billboard Hot 100
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 21 is the longest-running number one album by a female solo artist in the history of the UK and US Album Charts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In 2012, Adele released "Skyfall", which she co-wrote and recorded for the James Bond film of the same name
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The song won an Academy Award, a Grammy Award, and a Golden Globe Award for Best Original Song, as well as the Brit Award for British Single of the Year
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 After taking a three-year break, Adele released her third studio album, 25, in 2015
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It became the year's best-selling album and broke first week sales records in the UK and US
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 25 was her second album to be certified diamond in the US and earned her five Grammy Awards, including her second Grammy Award for Album of the Year, and four Brit Awards
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The lead single, "Hello", became the first song in the US to sell over one million digital copies within a week of its release
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Her third concert tour, Adele Live 2016, visited Europe, North America and Oceania, and concluded with finale concerts at Wembley Stadium in mid-2017
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In 2011, 2012 and 2016, Billboard named Adele Artist of the Year
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2012, she was listed at number five on VH1's 100 Greatest Women in Music
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Time magazine named her one of the most influential people in the world in 2012 and 2016
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 With sales of more than 100 million records, Adele is one of the best-selling music artists of all time
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An idiot, dolt, dullard or (archaically) mome is a person perceived to be lacking intelligence, or someone who acts in a self-defeating or significantly counterproductive way
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Along with the similar terms moron, imbecile, and cretin, the word archaically referred to the intellectually disabled, but have all since gained specialized meanings in modern times
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An idiot is said to be idiotic, and to suffer from idiocy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
James Thurston Nabors (born June 12, 1930) is a retired American actor, singer, and comedian
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Born and raised in Sylacauga, Alabama, Nabors moved to southern California because of his asthma
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 While working at a Santa Monica nightclub, The Horn, he was discovered by Andy Griffith and later joined The Andy Griffith Show, playing Gomer Pyle
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Nabors, Betty Lynn Elinor Donahue, and Ron Howard are the last surviving regular cast members from that series
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The character proved popular, and Nabors was given his own spin-off show, Gomer Pyle, U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
M
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
C
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Though known for his portrayal of Gomer Pyle, Nabors became a popular guest on variety shows in the 1960s and 1970s (including two specials of his own in 1969 and 1974), which showcased his rich baritone voice, and sometimes his higher-pitched voice
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He subsequently recorded numerous albums and singles, most of them containing romantic ballads
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Nabors is also known for singing "Back Home Again in Indiana", prior to the start of the Indianapolis 500, held annually over the Memorial Day Weekend
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Save for occasional absences due to health or other conflicts, Nabors sang the unofficial Indiana anthem almost every year from 1972 until his final time in 2014
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An idiot, dolt, dullard or (archaically) mome is a person perceived to be lacking intelligence, or someone who acts in a self-defeating or significantly counterproductive way
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Along with the similar terms moron, imbecile, and cretin, the word archaically referred to the intellectually disabled, but have all since gained specialized meanings in modern times
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An idiot is said to be idiotic, and to suffer from idiocy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Tarzoon: Shame of the Jungle (French: Tarzoon, la honte de la jungle) is a 1975 adult-oriented French/Belgian animated film directed by cartoonist Picha and Boris Szulzinger
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The film was the first foreign-animated film to receive both an X rating and wide distribution in the United States
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An English dub was released in 1979 where the English cast consists of Johnny Weissmuller, Jr
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, John Belushi, Bill Murray, Christopher Guest, and Brian Doyle-Murray
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

This film is also known as Jungle Burger in the United Kingdom
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 ΔFosB expression in these neurons directly and positively regulates drug self-administration and reward sensitization through positive reinforcement, while decreasing sensitivity to aversion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

As described by two groups of researchers, addiction exacts an "astoundingly high financial and human toll" on individuals and society as a whole through the direct adverse effects of drugs, associated healthcare costs, long-term complications (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, lung cancer with smoking tobacco, liver cirrhosis with drinking alcohol, or meth mouth from intravenous methamphetamine), the functional consequences of altered neural plasticity in the brain, and the consequent loss of productivity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Classic hallmarks of addiction include impaired control over substances or behavior, preoccupation with substance or behavior, and continued use despite consequences
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Habits and patterns associated with addiction are typically characterized by immediate gratification (short-term reward), coupled with delayed deleterious effects (long-term costs)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Examples of drug and behavioral addictions include: alcoholism, amphetamine addiction, cocaine addiction, nicotine addiction, opiate addiction, food addiction, gambling addiction, and sexual addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The only behavioral addiction recognized by the DSM-5 is gambling addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term addiction is misused frequently to refer to other compulsive behaviors or disorders, particularly dependence, in news media
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An important distinction between drug addiction and dependence is that drug dependence is a disorder in which cessation of drug use results in an unpleasant state of withdrawal, which can lead to further drug use
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Addiction is the compulsive use of a substance or performance of a behavior that is independent of withdrawal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adelaide ( AD-ə-layd) is the capital city of the state of South Australia, and the fifth-most populous city of Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In June 2016, Adelaide had an estimated resident population of 1,326,354
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 South Australia, with a total of 1
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
7 million inhabitants, has the most centralised population of any state in Australia, with more than 75 percent of its people living in greater Adelaide, while the other population centres in the state are relatively small
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adelaide is north of the Fleurieu Peninsula, on the Adelaide Plains between the Gulf St Vincent and the low-lying Mount Lofty Ranges which surround the city
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adelaide stretches 20 km (12 mi) from the coast to the foothills, and 94 to 104 km (58 to 65 mi) from Gawler at its northern extent to Sellicks Beach in the south
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Named in honour of Adelaide of Saxe-Meiningen, queen consort to King William IV, the city was founded in 1836 as the planned capital for a freely-settled British province in Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Colonel William Light, one of Adelaide's founding fathers, designed the city and chose its location close to the River Torrens, in the area originally inhabited by the Kaurna people
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Light's design set out Adelaide in a grid layout, interspaced by wide boulevards and large public squares, and entirely surrounded by parklands
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Early Adelaide was shaped by prosperity and wealth—until the Second World War, it was Australia's third-largest city and one of the few Australian cities to not have convict history
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It has been noted for early examples of religious freedom, a commitment to political progressivism and civil liberties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It has been known as the "City of Churches" since the mid-19th century
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The demonym "Adelaidean" is used in reference to the city and its residents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

As South Australia's seat of government and commercial centre, Adelaide is the site of many governmental and financial institutions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most of these are concentrated in the city centre along the cultural boulevard of North Terrace, King William Street and in various districts of the metropolitan area
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Today, Adelaide is noted for its many festivals and sporting events, its food and wine, its long beachfronts, and its large defence and manufacturing sectors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It ranks highly in terms of liveability, being listed in the Top 10 of The Economist Intelligence Unit's World's Most Liveable Cities index in 2010, 2011, 2012 and 2015
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was also ranked the most liveable city in Australia by the Property Council of Australia in 2011, 2012 and 2013
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adelges is a genus of insects which feed on conifers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Excepting galls formed by the spruce gall midge, galls are caused by aphid-like insects of the family Phylloxeridae (Adelgidae) commonly known as the spruce gall adelgids
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They have complex life cycles, some species feeding exclusively on spruce, others feeding on spruce and an alternate conifer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, galls characteristic of each species are formed only on spruce
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Six generations are usually needed to complete the 2-year cycle, and in the case of species having an alternate host, winged adults about 2 mm long are formed only in the generations that move from one host to the other
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The spruce gall adelgid (Adelges lariciatus Patch) occurs in alternate years on spruce and larch from Alberta to the Maritimes and in adjacent parts of the United States
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The pale spruce gall adelgid (Adelges strobilobius Kaltenbach) has a similar range but prefers black spruce or red spruce to white spruce
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Species include:
Adelges abietis (Pineapple gall adelgid)
Adelges cooleyi (Gall adelgid)
Adelges piceae (Balsam woolly adelgid)
Adelges tsugae (Hemlock woolly adelgid)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adelaide ( AD-ə-layd) is the capital city of the state of South Australia, and the fifth-most populous city of Australia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In June 2016, Adelaide had an estimated resident population of 1,326,354
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

7 million inhabitants, has the most centralised population of any state in Australia, with more than 75 percent of its people living in greater Adelaide, while the other population centres in the state are relatively small

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
