 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Adelgidae is a small family of the Hemiptera closely related to the aphids, and often traditionally included in the Aphidoidea with the Phylloxeridae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adelgids are often known as "woolly conifer aphids"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The family is composed of species associated with pine, spruce, or other conifers, known respectively as "pine aphids" or "spruce aphids"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This family includes the former family Chermesidae, or "Chermidae", the name of which was declared invalid by the ICZN in 1955
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There is still considerable debate as to the number of genera within the family, and the classification is still unstable and inconsistent among competing authors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There are about fifty species of adelgids known
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 All of them are native to the northern hemisphere, although some have been introduced to the southern hemisphere as invasive species
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Unlike aphids, the adelgids have no tail-like cauda and no cornicles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adelgids only lay eggs, and never give birth to live nymphs as aphids do
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adelgids are covered with dense woolly wax
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A complete adelgid life cycle lasts two years
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adelgid nymphs are known as sistentes, and the overwintering sistentes are called neosistens
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Rain can kill adelgids by dislodging eggs and sistentes from trees
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Ademption, or ademption by extinction, is a common law doctrine used in the law of wills to determine what happens when property bequeathed under a will is no longer in the testator's estate at the time of the testator's death
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For a devise (bequest) of a specific item of property (a specific gift), such property is considered adeemed, and the gift fails
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, if a will bequeathed the testator's car to a specific beneficiary, but the testator owned no car at the time of his or her death, the gift would be adeemed and the aforementioned beneficiary would receive no gift at all
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

General bequests or general gifts - gifts of cash amounts - are never adeemed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 If the cash in the testator's estate is not sufficient to satisfy the gift, then other assets in the residuary estate will need to be sold to raise the necessary cash
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Some property lies in a "gray" area, in which the testator's specific intent must be determined
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, where the testator bequeathes "500 shares of stock" in a company, this may be read as a general bequest (that the estate should purchase and convey the particular stocks to the beneficiary), or it may be read as a specific bequest, particularly if the testator used a possessive ("my 500 shares")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Such a gift is deemed to be a demonstrative gift
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Such demonstrative gifts are deemed to be a hybrid of both specific and general gifts
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 If one were to bequeath "500 shares of stock," most states would deem that to be a demonstrative gift
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The resultant gift to the heir receiving "500 shares," would be the date of death value of 500 shares of that particular stock
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Ademption may be waived if the property leaves the estate after the testator has been declared incompetent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Furthermore, in some cases the beneficiary will be entitled to the proceeds from the sale of property, or to the insurance payout for property that is lost or destroyed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

To avoid confusion as to what may or may not be adeemed, sometimes the phrase "if owned by me at my death" is placed into the articles of a will in which property is being bequeathed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

As for the sale of land under an executory contract, traditional case law agrees that ademption occurs upon the death of the testator and that the proceeds of sale, when the closing occurs, should not pass to the specific devisee of the property
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, the more modern view and the Uniform Probate Code, which has been adopted by some states, disagrees
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These jurisdictions find that when property subject to specific devise is placed under contract of sale before the decedent's death, the proceeds of the sale will pass to the specific devisee
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Aden (UK:  AY-duhn, US:  AH-den; Arabic: عدن‎‎ ʻAdin/ʻAdan  Yemeni pronunciation: [ˈʕæden, ˈʕædæn]) is a port city in Yemen, located by the eastern approach to the Red Sea (the Gulf of Aden), some 170 km (110 mi) east of Bab-el-Mandeb
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its population is approximately 800,000 people
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aden's ancient, natural harbour lies in the crater of a dormant volcano which now forms a peninsula, joined to the mainland by a low isthmus
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This harbour, Front Bay, was first used by the ancient Kingdom of Awsan between the 5th and 7th centuries BC
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The modern harbour is on the other side of the peninsula
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Aden gives its name to the Gulf of Aden
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Aden consists of a number of distinct sub-centres: Crater, the original port city; Ma'alla, the modern port; Tawahi, known as "Steamer Point" in the colonial period; and the resorts of Gold Mohur
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Khormaksar, located on the isthmus that connects Aden proper with the mainland, includes the city's diplomatic missions, the main offices of Aden University, and Aden International Airport (the former British Royal Air Force station RAF Khormaksar), Yemen's second biggest airport
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 On the mainland are the sub-centres of Sheikh Othman, a former oasis area; Al-Mansura, a town planned by the British; and Madinat ash-Sha'b (formerly Madinat al-Itihad), the site designated as the capital of the South Arabian Federation and now home to a large power/desalinization facility and additional faculties of Aden University
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Aden encloses the eastern side of a vast, natural harbour that comprises the modern port
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The volcanic peninsula of Little Aden forms a near-mirror image, enclosing the harbour and port on the western side
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Little Aden became the site of the oil refinery and tanker port
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Both were established and operated by British Petroleum until they were turned over to Yemeni government ownership and control in 1978
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Aden was the capital of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen until that country's unification with the Yemen Arab Republic in 1990, and again briefly served as Yemen's temporary capital during the aftermath of the 2014–15 Yemeni coup d'état, as declared by President Abd Rabbuh Mansur Hadi after he fled the Houthi occupation of Sana'a
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 From March to July 2015, the Battle of Aden raged between Houthis and loyalists to President Hadi
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Water, food, and medical supplies ran short in the city
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 On 14 July, the Saudi Army launched an offensive to retake Aden for Hadi's government
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Within three days the Houthis had been removed from the city
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adenanthera is a genus of flowering plants in the legume family, Fabaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It contains the following species:
Adenanthera bicolor Merr
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 (Sri Lanka)
Adenanthera intermedia Merr
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 (Philippines)
Adenanthera pavonina L
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 - Coralwood (India)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adenine  (A, Ade) is a nucleobase (a purine derivative)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its derivatives have a variety of roles in biochemistry including cellular respiration, in the form of both the energy-rich adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and the cofactors nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It also has functions in protein synthesis and as a chemical component of DNA and RNA
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The shape of adenine is complementary to either thymine in DNA or uracil in RNA
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The image on the right shows pure adenine, as an independent molecule
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 When connected into DNA, a covalent bond is formed between deoxyribose sugar and the bottom left nitrogen, so removing the hydrogen
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The remaining structure is called an adenine residue, as part of a larger molecule
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adenosine is adenine reacted with ribose as used in RNA and ATP; deoxyadenosine, adenine attached to deoxyribose, as is used to form DNA
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adenitis is a general term for an inflammation of a gland
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Often it is used to refer to lymphadenitis which is the inflammation of a lymph node
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adenium is a genus of flowering plants in the Apocynum family, Apocynaceae, first described as a genus in 1819
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is native to Africa and the Arabian Peninsula
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adenocarcinoma (; plural adenocarcinomas or adenocarcinomata ) is a type of cancerous tumor that can occur in several parts of the body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is defined as neoplasia of epithelial tissue that has glandular origin, glandular characteristics, or both
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adenocarcinomas are part of the larger grouping of carcinomas, but are also sometimes called by more precise terms omitting the word, where these exist
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Thus invasive ductal carcinoma, the most common form of breast cancer, is adenocarcinoma but does not use the term in its name—however, esophageal adenocarcinoma does to distinguish it from the other common type of esophageal cancer, esophageal squamous cell carcinoma
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Several of the most common forms of cancer are adenocarcinomas, and the various sorts of adenocarcinoma vary greatly in all their aspects, so that few useful generalizations can be made about them
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the most specific usage (narrowest sense), the glandular origin or traits are exocrine; endocrine gland tumors, such as a VIPoma, an insulinoma, or a pheochromocytoma, are typically not referred to as adenocarcinomas but rather are often called neuroendocrine tumors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Epithelial tissue sometimes includes, but is not limited to, the surface layer of skin, glands, and a variety of other tissue that lines the cavities and organs of the body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Epithelial tissue can be derived embryologically from any of the germ layers (ectoderm, endoderm, or mesoderm)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 To be classified as adenocarcinoma, the cells do not necessarily need to be part of a gland, as long as they have secretory properties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adenocarcinoma is the malignant counterpart to adenoma, which is the benign form of such tumors
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Sometimes adenomas transform into adenocarcinomas, but most do not
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Well differentiated adenocarcinomas tend to resemble the glandular tissue that they are derived from, while poorly differentiated adenocarcinomas may not
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 By staining the cells from a biopsy, a pathologist can determine whether the tumor is an adenocarcinoma or some other type of cancer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adenocarcinomas can arise in many tissues of the body owing to the ubiquitous nature of glands within the body, and, more fundamentally, to the potency of epithelial cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 While each gland may not be secreting the same substance, as long as there is an exocrine function to the cell, it is considered glandular and its malignant form is therefore named adenocarcinoma
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Zinc transporter ZIP3 is a protein that in humans is encoded by the SLC39A3 gene
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The adenoid, also known as a pharyngeal tonsil or nasopharyngeal tonsil, is the superior-most of the tonsils
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a mass of lymphatic tissue situated posterior to the nasal cavity, in the roof of the nasopharynx, where the nose blends into the throat
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Normally, in children, it forms a soft mound in the roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx, just above and behind the uvula
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The adenoid, also known as a pharyngeal tonsil or nasopharyngeal tonsil, is the superior-most of the tonsils
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a mass of lymphatic tissue situated posterior to the nasal cavity, in the roof of the nasopharynx, where the nose blends into the throat
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Normally, in children, it forms a soft mound in the roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx, just above and behind the uvula
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adenoidectomy is the surgical removal of the adenoids for reasons which include impaired breathing through the nose, chronic infections, or recurrent earaches
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The surgery is less commonly performed in adults in whom adenoids are considered vestigial and purposeless
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is most often done on an outpatient basis under general anesthesia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Post-operative pain is generally minimal and reduced by icy or cold foods
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The procedure can be combined with tonsillectomy if indicated and recovery time can range from several hours to two or three days (though as age increases so does recovery time)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adenoidectomy is not often performed under one year of age as adenoid function is part of the body's immune system but its contribution to this decreases progressively beyond this age
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An adenoma (from Greek αδένας, adeno-, "gland" + -ώμα, -oma, "tumor") (; plural adenomas or adenomata ) is a benign tumor of epithelial tissue with glandular origin, glandular characteristics, or both
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adenomas can grow from many glandular organs, including the adrenal glands, pituitary gland, thyroid, prostate, and others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some adenomas grow from epithelial tissue in nonglandular areas but express glandular tissue structure (as can happen in familial polyposis coli)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Although adenomas are benign, over time they may transform to become malignant, at which point they are called adenocarcinomas
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most adenomas do not transform
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 But even while benign, they have the potential to cause serious health complications by compressing other structures (mass effect) and by producing large amounts of hormones in an unregulated, non-feedback-dependent manner (causing paraneoplastic syndromes)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some adenomas are too small to be seen macroscopically but can still cause clinical symptoms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Lymphadenopathy or adenopathy is disease of the lymph nodes, in which they are abnormal in size, number, or consistency
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Lymphadenopathy of an inflammatory type (the most common type) is lymphadenitis, producing swollen or enlarged lymph nodes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In clinical practice, the distinction between lymphadenopathy and lymphadenitis is rarely made and the words are usually treated as synonymous
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Inflammation of the lymphatic vessels is known as lymphangitis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Infectious lymphadenitides affecting lymph nodes in the neck are often called scrofula
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The term comes from the word lymph and a combination of the Greek words αδένας, adenas ("gland") and παθεία, patheia ("act of suffering" or "disease")
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Lymphadenopathy is a common and nonspecific sign
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Common causes include infections (from minor ones such as the common cold to dangerous ones such as HIV/AIDS), autoimmune diseases, and cancers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Lymphadenopathy is also frequently idiopathic and self-limiting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adenosine is a purine nucleoside composed of a molecule of adenine attached to a ribose sugar molecule (ribofuranose) moiety via a β-N9-glycosidic bond
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adenosine is widely found in nature and plays an important role in biochemical processes, such as energy transfer—as adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and adenosine diphosphate (ADP)—as well as in signal transduction as cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is also a neuromodulator, believed to play a role in promoting sleep and suppressing arousal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adenosine also plays a role in regulation of blood flow to various organs through vasodilation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In addition to adenosine's endogenous forms, it is also used as a medication, specifically, as an antiarrhythmic agent, to treat a number of forms of supraventricular tachycardia that do not improve with vagal maneuvers
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Common side effects include chest pain, feeling faint, shortness of breath along with tingling of the senses 
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Serious side effects include a worsening dysrhythmia and low blood pressure
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It appears to be safe in pregnancy
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adenota is an alternative genus or sub-genus within the Reduncinae sub-family of family Bovidae, composed of the species Kobus kob (Kob) and Kobus vardonii (Puku)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was described by Nowak in 1991
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adenoviruses (members of the family Adenoviridae) are medium-sized (90–100 nm), nonenveloped (without an outer lipid bilayer) viruses with an icosahedral nucleocapsid containing a double stranded DNA genome
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Their name derives from their initial isolation from human adenoids in 1953
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

They have a broad range of vertebrate hosts; in humans, more than 50 distinct adenoviral serotypes have been found to cause a wide range of illnesses, from mild respiratory infections in young children (known as the common cold) to life-threatening multi-organ disease in people with a weakened immune system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An adept is an individual identified as having attained a specific level of knowledge, skill, or aptitude in doctrines relevant to a particular author or organization
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An adept is an individual identified as having attained a specific level of knowledge, skill, or aptitude in doctrines relevant to a particular author or organization
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In his seminal work Aspects of the Theory of Syntax (1965), Noam Chomsky introduces a hierarchy of Levels of Adequacy for evaluating grammars (theories of specific languages) and metagrammars (theories of grammars)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

These levels constitute a taxonomy of theories (a grammar of a natural language being an example of such a theory) according to potency
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This taxonomy might be extended to scientific theories in general, and from there even stretched into the realm of the aesthetics of art
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This present article's use of the phrase as a terminus technicus should not be confused with its everyday language uses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In mathematics, an adherent point (also closure point or point of closure or contact point) of a subset A of a topological space X, is a point x in X such that every open set containing x contains at least one point of A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A point x is an adherent point for A if and only if x is in the closure of A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

This definition differs from that of a limit point, in that for a limit point it is required that every open set containing 
  
    
      
        x
      
    
    {\displaystyle x}
   contains at least one point of A different from x
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Thus every limit point is an adherent point, but the converse is not true
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An adherent point of A is either a limit point of A or an element of A (or both)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An adherent point which is not a limit point is an isolated point
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Intuitively, having an open set A defined as the area within (but not including) some boundary, the adherent points of A are those of A including the boundary
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
A self-adhering bandage or cohesive bandage is a type of bandage or wrap that coheres to itself, but does not adhere well to other surfaces
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Because of this, it is commonly used as a wrap on limbs, since it will stick to itself and not loosen
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is used on humans, but also commonly used as a wrap on the legs of livestock because it will not stick to hair, so it is easily removed
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adhesion is the tendency of dissimilar particles or surfaces to cling to one another (cohesion refers to the tendency of similar or identical particles/surfaces to cling to one another)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The forces that cause adhesion and cohesion can be divided into several types
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The intermolecular forces responsible for the function of various kinds of stickers and sticky tape fall into the categories of chemical adhesion, dispersive adhesion, and diffusive adhesion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In addition to the cumulative magnitudes of these intermolecular forces, there are certain emergent mechanical effects
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adhesive may be used interchangeably with glue, cement, mucilage, or paste, and is any substance applied to one surface, or both surfaces, of two separate items that binds them together and resists their separation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adjectives may be used in conjunction with the word "adhesive" to describe properties based on the substance's physical or chemical form, the type of materials joined, or conditions under which it is applied
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The use of adhesives offers many advantages over binding techniques such as sewing, mechanical fastening, thermal bonding, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These include the ability to bind different materials together, to distribute stress more efficiently across the joint, the cost effectiveness of an easily mechanized process, an improvement in aesthetic design, and increased design flexibility
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Disadvantages of adhesive use include decreased stability at high temperatures, relative weakness in bonding large objects with a small bonding surface area, and greater difficulty in separating objects during testing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adhesives are typically organized by the method of adhesion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These are then organized into reactive and non-reactive adhesives, which refers to whether the adhesive chemically reacts in order to harden
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Alternatively they can be organized by whether the raw stock is of natural or synthetic origin, or by their starting physical phase
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adhesives may be found naturally or produced synthetically
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The earliest human use of adhesive-like substances was approximately 200,000 years ago, when Neanderthals produced tar from the dry distillation of birch bark for use in binding stone tools to wooden handles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The first references to adhesives in literature first appeared in approximately 2000 BCE
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Greeks and Romans made great contributions to the development of adhesives
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In Europe, glue was not widely used until the period 1500–1700 CE
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 From then until the 1900s increases in adhesive use and discovery were relatively gradual
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Only since the last century has the development of synthetic adhesives accelerated rapidly, and innovation in the field continues to the present
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Agostino Valier (7 April 1531 – 24 May 1606), also Augustinus Valerius or Valerio, was an Italian cardinal and bishop of Verona
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He was a reforming bishop, putting into effect the decisions of the Council of Trent by means of administrative and disciplinary measures
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He was one of the Christian humanist followers of Filippo Neri
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
John William Money (8 July 1921 – 7 July 2006) was a psychologist, sexologist and author, specializing in research into sexual identity and biology of gender
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He was one of the first scientists to study the psychology of sexual fluidity and how the societal constructs of "gender" affect an individual
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His work has been both celebrated for its innovation and criticized, particularly in regard to his involvement with the sex-reassignment of David Reimer and his eventual suicide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Money published around 2,000 articles, books, chapters and reviews
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His writing has been translated into many languages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Money has received around 65 world-wide honors, awards, and degrees, but has been discredited by, most notably, David Reimer, prior to his suicide
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adoration (Latin) is respect, reverence, strong admiration or devotion in a certain person, place, or thing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term comes from the Latin adōrātiō, meaning "to give homage or worship to someone or something"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In thermodynamics, an adiabatic process is one that occurs without transfer of heat or matter between a thermodynamic system and its surroundings
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In an adiabatic process, energy is transferred to its surroundings only as work
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The adiabatic process provides a rigorous conceptual basis for the theory used to expound the first law of thermodynamics, and as such it is a key concept in thermodynamics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Some chemical and physical processes occur so rapidly that they may be conveniently described by the term "adiabatic approximation", meaning that there is not enough time for the transfer of energy as heat to take place to or from the system
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

By way of example, the adiabatic flame temperature is an idealization that uses the "adiabatic approximation" so as to provide an upper limit calculation of temperatures produced by combustion of a fuel
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The adiabatic flame temperature is the temperature that would be achieved by a flame if the process of combustion took place in the absence of heat loss to the surroundings
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adiantaceae (as construed here, sensu strictu, not a synonym of Pteridaceae) is a family of ferns in the order Pteridales
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This includes the family formerly known as the "Vittariaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
" Recent genetic analyses based on chloroplast genes demonstrate that the vittarioid ferns cladistically nest within the genus Adiantum, making that genus paraphyletic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


The vittarioid ferns are primarily epiphytic in tropical regions and all have simple leaves with sori that follow the veins and lack true indusia; the sori are most often marginal with a false indusium formed from the reflexed leaf margin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The family also includes a species, Vittaria appalachiana, that is highly unusual in that the sporophyte stage of the life cycle is absent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This species consists solely of photosynthetic gametophytes that reproduce asexually
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The ferns historically considered as Adiantum include both petrophilic and terrestrial plants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most of the species in this genus do compose a clade within the family, but apparently Adiantum raddianum and possibly some related species constitute a clade that is sister to the vittarioids combined with the rest of the genus Adiantum
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

This family is most closely allied with the Pellaeaceae within the Pteridales
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Based on phylogenetic research, Smith et al
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 (2006) included Adiantaceae as part of the family Pteridaceae and Christenhusz et al
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 (2011) listed its genera in Vittarioideae (C
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Presl) Crabbe, Jermy & Mickel 1975, one of five subfamilies of Pteridaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adiantum , the walking fern or maidenhair fern, is a genus of about 250 species of ferns in the Vittarioideae subfamily of the family Pteridaceae, though some researchers place it in its own family, Adiantaceae
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The genus name comes from Greek, meaning "not wetting", referring to the fronds' ability to shed water without becoming wet
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adrien is a given name and surname, and the French spelling for the name Adrian
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is also the masculine form of the feminine name Adrienne
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Surname:
Caroline Adrien (born 1987), French kitesurfer
Jeff Adrien (born 1986), American basketball player
Martin-Joseph Adrien (1766-1823), French operatic bass
Adrien is also the name of a main character in the show called Miraculous: Tales of Ladybug and Cat Noir
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His superhero persona is Chat (Cat) Noir
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 (Black cat in French)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Adige (Italian pronunciation: [ˈaːdidʒe]; German: Etsch [ɛtʃ]; Venetian: Àdexe; Romansh:  Adisch ; Ladin: Adesc; Latin: Athesis; Ancient Greek: Ἄθεσις) is the second longest river in Italy after the Po, rising in the Alps in the province of South Tyrol near the Italian border with Austria and Switzerland, flowing 410 kilometres (250 mi) through most of North-East Italy to the Adriatic Sea
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adipocere (), also known as corpse, grave or mortuary wax, is a wax-like organic substance formed by the anaerobic bacterial hydrolysis of fat in tissue, such as body fat in corpses
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In its formation, putrefaction is replaced by a permanent firm cast of fatty tissues, internal organs, and the face
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In biology, adipose tissue , body fat, or simply fat is a loose connective tissue composed mostly of adipocytes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In addition to adipocytes, adipose tissue contains the stromal vascular fraction (SVF) of cells including preadipocytes, fibroblasts, vascular endothelial cells and a variety of immune cells such as adipose tissue macrophages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adipose tissue is derived from preadipocytes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Its main role is to store energy in the form of lipids, although it also cushions and insulates the body
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Far from being hormonally inert, adipose tissue has, in recent years, been recognized as a major endocrine organ, as it produces hormones such as leptin, estrogen, resistin, and the cytokine TNFα
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The two types of adipose tissue are white adipose tissue (WAT), which stores energy, and brown adipose tissue (BAT), which generates body heat
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The formation of adipose tissue appears to be controlled in part by the adipose gene
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adipose tissue – more specifically brown adipose tissue – was first identified by the Swiss naturalist Conrad Gessner in 1551
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In biology, adipose tissue , body fat, or simply fat is a loose connective tissue composed mostly of adipocytes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In addition to adipocytes, adipose tissue contains the stromal vascular fraction (SVF) of cells including preadipocytes, fibroblasts, vascular endothelial cells and a variety of immune cells such as adipose tissue macrophages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adipose tissue is derived from preadipocytes

 Its main role is to store energy in the form of lipids, although it also cushions and insulates the body

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An adit (from Latin aditus, entrance) is an entrance to an underground mine which is horizontal or nearly horizontal, by which the mine can be entered, drained of water, ventilated, and minerals extracted at the lowest convenient level
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adits are also used to explore for mineral veins
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In the Vedas, Aditi (Sanskrit: अदिति "limitless") is mother of the gods (devamata) and all twelve zodiacal spirits from whose cosmic matrix, the heavenly bodies were born
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As celestial mother of every existing form and being, the synthesis of all things, she is associated with space (akasa) and with mystic speech (Vāc)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She may be seen as a feminized form of Brahma and associated with the primal substance (mulaprakriti) in Vedanta
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She is mentioned nearly 80 times in the Rigveda: the verse "Daksha sprang from Aditi and Aditi from Daksha" is seen by Theosophists as a reference to "the eternal cyclic re-birth of the same divine Essence" and divine wisdom
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In contrast, the Puranas, such as the Shiva Purana and the Bhagavata Purana, suggest that Aditi is wife of sage Kashyap and gave birth to the Adityas such as Indra, Surya, and also Vamana
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In Hinduism, Ādityas (Sanskrit: आदित्य, pronounced [ɑːd̪it̪jɐ]), meaning "of Aditi", refers to the offspring of Aditi
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name, Aditya, is used in the singular to mean the Sun God, Surya
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The Bhagavata Purana lists a total of twelve Adityas as Sun-gods
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In each month of the year a different Aditya is said to shine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Each of these Adityas is a different expression of Lord Vishnu in the form of the Sun-God
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Addiction is a brain disorder characterized by compulsive engagement in rewarding stimuli, despite adverse consequences
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Despite the involvement of a number of psychosocial factors, a biological process – one which is induced by repeated exposure to an addictive stimulus – is the core pathology that drives the development and maintenance of an addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The two properties that characterize all addictive stimuli are that they are reinforcing (i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, they increase the likelihood that a person will seek repeated exposure to them) and intrinsically rewarding (i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, they are perceived as being inherently positive, desirable, and pleasurable)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Addiction is a disorder of the brain's reward system which arises through transcriptional and epigenetic mechanisms and occurs over time from chronically high levels of exposure to an addictive stimulus (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, morphine, cocaine, sexual intercourse, gambling, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ΔFosB, a gene transcription factor, is a critical component and common factor in the development of virtually all forms of behavioral and drug addictions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Two decades of research into ΔFosB's role in addiction have demonstrated that addiction arises, and the associated compulsive behavior intensifies or attenuates, along with the overexpression of ΔFosB in the D1-type medium spiny neurons of the nucleus accumbens
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Due to the causal relationship between ΔFosB expression and addictions, it is used preclinically as an addiction biomarker
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 ΔFosB expression in these neurons directly and positively regulates drug self-administration and reward sensitization through positive reinforcement, while decreasing sensitivity to aversion
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

As described by two groups of researchers, addiction exacts an "astoundingly high financial and human toll" on individuals and society as a whole through the direct adverse effects of drugs, associated healthcare costs, long-term complications (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, lung cancer with smoking tobacco, liver cirrhosis with drinking alcohol, or meth mouth from intravenous methamphetamine), the functional consequences of altered neural plasticity in the brain, and the consequent loss of productivity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Classic hallmarks of addiction include impaired control over substances or behavior, preoccupation with substance or behavior, and continued use despite consequences
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Habits and patterns associated with addiction are typically characterized by immediate gratification (short-term reward), coupled with delayed deleterious effects (long-term costs)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Examples of drug and behavioral addictions include: alcoholism, amphetamine addiction, cocaine addiction, nicotine addiction, opiate addiction, food addiction, gambling addiction, and sexual addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The only behavioral addiction recognized by the DSM-5 is gambling addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term addiction is misused frequently to refer to other compulsive behaviors or disorders, particularly dependence, in news media
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An important distinction between drug addiction and dependence is that drug dependence is a disorder in which cessation of drug use results in an unpleasant state of withdrawal, which can lead to further drug use
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Addiction is the compulsive use of a substance or performance of a behavior that is independent of withdrawal
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adventitious has various meanings in various disciplines and in general usage
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adventitious is from the Latin root advenire, meaning "to come to" and in English the meanings tend to have connections to "accidental/ casual occurrence", "arising from without; supervenient, accidental, casual"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

People sometimes speak of an event or occurrence as being "random", when the word "adventitious", or perhaps "accidental", might be more strictly correct
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In linguistics, an adjective (abbreviated adj) is a describing word, the main syntactic role of which is to qualify a noun or noun phrase, giving more information about the object signified
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adjectives are one of the English parts of speech, although historically they were classed together with the nouns
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Certain words that were traditionally considered to be adjectives, including the, this, my, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, are today usually classed separately, as determiners
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Tree-adjoining grammar (TAG) is a grammar formalism defined by Aravind Joshi
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Tree-adjoining grammars are somewhat similar to context-free grammars, but the elementary unit of rewriting is the tree rather than the symbol
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Whereas context-free grammars have rules for rewriting symbols as strings of other symbols, tree-adjoining grammars have rules for rewriting the nodes of trees as other trees (see tree (graph theory) and tree (data structure))
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In parliamentary procedure, an adjournment ends a meeting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It could be done using a motion to adjourn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A time for another meeting could be set using the motion to fix the time to which to adjourn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This motion establishes an adjourned meeting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

To adjourn to another time or place means to suspend proceedings until a later stated time or place
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In parliamentary procedure, an adjournment ends a meeting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It could be done using a motion to adjourn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A time for another meeting could be set using the motion to fix the time to which to adjourn
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This motion establishes an adjourned meeting
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

To adjourn to another time or place means to suspend proceedings until a later stated time or place

Charlize Theron ( char-LEEZ THERR-ən or  shar-LEES THAIR-ən; Afrikaans: [ʃarˈlis trɔn]; born 7 August 1975) is a South African and American actress and film producer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She has starred in several Hollywood films, such as The Devil's Advocate (1997), Mighty Joe Young (1998), The Cider House Rules (1999), Monster (2003), The Italian Job (2003), Hancock (2008), Snow White and the Huntsman (2012), Prometheus (2012), A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014), Mad Max: Fury Road (2015), The Fate of the Furious (2017), and Atomic Blonde (2017)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Theron received critical acclaim for her portrayal of serial killer Aileen Wuornos in Monster (2003), for which she won the Academy Award, Silver Bear, Golden Globe Award, and Screen Actors Guild Award for Best Actress among several other accolades, becoming the first South African to win an Academy Award in a major acting category
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She received Academy Award and Golden Globe Award nominations for her performance in the sexual harassment-themed drama North Country in 2005 and a Golden Globe Award nomination for her performance in Jason Reitman's 2011 film Young Adult
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Theron became a U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 citizen in 2007, while retaining her South African citizenship
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the late 2000s, she moved into the field of producing, both in television and film
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She founded and owns the production company Denver and Delilah Productions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2006, she produced the documentary East of Havana
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 She had producing credits on the films The Burning Plain (2008) and Dark Places (2015), both of which she starred in
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In 2016, Time named her in the annual Time 100 most influential people list
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adjudication is the legal process by which an arbiter or judge reviews evidence and argumentation, including legal reasoning set forth by opposing parties or litigants to come to a decision which determines rights and obligations between the parties involved
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An adjudicator is someone who presides, judges, and arbitrates during a formal dispute or competition
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They have numerous purposes, including preliminary legal judgments, to determine applicant eligibility, or to assess contenders' performance in competitions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In linguistics, an adjunct is an optional, or structurally dispensable, part of a sentence, clause, or phrase that, if removed or discarded, will not otherwise affect the remainder of the sentence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Example: In the sentence John helped Bill in Central Park, the phrase in Central Park is an adjunct
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A more detailed definition of the adjunct emphasizes its attribute as a modifying form, word, or phrase that depends on another form, word, or phrase, being an element of clause structure with adverbial function
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 An adjunct is not an argument (nor is it a predicative expression), and an argument is not an adjunct
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The argument–adjunct distinction is central in most theories of syntax and semantics
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The terminology used to denote arguments and adjuncts can vary depending on the theory at hand
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some dependency grammars, for instance, employ the term circonstant (instead of adjunct), following Tesnière (1959)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The area of grammar that explores the nature of predicates, their arguments, and adjuncts is called valency theory
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Predicates have valency; they determine the number and type of arguments that can or must appear in their environment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The valency of predicates is also investigated in terms of subcategorization
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adoration (Latin) is respect, reverence, strong admiration or devotion in a certain person, place, or thing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term comes from the Latin adōrātiō, meaning "to give homage or worship to someone or something"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adjara (Georgian: აჭარა [at͡ʃʼara]), officially known as the Autonomous Republic of Adjara (Georgian: აჭარის ავტონომიური რესპუბლიკა [at͡ʃʼaris avtʼɔnɔmiuri rɛspʼublikʼa]), is a historical, geographic and political-administrative region of Georgia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Located in the country's southwestern corner, Adjara lies on the coast of the Black Sea near the foot of the Lesser Caucasus Mountains, north of Turkey
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is an important tourism destination and includes Georgia's second-largest city of Batumi as its capital
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 About 350,000 people live on its 2,880 km2
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adjara is home to the Adjarians, a regional subgroup of Georgians
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adjara's name can be spelled in a number of ways, including Ajara, Ajaria, Adjaria, Adzharia, and Achara, among others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Under the Soviet Union, Adjara was part of the Georgian Soviet Socialist Republic as the Adjarian ASSR
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An adjustable spanner (UK, and most other English-speaking countries) or adjustable wrench (US and Canada) is an open-end wrench with a movable jaw, allowing it to be used with different sizes of fastener head (nut, bolt, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
) rather than just one fastener size, as with a conventional fixed spanner
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Several other names are in use, including the US trademark crescent wrench
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Claims adjuster (claim adjuster), or claims handler (claim handler), investigates insurance claims by interviewing the claimant and witnesses, consulting police and hospital records, and inspecting property damage to determine the extent of the company's liability
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the United Kingdom, Ireland, Australia, South Africa, the Caribbean and New Zealand the term loss adjuster is used
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other claims adjusters who represent policyholders may aid in the preparation of an insurance claim
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the United States, a claims adjuster's duties typically extend to include the following elements:
Verify an insurance policy exists for the insured person and/or property
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In general, these are written by the policy-holding insurance company
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Risk(s) of loss(es), or damages to property, culminating in the loss of property and or bodily injury
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

After completing the above investigations, evaluate the covered injuries and/or damages that have been determined according to the coverage grants
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Negotiate a settlement according to the applicable law(s), and identify coverages for which the insured is covered, following best insurance practices
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A Claims adjuster or Public Adjuster does not, and should not, engage in the practice of law
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 While adjusting the claim does mean applying the loss circumstances to the insured's policy, it does not account for if and when there becomes an issue of coverage, which is a matter and practice of Law, and should only be engaged by a properly licensed attorney
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In casualty insurance the main type of coverages include but may not be limited to the followings:
First party auto and other than auto coverages (sometimes referred to collision and comprehensive coverages) there are numerous types of first party insurance coverages for any kind of risk of loss or damages
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Third party liability for property damage of others property and bodily injury
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 (in law terms these are "tort" claims)

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Certain words that were traditionally considered to be adjectives, including the, this, my, etc
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, are today usually classed separately, as determiners
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adjutant is a military rank or appointment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In some armies, including most English-speaking ones, it is an officer who assists a more senior officer, while in other armies, especially French-speaking ones, it is a non-commissioned officer (NCO), normally corresponding roughly to a staff sergeant or warrant officer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An adjutant general is commander of an army's administrative services
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adjutant is a military rank or appointment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In some armies, including most English-speaking ones, it is an officer who assists a more senior officer, while in other armies, especially French-speaking ones, it is a non-commissioned officer (NCO), normally corresponding roughly to a staff sergeant or warrant officer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An adjutant general is commander of an army's administrative services
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An adjuvant is a pharmacological or immunological agent that modifies the effect of other agents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adjuvants may be added to a vaccine to modify the immune response by boosting it such as to give a higher amount of antibodies and a longer-lasting protection, thus minimizing the amount of injected foreign material
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adjuvants may also be used to enhance the efficacy of a vaccine by helping to modify the immune response to particular types of immune system cells: for example, by activating T cells instead of antibody-secreting B cells depending on the purpose of the vaccine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adjuvants are also used in the production of antibodies from immunized animals
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are different classes of adjuvants that can push immune response in different directions, but the most commonly used adjuvants include aluminum hydroxide and paraffin oil
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adjutant is a military rank or appointment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In some armies, including most English-speaking ones, it is an officer who assists a more senior officer, while in other armies, especially French-speaking ones, it is a non-commissioned officer (NCO), normally corresponding roughly to a staff sergeant or warrant officer
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

An adjutant general is commander of an army's administrative services
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adlumia is a genus of two species in the Papaveraceae family
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 One species, A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 fungosa, is commonly known as the Allegheny vine, climbing fumitory, or mountain fringe
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is found in the eastern US, north of VA and TN, as far west as IA and MN, as well as in eastern Canada
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The other species, A
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 asiatica, is native to Korea and immediately neighbouring parts of China and southeast Russia
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The genus name derives from John Adlum (1759–1836), a surveyor, associate judge, plantsman and agriculturist who ran an 80 ha (200 acre) experimental farm in Georgetown, Washington, D
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
C
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Addams is a patronymic surname of English origin from the given name Adam
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There are other spellings
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Notable people with the surname include:

Christian Hejnal Addams (born 1969) American producer & musician
