William Addams (1777–1858), American politician, U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 representative from Pennsylvania
Fictional characters:
“The Addams Family”, American print cartoon by Charles Addams; and television series, films, and video games based on the cartoon, though the patriarch of the family is of Spanish origin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Port St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Charles marina is a luxury marina development situated on the western coast of Barbados
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Found within the parish of Saint Peter, the marina is in Heywoods and is in close proximity to Speightstown
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Port St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Charles marina contains an admeasurement of sum 1549 square metres, and is made up exclusive villas, condos and apartments, and a small inland lagoon area (with a depth of 14 feet at low tide) and adorned with facilities for residents to berth their yachts close to their vacation homes
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 These berths range from 30 ft to 110 ft in length
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Water, electricity, telephone and television connection are available at all 50 ft to 110 ft berths and some of the smaller berths
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In addition, there are six mega-yacht berths located on the offshore breakwater
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The offshore breakwater was designed by Canada-based HCCL
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The marina is host to a branch of the Coastguard, Police, Immigration and Customs facilities operating on the offshore breakwater
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 As such, it is one of two officially designated sea-based ports of entry in Barbados—the Deep Water Harbour in the capital city of Bridgetown being the other
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Also found in the development are a "heliport" to transport guests to the Grantley Adams International Airport or the Bridgetown Heliport, a health spa, and just off the coast of the Marina lies the Tom Snooch Reef
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The inner lagoon of Port St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Charles is restricted to residents or persons staying at the marina development
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Properties at the Port St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Charles Marina are managed by Port St
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Charles Development Ltd
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

On the outermost portion of the breakwater is a Heliport
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Identification of Medicinal Products (IDMP) is a set of five ISO norms which has been developed in response to a world-wide demand for internationally harmonized specifications for medicinal products
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 IDMP provides the basis for the unique identification of medicinal products, it facilitates the activities of medicines regulatory agencies world-wide by jurisdiction for a variety of regulatory activities (development, registration and life cycle management of medicinal products; pharmacovigilance and risk management)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 IDMP is the base for the Marketing authorization of medicinal products in Europe
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It requires the five ISO Norms being implemented in the Marketing Authorization Application process
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Messaging specifications are included as an integral part of the IDMP standards
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They describe and protect the integrity of the interactions for the submission of regulated medicinal product information in the context of the unique product identification; they include acknowledgement of receipt including the validation of transmitted information
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Health level Seven (HL7) Message Exchange are normative within the IDMP Standards
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

IDMP Standards are designed to allow unambiguous identification of products across regions to improve the robustness of pharmacovigilance and regulatory activities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 they can also be applied to Investigational Medicinal Products
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

IDMP Standards are completed with Implementation Guides which are currently in development (2017)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The standards can be found from ISO TC 215´s deliveries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Admiral is one of the highest naval ranks in some navies, and in many navies is the highest rank
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is usually abbreviated to "Adm" or "ADM"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The rank is generally thought to have originated in Sicily from a conflation of Arabic: أمير البحر‎‎, amīr al-baḥr, "commander of the sea", with Latin admirabilis ("admirable") or admiratus ("admired"), the first was admiral Lumu Farouk, although alternative etymologies derive the word directly from Latin, or from the Turkish military and naval rank miralay
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In the Commonwealth and the U
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
S
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, a "full" admiral is equivalent to a "full" general in the army, and is above vice admiral and below admiral of the fleet (or fleet admiral)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In NATO, admirals have a rank code of OF-9 as a four-star rank
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Admiralty formerly known as the Office of the Admiralty and Marine Affairs, was the government department responsible for the command of the Royal Navy first in the Kingdom of England, second in the Kingdom of Great Britain, and from 1801-1964, the United Kingdom and former British Empire
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Originally exercised by a single person, the Lord High Admiral, the Admiralty was, from the early 18th century onwards, almost invariably put "in commission" and exercised by the Lords Commissioners of the Admiralty, who sat on the Board of Admiralty
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In 1964, the functions of the Admiralty were transferred to a new Admiralty Board, which is a committee of the tri-service Defence Council of the United Kingdom and part of the Navy Department  of the Ministry of Defence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The new Admiralty Board meets only twice a year, and the day-to-day running of the Royal Navy is controlled by a Navy Board (not to be confused with the historic Navy Board described later in this article)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is common for the various authorities now in charge of the Royal Navy to be referred to as simply The Admiralty
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The title of Lord High Admiral of the United Kingdom was vested in the monarch from 1964 to 2011
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The title was awarded to Philip, Duke of Edinburgh by Queen Elizabeth II on his 90th birthday
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 There also continues to be a Vice-Admiral of the United Kingdom and a Rear-Admiral of the United Kingdom, both of which are honorary offices
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Admiration is a social emotion elicited by people of competence, talent, or skill exceeding standards
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Admiration facilitates social learning in groups and motivates self-improvement through learning from role-models
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Gallup’s most admired man and woman poll is an annual poll that Gallup has conducted at the end of most years since 1948
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Americans are asked, without prompting, to say what man and woman "living today in any part of the world, do [they] admire most?" The result is published as a top ten list
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Most years the most admired man is the sitting President of the United States and the most admired woman is or has been the First Lady of the United States
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
"What a piece of work is a man!" is a phrase within a monologue by Hamlet in William Shakespeare's eponymous play
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Hamlet is reflecting, at first admiringly, and then despairingly, on the human condition
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
In electrical engineering, admittance is a measure of how easily a circuit or device will allow a current to flow
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is defined as the reciprocal of impedance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The SI unit of admittance is the siemens (symbol S); the older, synonymous unit is mho, and its symbol is ℧ (an upside-down uppercase omega Ω)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Oliver Heaviside coined the term admittance in December 1887
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Admittance is defined as

  
    
      
        Y
        ≡
        
          
            1
            Z
          
        
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle Y\equiv {\frac {1}{Z}}\,}
  
where
Y is the admittance, measured in siemens
Z is the impedance, measured in ohms
Resistance is a measure of the opposition of a circuit to the flow of a steady current, while impedance takes into account not only the resistance but also dynamic effects (known as reactance)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Likewise, admittance is not only a measure of the ease with which a steady current can flow, but also the dynamic effects of the material's susceptance to polarization:

  
    
      
        Y
        =
        G
        +
        j
        B
        
      
    
    {\displaystyle Y=G+jB\,}
  
where

  
    
      
        Y
      
    
    {\displaystyle Y}
   is the admittance, measured in siemens
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


  
    
      
        G
      
    
    {\displaystyle G}
   is the conductance, measured in siemens
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


  
    
      
        B
      
    
    {\displaystyle B}
   is the susceptance, measured in siemens
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------


  
    
      
        
          j
          
            2
          
        
        =
        −
        1
      
    
    {\displaystyle j^{2}=-1}
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

        −

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) film rating system is used in the United States and its territories to rate a film's suitability for certain audiences based on its content
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The MPAA rating system is a voluntary scheme that is not enforced by law; films can be exhibited without a rating, although many theaters refuse to exhibit non-rated or NC-17 rated films
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Non-members of MPAA may also submit films for rating
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other media, such as television programs and video games, is rated by other entities such as the ESRB and the TV Parental Guidelines
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The MPAA rating system is one of various motion picture rating systems that are used to help parents decide what films are appropriate for their children
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is administered by the Classification & Ratings Administration (CARA), an independent division of the MPAA
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Motion Picture Association of America (MPAA) film rating system is used in the United States and its territories to rate a film's suitability for certain audiences based on its content
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The MPAA rating system is a voluntary scheme that is not enforced by law; films can be exhibited without a rating, although many theaters refuse to exhibit non-rated or NC-17 rated films
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Non-members of MPAA may also submit films for rating
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Other media, such as television programs and video games, is rated by other entities such as the ESRB and the TV Parental Guidelines
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The MPAA rating system is one of various motion picture rating systems that are used to help parents decide what films are appropriate for their children
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is administered by the Classification & Ratings Administration (CARA), an independent division of the MPAA
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adoration (Latin) is respect, reverence, strong admiration or devotion in a certain person, place, or thing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term comes from the Latin adōrātiō, meaning "to give homage or worship to someone or something"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adonis (; Greek: Ἄδωνις) is a divine figure in Greek mythology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His legend possibly derives from ancient Canaanite religion; the ancient Greeks themselves believed him to be of oriental origin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He is portrayed as a beautiful youth and his cult was associated with fertility
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There has been much scholarship over the centuries concerning the multiple roles of Adonis, his meaning and purpose in Greek religious beliefs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Modern scholarship sometimes describes him as an annually renewed, ever-youthful vegetation god, a life-death-rebirth deity whose nature is tied to the calendar
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His name is often applied in modern times to handsome youths, of whom he is the archetype
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Admonition (or "being admonished") is a punishment under Scots law when an offender has been found guilty but is neither imprisoned nor fined but receives verbal discipline and is afterwards set free; the conviction is still recorded
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This disposition is comparable to an absolute discharge in jurisdictions where an absolute discharge involves the recording of a conviction (i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, where the "discharge" is from punishment only) but stands in contrast to an absolute discharge in jurisdictions in which an absolute discharge does not involve the recording of a conviction (i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, where the "discharge" is from conviction as well)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

It is usually the result of either the strict application of law where no real wrong has been caused or where other circumstances (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 time already spent in custody or attending court) make further punishment unjust in the circumstances specific to the case involved
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Currently, admonition holds a 5 year disclosure period due to absence of mention in the Rehabilitation of Offenders Act 1974 and thus being classified as an "other" offence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Admonition (or "being admonished") is a punishment under Scots law when an offender has been found guilty but is neither imprisoned nor fined but receives verbal discipline and is afterwards set free; the conviction is still recorded

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The index finger (also referred to as forefinger, first finger, pointer finger, trigger finger, digitus secundus, digitus II, and many other terms), is the first finger and the second digit of a human hand
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is located between the first and third digits, between the thumb and the middle finger
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is usually the most dextrous and sensitive finger of the hand, though not the longest – it is shorter than the middle finger, and may be shorter or longer than the ring finger – see digit ratio
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

"Index finger" literally means "pointing finger", from the same Latin source as indicate; its anatomical names are "index finger" and "second digit"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The adrenal glands (also known as suprarenal glands) are endocrine glands that produce a variety of hormones including adrenaline and the steroids aldosterone and cortisol
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They are found above the kidneys
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Each gland has an outer cortex which produces steroid hormones and an inner medulla
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The adrenal cortex itself is divided into three zones: zona glomerulosa, the zona fasciculata and the zona reticularis
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The adrenal cortex produces three main types of steroid hormones: mineralocorticoids, glucocorticoids, and androgens
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Mineralocorticoids (such as aldosterone) produced in the zona glomerulosa help in the regulation of blood pressure and electrolyte balance
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The glucocorticoids cortisol and corticosterone are synthesized in the zona fasciculata; their functions include the regulation of metabolism and immune system suppression
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The innermost layer of the cortex, the zona reticularis, produces androgens that are converted to fully functional sex hormones in the gonads and other target organs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The production of steroid hormones is called steroidogenesis, and involves a number of reactions and processes that take place in cortical cells
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The medulla produces the catecholamines adrenaline and noradrenaline, which function to produce a rapid response throughout the body in stress situations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A number of endocrine diseases involve dysfunctions of the adrenal gland
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Overproduction of cortisol leads to Cushing's syndrome, whereas insufficient production is associated with Addison's disease
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Congenital adrenal hyperplasia is a genetic disease produced by dysregulation of endocrine control mechanisms
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 A variety of tumors can arise from adrenal tissue and are commonly found in medical imaging when searching for other diseases
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adnoun is a linguistic term used with two different meanings
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adobe (US: , UK: ; Spanish: [aˈðoβe]) is a building material made from earth and often organic material
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adobe means mudbrick in Spanish, but in some English speaking regions of Spanish heritage it refers to any kind of earth construction, as most adobe buildings are similar in appearance to cob and rammed earth buildings
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adobe is among the earliest building materials, and is used throughout the world
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adobo or Adobar (Spanish: marinade, sauce, or seasoning) is the immersion of raw food in a stock (or sauce) composed variously of paprika, oregano, salt, garlic, and vinegar to preserve and enhance its flavor
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The Portuguese variant is known as Carne de vinha d'alhos
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The practice is native to Iberia, namely Spanish cuisine and Portuguese cuisine
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It was widely adopted in Latin America and other Spanish and Portuguese colonies, including the Azores and Madeira
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In the Philippines, the name adobo was given by the Spanish colonists to an indigenous cooking method that also uses vinegar, which, although superficially similar, had developed independently of Spanish influence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adolescence (from Latin adolescere, meaning 'to grow up') is a transitional stage of physical and psychological development that generally occurs during the period from puberty to legal adulthood (age of majority)
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adolescence is usually associated with the teenage years, but its physical, psychological or cultural expressions may begin earlier and end later
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, puberty now typically begins during preadolescence, particularly in females
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Physical growth (particularly in males), and cognitive development can extend into the early twenties
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Thus age provides only a rough marker of adolescence, and scholars have found it difficult to agree upon a precise definition of adolescence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

A thorough understanding of adolescence in society depends on information from various perspectives, including psychology, biology, history, sociology, education, and anthropology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Within all of these perspectives, adolescence is viewed as a transitional period between childhood and adulthood, whose cultural purpose is the preparation of children for adult roles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is a period of multiple transitions involving education, training, employment and unemployment, as well as transitions from one living circumstance to another
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The end of adolescence and the beginning of adulthood varies by country and by function
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Furthermore, even within a single nation state or culture there can be different ages at which an individual is considered (chronologically and legally) mature enough for society to entrust them with certain privileges and responsibilities
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Such milestones include driving a vehicle, having legal sexual relations, serving in the armed forces or on a jury, purchasing and drinking alcohol, voting, entering into contracts, finishing certain levels of education, and marriage
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adolescence is usually accompanied by an increased independence allowed by the parents or legal guardians, including less supervision as compared to preadolescence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In studying adolescent development, adolescence can be defined biologically, as the physical transition marked by the onset of puberty and the termination of physical growth; cognitively, as changes in the ability to think abstractly and multi-dimensionally; or socially, as a period of preparation for adult roles
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Major pubertal and biological changes include changes to the sex organs, height, weight, and muscle mass, as well as major changes in brain structure and organization
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Cognitive advances encompass both increment in knowledge and in the ability to think abstractly and to reason more effectively
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The study of adolescent development often involves interdisciplinary collaborations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, researchers in neuroscience or bio-behavioral health might focus on pubertal changes in brain structure and its effects on cognition or social relations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Sociologists interested in adolescence might focus on the acquisition of social roles (e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
g
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
, worker or romantic partner) and how this varies across cultures or social conditions
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Developmental psychologists might focus on changes in relations with parents and peers as a function of school structure and pubertal status
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Some scientists have questioned the universality of adolescence as a developmental phase, and argue that traits often considered typical of adolescents are not inherent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
An adonic (Latin: adoneus) is a unit of Aeolic verse, a five-syllable metrical foot consisting of a dactyl followed by a trochee
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The last line of a Sapphic stanza is an adonic
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The pattern (with "-" a long and "u" a short syllable) is: "- u u - -" when the pattern ends with a spondee (i
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
e
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 --) or " -uu -u " if a trochee is intended
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adonis (; Greek: Ἄδωνις) is a divine figure in Greek mythology
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His legend possibly derives from ancient Canaanite religion; the ancient Greeks themselves believed him to be of oriental origin
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 He is portrayed as a beautiful youth and his cult was associated with fertility
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

There has been much scholarship over the centuries concerning the multiple roles of Adonis, his meaning and purpose in Greek religious beliefs
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Modern scholarship sometimes describes him as an annually renewed, ever-youthful vegetation god, a life-death-rebirth deity whose nature is tied to the calendar
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 His name is often applied in modern times to handsome youths, of whom he is the archetype
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adolf, also spelled Adolph and sometimes Latinised to Adolphus, is a given name used in German-speaking countries, in Scandinavia, in the Netherlands and Flanders and to a lesser extent in various Central European countries
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adolphus can also appear as a surname, as in John Adolphus, the English historian
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The name is a compound derived from the Old High German Athalwolf, a composition of athal, or adal, meaning noble, and wolf; compare Rudolf
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The name is cognate to the Anglo-Saxon name Æthelwulf
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------



 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
The Adopted (original title: Les Adoptés) is a 2011 French drama film directed and co-written by Mélanie Laurent
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It stars Marie Denarnaud, Denis Ménochet, Laurent and Clémentine Célarié
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Denis Ménochet won a Lumières Award for Most Promising Actor for his performance in the film
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adoption is a process whereby a person assumes the parenting of another, usually a child, from that person's biological or legal parent or parents, and, in so doing, permanently transfers all rights and responsibilities, along with filiation, from the biological parent or parents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Unlike guardianship or other systems designed for the care of the young, adoption is intended to effect a permanent change in status and as such requires societal recognition, either through legal or religious sanction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Historically, some societies have enacted specific laws governing adoption; where others have tried to achieve adoption through less formal means, notably via contracts that specified inheritance rights and parental responsibilities without an accompanying transfer of filiation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Modern systems of adoption, arising in the 20th century, tend to be governed by comprehensive statutes and regulations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adoption is a process whereby a person assumes the parenting of another, usually a child, from that person's biological or legal parent or parents, and, in so doing, permanently transfers all rights and responsibilities, along with filiation, from the biological parent or parents
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Unlike guardianship or other systems designed for the care of the young, adoption is intended to effect a permanent change in status and as such requires societal recognition, either through legal or religious sanction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Historically, some societies have enacted specific laws governing adoption; where others have tried to achieve adoption through less formal means, notably via contracts that specified inheritance rights and parental responsibilities without an accompanying transfer of filiation
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Modern systems of adoption, arising in the 20th century, tend to be governed by comprehensive statutes and regulations
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adaptive behavior refers to behavior that enables a person (usually used in the context of children) to get along in his or her environment with greatest success and least conflict with others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 This is a term used in the areas of psychology and special education
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Adaptive behavior relates to every day skills or tasks that the average person is able to complete, similar to the term life skills
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Nonconstructive or disruptive social or personal behaviors can sometimes be used to achieve a constructive outcome
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, a constant repetitive action could be re-focused on something that creates or builds something
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 In other words, the behavior can be adapted to something else
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

In contrast, maladaptive behavior is a type of behavior that is often used to reduce one's anxiety, but the result is dysfunctional and non-productive
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 For example, avoiding situations because you have unrealistic fears may initially reduce your anxiety, but it is non-productive in alleviating the actual problem in the long term
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Maladaptive behavior is frequently used as an indicator of abnormality or mental dysfunction, since its assessment is relatively free from subjectivity
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 However, many behaviors considered moral can be maladaptive, such as dissent or abstinence
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Maladaptive behavior may be affected by mechanisms in the brain that lead to addiction
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Regarding addiction as a disease provides opportunities for its treatment
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

Adaptive behavior reflects an individual’s social and practical competence to meet the demands of everyday living
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 Behavior patterns change throughout a person's development, across life settings and social constructs, changes in personal values, and the expectations of others
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 It is important to assess adaptive behavior in order to determine how well an individual functions in daily life: vocationally, socially and educationally
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adoration (Latin) is respect, reverence, strong admiration or devotion in a certain person, place, or thing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term comes from the Latin adōrātiō, meaning "to give homage or worship to someone or something"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Adoration (Latin) is respect, reverence, strong admiration or devotion in a certain person, place, or thing
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The term comes from the Latin adōrātiō, meaning "to give homage or worship to someone or something"
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
Seventeen (Hangul: 세븐틴), also stylized as SEVENTEEN or SVT, is a South Korean boy group formed by Pledis Entertainment in 2015
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 The group consists of thirteen members who are separated into three sub-units, each with different areas of specialization: a 'Hip-Hop Unit', 'Vocal Unit', and 'Performance Unit'
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
 They have released one studio album and four extended plays
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

The group's members have been deeply involved in the composition and production of their discography and choreography since debut, leading to the nickname "self-producing" idol group
 -----------------------------END---------------------------------

 -----------------------------END---------------------------------
